Spencer certainly deserved her Oscar for the great scenes she is in whether serious or funny, the most memorable of course being the pie sequence, Davis could have won as well for her emotional and established lead performance, Stone is a great choice to play the woman writing the novel to hopefully make some change, and many supporting cast members are great too, I'd say particularly Howard as the nasty snobbish ringleader with disrespectful and very racist views. It is a terrific film told from the perspectives of the black women who want to speak out for all black people who are mistreated in the world and the woman hoping to help them speak out for those suffering the torment, and it has all the emotions, good and bad, to make a well-paced and most worthwhile drama. It was nominated the Oscar for Best Motion Picture of the Year, and it was nominated the BAFTAs for Best Film and Best Adapted Screenplay, and it was nominated the Golden Globe for Best Motion Picture - Drama and Best Original Song for Mary J. Blige's "The Living Proof". Worth watching!

I can only echo the other reviews already written about this outstanding movie. The performances are incredible, especially Viola Davis, who shines in her role.Credit also goes to Tate Taylor, who wrote the screenplay and directed this wonderful film.The story is poignant, but also funny, and describes the racism that took place in the South during the Sixties. I can only highly recommend THE HELP. DO NOT miss this movie. It's one of the best of 2011, if not THE best.

An aspiring author (Emma Stone) during the civil rights movement of the 1960s decides to write a book detailing the African-American maids' point of view on the white families for which they work, and the hardships they go through on a daily basis.Exactly how accurate this is, I have no idea. My assumption is that it is fairly close to the truth. The idea that a maid is the daughter of a maid, and that maid is the daughter of a "house slave"... this seems about right. Because slavery ended does not mean racism went away. And because slavery ended, it does not mean the former slaves suddenly had access to better jobs. Maids and butlers seem like the next step to keep the (unfortunate) continuity.The costumes and hair deserve much credit. Emma Stone unfortunately looks like Lindsay Lohan in this film, but others are almost unrecognizable. Allison Janney? Wow. A simple change of hair and she is whole different person...

reviews.review_title: The black maids of Jackson, Mississippi, the "help."
reviews.content: I realize this is a work of fiction, based on a book, but having lived through most of this, growing up in the south in the 1950s and 1960s, the story seems to be very plausible. The 1950s and 1960s that I knew, and depicted in this movie, were part of the "transition" years between slavery, which was abolished, and true freedom. Well-off white families had black maids, often referred to as "the help", paid relatively little and, at least depicted here, ordered around and expected to be slaves to their employer, even though they were "free" to leave. But they needed work, times were hard, and they often raised white children while other family members raised their own children. That is the situation in this movie, depicted in Jackson, Mississippi. Was Missisippi in the 1950s and 1960s the most racially bigoted state? I don't know, but a former co-worker who happens to be black attended Ole Miss back then and he said it was a very difficult environment.Emma Stone is aspiring journalist Skeeter Phelan, herself raised by a black maid (Cicely Tyson) who had almost become part of the family. Now Skeeter was back home after graduating from Ole Miss and began to clearly see the situation, and how bigoted her former friends were and how poorly maids were treated. She wanted to do something significant, to give voice to their plights, and sought to write the book, The Help, based on interviews she would do with maids. Perhaps the key maid character is Viola Davis as Aibileen Clark. The other is Octavia Spencer as Minny Jackson.Skeeter's friend and now housewife is Bryce Dallas Howard as Hilly Holbrook. Hilly becomes the main activist for keeping maids separate and "in their place" which includes a petition to require all domestic employers to have a separate bathroom for their black maids. As the story moves along we witness Skeeter and Hilly becoming former friends as their personal agendas drive them in different directions.The movie is well-written and well-acted. It tells an important story of that time. While it is a very serious, and often sad, subject the story is also sprinkled liberally with humor. Especially the "special" chocolate pie that Minny bakes for Hilly after Hilly had fired her.
A powerful glimps into the lives of women of color and the stark difference of how they were treated by middle class white women.

reviews.review_title: predictability saved by the power of female acting chops, especially Viola Davis
reviews.content: I may be giving this a higher rating that it deserves; it's a predictably plotted story and you know how a lot of it's going to go, what lessons may be learned by and to whom and so on. But like The King's Speech, it's nice to see an Oscar-bait(ish) movie that has strong performances (with one exception, which I'll get to momentarily) and on its own terms is pretty good. Not very good, or great, and The Help may be overrated, but it carries a strong message and I liked seeing these actors as these characters together, for the most part.As a story surrounding the Noble White Savior(TM) it surprised me how the cast was handled very evenly (Viola Davis got a best actress, not supporting, nomination for good reason and probably should've won all things considered). I thought it would be the Emma Stone show, with her as the Mississippi writer who works for a local paper but gets inspired by what she sees with the local maids working for generations (basically linked by blood and heritage and all to slavery) and gets a book deal about what it's like for 'the Help' to work and live. I though that all these other women (this is very much a woman-centric movie as well, which is commendable, albeit directed by a man) as small side characters. Not really the case, which helps since if you get tired of seeing one character it'll soon flip over to another.I heard from a few friends in the years before seeing this that Octavia Spencer's Minny was over the top, playing up the "mmHMM" Big Black Lady stereotype and got an undeserved Oscar. I thought she was fine, and more than that really, and got to portray a fully fleshed out character, and especially put against two very different white ladies - Bryce Dallas Howard's Hilly and Jessica Chastain's Celia, both she works for at separate times - we see how she can be your best friend or your worst enemy (if you push her far enough and hard for a long time like Hilly).If I had any problem it was with Howard, though that may be more in the writing; she's the one clear antagonist, but by and large because whenever she's on screen, even if she's sitting peacefully and only saying a little bit, there's a feeling like 'oh wow, what's she about to say now or put on that ugly-mean thing that has the guise of 'Southern Gentility'. But with what little she's given I found Howard more caricature than character, while Chastain, also seemingly not given quite a lot with a white-trash lady like Celia, she was a lot more fun and interesting and had real dynamics to play with (and tragedy as well). Perhaps I'm wrong and Hilly was fun to play as well, but I'm not sure I saw it.The heart of the movie though is Davis, and without her I probably wouldn't recommend the movie as much as I do. Yes, the great Allison Janney, in just a handful of scenes, does wonders as she always does as Stone's mother, and Emma Stone's Skeeter herself is really good as well (a few moments that should be especially tear-jerkery, like with a revelation surrounding a formerly employed maid who raised Skeeter, feel earned just by how much the actresses commit and don't let a lot of falsehood enter their performances).But I just felt the movie take it up a notch or two with Davis there, and I'm sure (first-time!) director Tate Taylor knew that as well. Just simple scenes showing Aibileen playing with the little white baby girl, or protecting her under a mattress during a tornado, there's just so much warmth to play with but also a lot of horror from that period of time in history, and she finds it all. Even (maybe especially) when she says little and is just standing there, exhausted, sad, trying to hide her deep-seated rage, Davis reminds us not just about how good she can act but about the constant, just understood horrors of the black experience at that time and place.In short, The Help is highly watchable as an actor's movie, and compensates for a little over-length (I'm not sure where, but it could've lost ten minutes somewhere I bet) and with things moving at a pace where you know how things will end up with this book coming out and who may or may not get it. Needless to say the ending also caught me off guard for how emotional it got, also genuinely and to a point where I was sold by what the actors were doing but also the deeper implications of what this ending meant for everyone involved.

Went to this movie at the request of my wife, and am not sorry I did. I recommend it to anyone. One of the best movies that addresses racism realistically - You know, not everyone was evil while some were "evil"... much like the real world. The movie, was for the most part non- confrontational while accurately demonstrating a dark time in history... and shining the light on a person or group can make a difference and pride in ones self isn't a bad thing. The movie is well over two hours but keeps your interest the whole way... The movie takes you through several emotions and is very entertaining. GO see this movie!

White girl drama mixed with black opression told through cliched scenes and storylines. Too glossy, corny, and saccharine for me to take seriously. The wigs are bad. Just as bad as the Selena series on Netflix.

Having read the book, I feel that this is one of the better adaptations. The storyline is well developed and captivating. The characters are so well cast and therefore well acted. Such heartfelt emotion is conveyed in this film, it really is amazing.

reviews.review_title: Institutionalized Racism Was Never Better-The Help ****
reviews.content: Outstanding film detailing the lives of maids in Jackson, Mississippi before the Civil Rights Act of 1964.The film is outstanding not only with superb performances by the ensemble cast, it details the nastiness of prejudice and how it was deeply rooted in the institutions of the old deep south. Their rules regarding the alleged place of the African-American in society were absolutely revolting, but nevertheless, must be told.When a group of maids agree to tell their stories to a young liberal aspiring writer in the town, we're in for quite a ride. Despite the fact that she was nominated for best supporting actress, Jessica Chastain, as Celia, the writer, was given top billing. She is really the black sheep of the town with her liberal attitude.A terrific film with Viola Davis leading the way as the maid who will inspire others, as well as supporting Oscar winner Octavia Spencer, who reminded me of this century's Hattie McDaniel.It was said in the film that Margaret Mitchell never allowed Mammie (McDaniel) to express her feelings. The actresses in "The Help" did just that.

reviews.review_title: An exceptional window into the human soul
reviews.content: An exceptional window into the human soul that will shake you to the core and change your life. This meaningful and emotionally rewarding experience is unique in its honesty. If ever you questioned life, living and the differences that divide, The Help is a welcome wake-up call that serves as a reminder of how important it is to have friends that will support you through the best and worst of times. It's one of those rare films that sneaks up on you and crawls deep into your heart. It poignantly addresses important social issues without casting judgment and allows its vibrant characters to unashamedly display their weaknesses. Tate Taylor's direction is heartfelt and his well crafted screenplay gloriously magnifies Kathryn Stockett's critically acclaimed No. 1 New York Times best-selling debut novel. The cast shines in their respective roles, particularly Viola Davis as Aibileen, the heart and soul of the film, and Octavia Spencer as out-spoken Minny Jackson. Equally brilliant is Bryce Dallas Howard as the bitch from hell, with Jessica Chastain unforgettable as the wounded and lonely, fish-out-of-water Celia. The Help is a film you have to see and one you will most definitely revisit with friends and loved ones

Great movie. An emotional roller-coaster, highlighting the racial inequality and prejudices of America's past. Not perfect - some scenes seem unnecessary, and the whole thing isn't entirely seamless. (The unnecessary scenes don't weigh on the movie though, as they are often contain humorous detours). Also the ending is a bit too neat, and quick, after the slow, deliberate build-up.However, the flaws are more than negated by the beauty, spirit and emotion of the movie, and the feeling that you are witnessing history and change in the makingGreat performances all round. Octavia Spencer won the 2012 Best Supporting Actress Oscar for her portrayal of Minny and Viola Davis and Jessica Chastain got Best Actress and Best Supporting Actress nominations respectively, all of which were well-deserved. Emma Stone showed that she is more than a comedy actress, putting in a superb dramatic performance. Remaining cast, which includes Bryce Dallas Howard, Sissy Spacek and Allison Janney, don't put a foot wrong.Surely a classic: a sad reminder of the racial injustices of the past and an uplifting reminder of how these were overcome.

reviews.review_title: The Word of Truth Will Set You Free
reviews.content: "Tradition is the illusion of permanence"......Woody AllenSometimes traditional bad behavior does not change unless it has no choice. Like making it against the law. The only thing unlawful in the time this movie is set, is talking or writing about this bad behavior, that is not only legal but the respectful norm. Laws, by the way, written by people who engage and revel in it and have the audacity and the self righteousness to enforce it on others.Occasionally we need a movie or a book like this. Not to pass on guilt or to make money on emotional anguish, but just to remind us that we have evolved. We are reminded of a time when, we saw what could be called destructive traditional beliefs that were not right, or used to enrich those who perpetuated the paradigm for selfish and hateful reasons, evaporate and rise to a more healthful and heartfelt heaven.It reaffirms that reform can happen. That good can win out over evil. ("you are a Godless person Miss Hilly" the maid cries). All we have to do is want to be better and that means we can have a dream and make it come true.

reviews.review_title: Forgotten how good this movie is
reviews.content: It's 2020 and The Help is on tv. I hadn't seen it since it was in theatres. I had forgotten how great this movie is. The story is beautiful and told wonderfully by every actress on the screen- the heroes and the villains. This is how a woman ensemble movie is done.

Basically this is being a great movie for the approach that it's taking. It's being a drama, that however is being brought in a quite entertaining way. It doesn't make "The Help" the heaviest drama you will ever see, despite of its heavy and serious subject but that doesn't mean that it doesn't let its message come across as anything powerful or effective.Because the movie wasn't trying to be over-sentimental or heavy handed with its subject, it actually became a far more involving movie to watch. It was easy to care for most of the characters because they got portrayed as real humans, you could identify easily yourself with. It also really made the movie pleasant to follow and you won't even notice it's a 146 minutes long movie. It makes it a bit of a shame that the last 20 minutes of the movie felt the need to be still extremely sentimental and sappy. Really, I don't believe this was needed for this movie at all. In my opinion it felt too forced and was like a cheap way to let the audience leave the theaters crying. It's true that the movie due to its approach never goes all out and mostly plays things safe but I don't really hold that against this movie. It's simply a movie made for a broad audience, so it could get its story and message across to as many different people as possible.Actually it's a real accomplishment that the movie works out as well as it did. Because if you strip everything away from it, it's being just like an ordinary made for TV movie. Its story is very typical for that but yet the movie works out as something way more than that. It's really a well made and put together movie by director Tate Taylor, who really wasn't all that experienced yet when he did this movie.Of course things are also getting lift to greater heights by its fantastic cast. Really everyone seemed perfectly cast and gave away a great performance. Of course most of the talk is about Viola Davis and Octavia Spencer but next to Spencer, Bryce Dallas Howard really gave away the best performance in this movie, in my opinion. Sort of a shame she is getting overlooked for her role in this movie, while everyone around her is getting nominated for something, for their part in this movie, including for the big prizes.A great movie, about a not much talked about- but all important subject.8/10 http://bobafett1138.blogspot.com/

reviews.review_title: Far from Perfect But Carries a Welcome Message
reviews.content: "The Help" has so many positive things to say and is full of such good actors giving such good performances that it's pretty hard to outright dislike. It's one of those movies that seems really good while you're in the middle of watching it but begins to fall apart somewhat when you think back on it. I wonder how much different the viewing experience would be if you'd read the book on which it was based (I have not). As it is, there are many parts that feel like they're in the film because they're in the book but weren't as fully fleshed out in the movie as I imagine they were in the novel. An entire storyline involving Jessica Chastain as a helpless housewife who turns to her black maid to help her is welcome because it gives Chastain a chance to deliver a winning and immensely likable performance, but I'm not sure what it really had to do with the rest of the movie around it. The character played by Allison Janney doesn't make much sense at all. Representative of a certain kind of white person who's basically well meaning but allows peer pressure to turn her eyes away from the injustices of segregation, her character is first portrayed as a foolish and vain woman with whom we're supposed to be disgusted and then turns on a dime to become a champion for her daughter, played as appealingly as always by Emma Stone, when her daughter writes an expose of white oppression from the point of view of the black household staffs. And don't even get me started on the character played by Bryce Dallas Howard, an unlikable actress anyway who's given a gross caricature to play, so vile but ultimately so juvenile that she threatens to undermine the entire point of the movie -- if all racists were as silly and as easy to dismiss as her, all of our race problems would be solved.Viola Davis and Octavia Spencer, as the two black maids at the center of the story, deserve the accolades that have been directed their way. My only complaint, which is really a compliment, is that Davis had been given more screen time.Grade: B+

reviews.review_title: The Help: Everyone has a story
reviews.content: Skeeter Phelan (Emma Stone) wants to write about the African American maids and how they see the white families they work for, and the struggles of their job and life. With the help of Aibileen Clark (Viola Davis) and Minny Jackson (Octavia Spencer) this might be a fantastic success.I was scrolling through Netflix when I discover this movie. Clearly, I was excited to watch this movie because Viola Davis is in it. I love that women and this movie wasn't a disappointing. I wasn't expecting anything but something good and it was so much more.The story is remarkable, every leading character has their unique storyline and every single one is as good as the other. Viola Davis and Octavia Spencer are the highlights of the movie. Their acting is more than just great; they will make you feel what their character suffered.In the technical department everything is delightful. Good shots and very pleasant image. I think this movie is flawless. One of the best dramas I've seen so far.

In 1963, a young journalist and aspiring novelist returns to her hometown, Jackson, Mississippi, at a time when the civil rights movement is gaining momentum. Her job on the Jackson Journal – writing a column on house cleaning tips – leads her into contact with the experts: black women who are the nannies, cooks and housekeepers for rich white folk. Thus begins an unlikely alliance that exposes the indignities suffered by black maids at the hands of Southern belles who ironically spend their idle moments raising money for African charities. The ultimate revenge of the maids is both funny and gross. The movie evokes many emotions; laughter, tears, anger and perhaps even shame. There are wonderful performances by the maids, Octavia Spencer and Viola Davis, who surely must be in the running for Oscar nominations.The book on which the movie is based is pure fiction but the interspersing of historical facts – the murder of a civil rights campaigner and the assassination of President Kennedy – create the feel of a true story. The excesses of the era, from Ford Thunderbirds to the women's dresses and hairstyles, are authentically depicted. And there are real parallels between the fictional novelist (Skeeter Phelan – played by Emma Stone) and the book's author, Kathryn Stockett, who was born in Jackson, raised by a black nanny, and who struggled to get her first novel published. The movie can also be viewed as a social commentary on the times. As such, it has been criticized for its stereotypes, caricatures, hyperbole, even racism. Such a criticism would be valid for a documentary but not for a work of fiction. Perhaps the criticism is an indication that the topic can still hit a raw nerve.

reviews.review_title: The voice of black maids in the early 60s
reviews.content: That pretty much sums up 2011's heralded "The Help," which stars Emma Stone as an aspiring journalist who encourages black maids (Viola Davis & Octavia Spencer) to chronicle their experiences for an article as the Civil Rights Movement kicks into full gear in 1963 Jackson, Mississippi. Bryce Dallas Howard is on hand as the uppity biyatch and Jessica Chastain plays an amiable Marilyn Monroe-ish housewife.I like films that involve rural blacks, like "Mississippi Burning" (1988) and "Waterproof" (2000), and "The Help" falls into this category. The movie provides a window into early 60's Southern culture and the plight of black women. Despite being snooty, Bryce looks great and Jessica looks even better, nice and curvy (she reportedly gained 15 lbs. for the role, which I wish she'd keep). Emma is effective as the protagonist, but she's too good-looking to for the role since it calls for an early 20s woman who's never been asked out on a date. Why sure! Nevertheless, this is a solid period drama with authentic Mississippian locations.The movie runs 146 minutes and was shot in Clarksdale, Greenwood and Jackson, Mississippi.GRADE: B

While there have been many movies made detailing the Civil Rights movement of the 1960s, The Help's director and adapter of Kathryn Stockett's novel, Tate Taylor, manages to let the movie be something different than just a movie about the plights of African Americans in the 1960s. The Help is an ensemble story, following the multi-layered cast of some of the finer actresses currently working in the industry and their own brushes with the help of black housemaids in upper class Jackson, Mississippi. Where The Help distances itself away from the pack of similar tales, is that the movie isn't simply preaching a history lesson of tolerance, in fact it's left to our imaginations whether or not the white racist women in this movie will ever change, but the tale succeeds because it wears its heart on its sleeve and is not afraid to be both funny and oozing with sentimental emotion at each turn. The thing is, there is no moment where the white people's hearts are changed, as is seen in stuff like Remember the Titans, but rather The Help just lets the events unfold and speak for themselves. We watch these black housemaids struggle with their own emotions, caring for the white children they are nannies for, but detesting their mothers who talk down to them and wont let them use the indoor toilet on a rainy day. The Help just is, like an old fashioned Hollywood movie, there are not many frills or whistles in the direction, it is straight forward storytelling that does very little manipulation or fantasy creation to try and paint a more beautiful picture, but rather it is beautiful because of the chemistry between the flawless ensemble cast (with particular accolades to Jessica Chastain as Celia Foote). While the movie runs long, it will keep the viewer watching till the end to see where these characters will end up.I give The Help a 9 out of 10!

reviews.review_title: Give it a chance & make up your own mind
reviews.content: Has some of the best acting ever and can be appreciated for that fact alone. There's a lot of controversy over using black life in the Old South as a backdrop for a young white woman's self-awakening. It's certainly guilty as charged on that count, but it's so high-quality it can still be enjoyed as a movie and as entertainment. It's not posing as a documentary, it's a Hollywood tear-jerking, inspirational, feel-good film with some fantastic characters and performances all the way around.Yes, I'm aware the book never happened, and that there are some excellent reasons why not. A real-life Skeeter would've been quickly discovered and discouraged - to put it mildly. The police and the Klan (often the same men) would've also firebombed some of the maids' houses and probably the church, too, just for good measure. At least one of the maids would've suffered terribly before being murdered or framed and imprisoned. So it's also a Hollywood fantasy, albeit a terrifically realized one. But guess what? Name your favorite movies and see how well they live up to reality. How many mob bosses were anything like Don Vito or Michael Corleone? Could Mexican farmers round up seven great gunfighters to risk their lives for them for $20 apiece? Or make it seven samurai doing the same thing for a bowl of rice a day. How closely did the Malcolm X movie actually follow his autobiography? See what we're getting into here? Like my father once said: "You pay your money and sit down and then you decide for yourself how much of it you want to believe." The point here is to just relax and enjoy some epic acting - not hambone emoting, but truly nuanced portrayals and skillfully designed and actualized characterizations. Give "The Help" a chance and make up your own mind about whether you like it or not.

This world really needs a large number of brave and wise women who do not follow the rules. Otherwise it will never move forward. Personally, "The Help" is a movie full of light and hope. When I feel confused about the future and lose faith in the world, I would always think of it.

reviews.review_title: This is a fantastic American cinematic gem that is an absolute must see
reviews.content: The Help (2011) is a movie that I recently rewatched for the first time in a long time on HBOMAX. The storyline follows a young up and coming writer just out of college who returns home to Alabama looking for fresh content to make it big. When her longtime family maid is fired before she gets home she is inspired to hear more about what happened and why. Maids at that time are like family members who spend more time raising the kids than the parents. She decides that these maids, their lifestyle and the tasks they have to help with, or hide, would be the perfect content to write a book about....This movie is directed by Tate Taylor (Ma) and stars Viola Davis (Suicide Squad), Cicely Tyson (Fried Green Tomatoes), Octavia Spencer (Hidden Figures), Emma Stone (La La Land), Jessica Chastain (Zero Dark Thirty), Bryce Dallas Howard (Jurassic World: Dominion) and Sissy Spacek (Carrie).This movie is magnificent - the story, depiction of the historical elements, the characters and the circumstances are all fascinating, hilarious, sad and compelling. Viola Davis, Octavia Spencer and Jessica Chastain deliver tremendous performances and Cicely Tyson really brings the conclusion home. The pie scene in this will always be legendary but Spencer's mannerisms, body language and dialogue were remarkable and really takes this film over the top.Overall, this is a fantastic American cinematic gem that is an absolute must see. I would score this a 10/10 and strongly recommend it.

There are many many fine things to say about the film THE HELP, not the least of which is the cast of women gathered by screen writer/director Tate Taylor for this cinematic version of the book by Kathryn Stockett. The setting of the story in the 1960s is well recreated and it is truly tough to see how the folks in Jackson, Mississippi treated African Americans knowing that the group of bigoted WASPs were mirrored across the country. To be reminded of just how atrocious racial relations were in the time of JFK, Martin Luther King, JR et al makes of tough watching. This story, THE HELP, has be told and retold so many times that it lacks freshness and when the story is pulled like hot taffy for over 2 1/2 hours it wears thin.Viola Davis is magnificent as Mother Earth Aibileen but for this viewer her performance is almost matched by Octavia Spencer as her best friend Minny: both are excellent. And it takes a lot of chutzpah for the actresses playing the disgusting wives and members of the Junior League and Bridge Club who treat the help in such a demeaning way - so kudos to the 'worst' of them, Bryce Dallas Howard, Ahna O'Reilly, the smarmy Allison Janney, et al. There is a fine cameo for Cicely Tyson, and major star turn for Jessica Chastain as the only white woman (other than the author Skeeter as played by Emma Stone) for whom we care.It is a story about making a story (book) that changes the life of a small Southern town in the midst of Social Revolution. The acting has been cited and makes the film worth seeing, but as for whether or not it deserves to be considered for Best Picture....probably not. It is a VERY long song! Grady Harp

I loved, loved, loved Viola Davis as Aibileen. She overpowered the movie with the sense of her history and background through her sheer presence on the screen. She'd just be standing there framed in the shot and you knew what she'd gone through and how she carried the weight of her regrets and sadness on her back. I can't rave about this performance enough. She so embodied Aibileen, in a way even more than what I imagined. Her last moments were stunning, saying goodbye suddenly to Mae Mobley and the fear of leaving behind what you've always known and loved. This to follow a dream you might fail at, but either way your hope and faith says you must take the opportunity in the name of all you have lost. In her walk down the road to the bus you know without her saying that taking part in the writing of The Help she has done all in her power for Mae Mobley's future and because of that she has the opportunity to pursue her son's destiny to become a writer herself. Through love and letting go of the hate and disgust she's put herself on the road to a better future no matter what roadblocks she faces. Hehe, yeah I got a lot of unspoken messages out of Viola Davis' performance.Jessica Chastain rocked Celia Foote! Even though a lot of what I loved about the character was slimmed out of the movie I thought Chastain really took every moment to embody Celia. The screenwriter did a solid job keeping enough about the character that her arc didn't feel choppy or all over the place. This gave Chastain a good foundation for the character but I feel like the actress worked well not only as her character but in conjunction with Octavia Spencer as Minny and with the cast as a whole. Her role was a rather physical one in comparison to Viola Davis who had to stand around and emote. Chastain really excelled in this aspect. Balancing seems to be a skill she excels at. Watching the second time I found myself even more moved by her entire story as her relationship with Minny was a powerful as Aibileen's relationship with Mae Mobley.Sissy Spacek as Missus Walters rocked it! Wow! I could have watched an entire movie with her and Minny in some kind of Odd Couple or Grouchy Women knock off. She added such dimension I believe to both Minny and Hilly. In fact, I think she made the movie version of her character pop in ways the book version washed out. Cicely Tyson as Constantine Jefferson did the same thing for Skeeter except she only had one scene to do it. Talk about a master! From that one scene you got the movie version of Skeeter's motivation and the root of her ability to withstand her family and friends opinions and disapproval. The moving scene where she packs her belongings and touched Skeeter's height markingswow, nothing even need be said how much she loved Skeeter. I hate to write so little when the performances were so powerful but a lot of their accolades are directed to those they supported.Ahna O'Reilly as Elizabeth Leefolt and Allison Janney as Charlotte Phelan were fine in their respective roles. O'Reilly portrayed Elizabeth as what she was a follower. Janney very subtly worked her role as Skeeter's mother. There were a lot of changes to her story arc and so there were changes to the character. I didn't love these changes but I feel like they were no reflection on the actress.As for winning any of the Best Ensemble Awards I believe they are totally deserved, even with my criticism for some of the acting. This might seen hypocritical to some – I don't think so though. The acting was solid in the movie. There was a lot of different elements to the characters and the plot to balance and if the director seemed to drop the ball at times that wasn't really the actresses fault. I guess what I'm really saying is I think the missteps I perceived were in the acting upon my first viewing were not acting problems so much as direction problems. Perhaps he was too close to the material or the people involved. Perhaps balance is not his forte. As a story lover some of the characters didn't quite jive with their arc on a specific level, but for most I believe it works on the more general one.The movie was good. It didn't blow my mind like the book though. I would have loved to have seen a little more of the finer details transferred from the written medium to the visual. Still I think everyone ought to at least see the movie if you aren't one for reading. The cast is worth the effort.To read more about the adaption of the book to the movie: http://yaykisspurr.wordpress.com/2012/04/12/which-skeeter-is-better/

A realistic movie about racism. the story was perfect the play of Emma Stone, Viola Davis, Octavia Spencer & Jessica Chastain were great. I really enjoy Almost every second of the movie. this wasn't all about producing a movie but it is also about real terrible things that some white people did to the colored people back then and you can still find some racist people in all over the world who they do such terrible thing to the colored people. let us pray to Lord to free this world from racism.

This four Oscar-nominated film has finally set ashore here in the theater and is destined to be a gratifying crowd-pleaser. It is a resourceful reference to the color discrimination period almost 50 years ago in USA. The film is able to find its resonance elsewhere in the world painlessly, even for a Chinese like myself, discrimination is commonplace among human societies, and we can all empathize with the characters and enjoy the theatrical conflict with some well-infilled satisfaction after a lengthy 150 minutes. From director/writer Tate Taylor (who has a supporting role in another Oscar-favorite WINTER'S BONE 2010), THE HELP interweaves a lively portrait of the bitterness and felicity of the lives of black helps, through a young white girl's intervention to harness their stories as the source materials for her book. Maybe one can argue that all the twist-and-turn is too hoary for the audience in the 21st century, but propped by an all-out effort from a superb cast, the film miraculously enjoyable and the epiphany comes with a perfect tempo, arguably a supporting role, Viola Davis demos a tenacious mojo on screen and her emotional flare-up is wondrous to watch, Octavia, Bryce, Jessica are among the elites of the nearly all-female supporting groups (Viola and Octavia is my current win in the leading and supporting actress respectively), and old hands like Allison, Sissy, Cicely and Mary also showcase their meticulous scene-stealer dexterity. All these accompaniments has induced that Emma Stone's appearing leading role awkwardly being eclipsed by her co-stars and her performance is nevertheless a safely touching one with somewhat abating stringency. The film has a winning charm in its refined settings and costumes, it has everything we can expect from an orthodox Hollywood drama feature without any sumptuous bravura, it deserves the crown as the highest domestic grossing ($169,598,523) film among all 9 BEST PICTURE nominated films in 2011.
One of the most moving movies of my lifetime - every living person needs to see this movie to at least ground them and make them realise that the world we live in today is not one without struggle.

An adaptation of Kathryn Stockett's novel of the same name, 'The Help' is among the finest films of 2011. A film that engages & moves you. It's a film that goes beyond color!'The Help' Synopsis: An aspiring author during the civil rights movement of the 1960's decides to write a book detailing the African-American maid's point of view on the white families for which they work, and the hardships they go through on a daily basis.'The Help' is an engaging & moving cinematic experience. It's emotionally directed, wonderfully adapted & superbly acted. It works as a drama & as tale of struggle & faith. The characters are very well-penned, their interactions are accurate & the overall message of this story, is brilliant.Tate Taylor's Screenplay is wonderful, while his Direction is emotionally charged. He deserves immense praise for his great work in here. Cinematography, Editing & Art Design, are excellent. Performance-Wise: Jessica Chastain steals the show with an outstanding performance. Cast as a naive girl, Chastain rips it up completely in here. Viola Davis is ever-dependable. Emma Stone has done well. Octavia Spencer is superb all through. Bryce Dallas Howard is terrific as the racist. Sissy Spacek & Mary Steenburgen appear in small roles. Others are adequate. On the whole, 'The Help' is a winner all the way. Among 2011's finest films!

Based on a popular book, The Help are Black maids working for white women. It's a period piece that takes place in Mississippi in the early sixties.Excellent performances all around. Viola Davis and others will be remembered during award season.It's the kind of drama Douglas Sirk did so well in the fifties. Think "Imitation of Life"."The Help" suffers from the written and directed by syndrome. It's too long. Tate Taylor is not Douglas Sirk. Much of the exposition is through dialogue rather then shown. The maids stories are often told rather then shown. Late in the movie we're told, "We sent your brother to Chicago" and we didn't have a clue the character had a brother, but we needed the information the brother found.The flash backs were awkward and contrived. The character has to look at the bench or drive by the porch before we go back there. It seemed as though no one at the bridge parties knew how to play bridge.The film looks appropriate for the time period. There are plenty of classic cars. The use of period music was effective.It's a good movie that feels like it could have been better.

Always touching and thoughtful.Disagree that the director stirs up sympathetic feelings about injustice.Anyone who knows anything about American history knows that racial discrimination in the 1960s was very serious.The leading role is flawless and the character is well-rounded.

reviews.review_title: Good script for a Great story, Great acting for Good characters ...
reviews.content: A woman-centered film about the treatment of black maids in Jackson, Mississippi during the 60's the kind of pitches that instantly remind of "Mississippi Burning" and "The Color Purple", as if Tate Jackson's film, "The Help" was only begging for critical acclaim and Academy Awards. But if we were cynical enough to judge a movie only by its plot, we might also be able to judge people by the color of their skin, or their ethnic background... while there's so much more that justifies "The Help" success.Those who didn't have black maids as children, at least grew up with the immortal Pop-culture image of Hattie McDaniel in "Gone With the Wind" or the iconic Mammy-Two-Shoes in "Tom and Jerry" cartoons. I, myself, from a Moroccan background learned many stories about my Mom being raised in the 60's by a 'dada', which was the affectionate word used for black nannies, subtly masking the tragic reality of these women's historical backgrounds. My generation didn't have these 'dadas' but only maids from the country's poorer area, and the ways some were treated echo the film's saddest subplots. They were not all victims, as for my part, still have great memories about the maid who took care of me, whether it was cleaning me after 'I finished', or in the shower. My nanny stayed with us almost 20 years, and will forever be part of my greatest memories. Indeed, there are many maid stories and it's the combination of them that highlights the harsh reality of racism. The film is told from the perspective of Aibileen Clark, Viola Davis in one of this year's best performances as a veteran maid, interviewed by the heroine, Emma Stone as Skitter Phelan, an ambitious girl whose journalism rhymes (unfortunate cliché) with feminism. The film still doesn't fall in the convenient trap that would portray all the maids as victims but it features one of the most recently despicable villains: Blythe Dallas Howard as Hilly Holbrook, the authoritarian President of Jackson Junior League. Hilly embodies the ugliest part of racism, the one disguised with a condescending paternalism, mostly made from the sentiment of domination provided by wealth and education. Indeed, as much as many women were raised by black nannies in my country and in the film, most of them would never allow their daughter to marry an African man, except if he was rich and educated. The economical racism is still relevant today, especially if we dared to imagine, a rich black woman behaving like Hilly Holbrook with a Mexican maid. The treatment of racism in "The Help" is its greatest accomplishment, because we don't have burning crosses and Jackson is surprising Ku-Klux Klan-less ... although they felt necessary to include a scene of violence so random I wondered if it was really needed. I think the most thought-provoking aspect of the script was precisely in the way racism was depicted, something as banal as routine, and as natural as our most basic daily actions, which didn't make it less hateful. Toilets play a significant part in the film, sometimes much more than needed even for comedic purpose, but this perfectly shows that racism can be less about the glorification of a race than a constant reluctance toward one: refusing to touch someone or to sit on the same toilet... How many of us said that without being racist, were not attracted to a particular race, black, Chinese or even white? Some of us have precisely dealt with prejudice, and not necessarily as victims and the film mirrors if not our racism but our guiltiest thoughts and unconscious capability to sort-of understand racism, which turns us into accomplices. In "The Help", many white characters are not racist, but they participate to it because of their incapability to resist peer pressure and display tolerance in front of people, on the top of them, Skitter's mother Charlotte, Allison Phaney proving her immense talent to play motherly figures in Best Picture potentials and Ahna O'Reilly as Elizabeth Lefoit the mother of the adorable little girl, mother by title since Aibileen Clark, her nanny, is obviously the only real mother figure. Many scenes features this ambiguity of behavior, provoking in our open-minded consciences frustrated reactions. Needless to say that Skitter does resist to this pressure, since she's the one who made the book possible but strangely, I thought her character was too stereotypical while the film should have elevated itself above those clichés. Some scenes sounded probably great on the paper, but on-screen, embarrassed me a little, especially a romance that started from nowhere, and as I expected, went nowhere (like in many all-female cast, male characters were underdeveloped) and some maids, Eugenia's nanny to name one, were too 'noble' not to remind of the good old' wise black person cliché. It's one thing to avoid one-dimensional villains in a film, but it's even better when you don't make the opposite mistake and make some people unbelievably good when the hardship they endured would have made them tougher. This is why the most interesting performances came from Octavia Spencer as Minny Jackson and Jessica Chastain as Celia Foote. Both demonstrated, not without humor though, that the rejection endured by women in the 60's wasn't only based on racism, and some of the greatest scenes feature either Minny or Celia, or both, and I wouldn't be surprised if they received Oscar nominations, with a win for Spencer."The Help" will probably garner many awards in 2012, but I wonder if it does justice to the novel it's adapted from, because its main flaws come from a script whose parts could have been more equally developed, avoiding some subplots and enriching others. It's still one of the best films of 2011, but it really feels like it took its original story and inspiring message for granted.

reviews.review_title: Not the most entertaining movie of the year but a movie that is still worth seeing
reviews.content: I am going to be honest this isn't one of the most entertaining movies I seen this year but it's still a movie that is worth seeing. The story takes place in the 60's with the civil rights movement and has to do with the mistreatment of black housemaids during that era and what blacks went through. And revolves around a writer Eugenia "Skeeter" Phelan(Emma Stone) writing about what the black housemaids went through and tries to get it published. This movie takes place in a conservative era and portrays most of the whites as arrogant one dimensional superficial characters. I guess it's needed to show the cruelty the blacks faced during that era but sometimes it just seemed a bit forced at times. Maybe I had to have lived during that era to get a better understanding though. The movie is a bit dry though and it sort of reminded me of books I had to read in middle school although it's based on a novel. It was sad to see how the blacks were treated in a degrading and demeaning manner in that era. Nothing new to anyone that graduated from high school but still leaves a bit of an impact. If your looking for a fast paced movie with some shock factor in some genre like this you might be a bit disappointed. But this movie does a decent job of showing the feeling and emotions of blacks during that era. And their perspective of what is going on at that time. This is a good movie to show in school during class in order to educate the students but it's not a movie that I would watch again. But it makes you think when it's over, especially about how the blacks were forced sometimes no matter how hard they worked they didn't have enough to give their children a proper life. I am not going to lie and say it's one of the most exciting movie of the year it just lacked the focus but it's a film that is worth seeing and has good character development and that applies to the side characters as well.7.2/10

reviews.review_title: 'THE HELP' could have used some help in polishing out a good film.
reviews.content: 'THE HELP': Three and a Half Stars (Out of Five) Another 2011 Academy Award 'Best Picture' nominee, this one being financially the most successful of the bunch. It's an unbalanced film combining serious emotional drama dealing with real racial issues with exaggerated sentimentality and cheesy comic relief. It was written and directed by actor turned filmmaker Tate Taylor, which he adapted from a book (of the same name) by Kathryn Stockett. It's an ensemble piece in which three actresses were also nominated for Academy Awards (Viola Davis, Octavia Spencer and Jessica Chastain).Emma Stone stars as Skeeter Phelan, an author in 1960's Mississippi who recently graduated college and moved back home with her family. She discovers that the maid who raised her (Cicely Tyson) has quit but is suspicious about what really happened to her and can't get much information out of her parents (Allison Janney and Brian Kerwin). After witnessing more abuse of other maids she's come to know in the area she decides to write a book from the African American maids point of view about working for white families. At first many are afraid to help her, out of fear what could result from it, but she slowly earns the help of one bold maid name Aibillen Clark (Davis).The movie is hard hitting at times but other times the drama feels far too forced. Still it's much better than the likes of something like 'THE BLIND SIDE'. It's also filled with odd comedy including those involving fecal matter. None of that quite comes off right but when the film works it really works and is very memorable at times. Davis is outstanding in the lead and Chastain and Bryce Dallas Howard (the two would be sisters) are both exceptional in supporting roles as well. I found Spencer's character to be too much of an exaggerated stereotype forced to deliver the bulk of the bad comedy, which Spencer does a good job at but not an Oscar worthy performance (due to the directing and writing of her role). The movie as a whole is a mixed bag but definitely worth a look.Watch our review show 'MOVIE TALK' at: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Sd0S1srQ9T8
