reviews.review_title: Watch this movie, you will not regret it.
reviews.content: I can easily say that this movie was worth every minute of its 2 1/2 hour screen time. There are some cliches that it could have done without but overall this movie truly is excellent. The characters are well developed, the acting is absolutely perfect, and each plot is cared for throughout the entirety of the film.

reviews.review_title: 'The Help' Packs In Some Serious Girl Power And Is One Of The Best Films Of Its Year
reviews.content: Crafted with care, told with composure & powered by strong feminine energy, The Help is a wicked combination of comedy & drama that manages to touch on serious issues without ever discarding its funny side. Entertaining & enlightening in equal doses, this period drama is a roller-coaster ride of emotions that delivers a powerful jolt while also boasting moments of genuine laughter.Set during the 1960s, the story of The Help follows a young woman who aspires to be a successful writer and, after witnessing the poor treatment of African-American maids from their employers on a daily basis, decides to reveal their side of the story by writing a book detailing their experiences. Assisting to bring her noble work to life are two maids who work for her white socialite friends.Written & directed by Tate Taylor, the film packs a few dense moments in between but maintains a lighthearted tone for the majority of its runtime. Taylor could have gone for a serious, hard-hitting drama about the racial injustice & hardships these housemaids go through on a daily basis but the witty dimension gives this tale an accessible layer that gets the job done without trying too hard.Production design team does a fab job at recreating the required 1960s setting, Cinematography is expertly carried out, for the images brim with warm palette & bright lighting while fluid movements of the camera keep the drama sharp & resonant. Its 146 minutes runtime is never felt, thanks to its steady pacing & first-rate editing. And Thomas Newman's score is able to evoke the apt emotions with its serene tracks.Coming to the performances, The Help features a powerful ensemble in Emma Stone, Viola Davis, Octavia Spencer, Bryce Dallas Howard, Jessica Chastain, Allison Janney & Sissy Spacek, and all of them get their moment to shine. Davis delivers the most powerful performance of them all, and is closely followed by Spencer. Stone is absolutely adorable, Dallas Howard does well with what she is given, while Chastain pretty much steals the show & is my absolute favourite here.On an overall scale, The Help is a skilfully directed, deftly written, brightly photographed, smartly edited, calmly composed & ingeniously performed cinema that could've done a tad more with its provocative themes but in the end, it still succeeds as a rich example of its genre that's enjoyable, amusing & illuminating. Sophisticated in all filmmaking departments, strengthened by a casting powerhouse & keeping a firm grip on the viewers' senses, The Help is one of the best films of its year that's worth your time & money.

reviews.review_title: Not my movie of choice, but really good.
reviews.content: 'The Help' is not my kind of movie. Drama is not my genre of choice, let alone movies that deal with racial issues. Yet, I can't help but praise this movie.Set in 1964 when there was a great divide between black and white people - apartheid as they call it in South Africa - the film deals with issues that will offend some viewers, and bring others to tears. Being white myself, I fail to understand why white people treated black people they way they did back then, and why there had to be this big advantage gap in the first place. People are people, are they not? People should be judged by their actions, and not the colour of their skin, or their background.Our heroin is Skeeter (Emma Stone) who grows tired of the rich and pretentious community's attitude towards (black) maids. She then decides to write a book from a maid's point of view, and how they perceive the situation they find themselves in. We so naively believe maids are there simply to do our daily chores, but they have lives and emotions too.The first maid who agrees to be interviewed by Skeeter, is Aibileen (Viola Davis), followed by Minny (Octavia Spencer). Together, they form a bond, and the film becomes a heartfelt journey filled with emotion. The performances are fantastic. The script is really good, and I enjoyed the subtle score.I completely understand the relevance of the film, and the need for the story to be told. This is a good movie, with a positive, feel-good message, and a beautiful ending. Although not entirely my cup of tea, it was a movie well worth watching.

Greetings from Lithuania."The Help" (2011) is very well made, strongly acted motion picture about things, that we usually don't see on screen. I'm not saying that intolerance, racism is something rare in pictures, but it's a rare thing to see it shown from this angle. It's not entirely gruesome or villain actually, "The Help" is a good feel type of a picture, which shows the very gentle side of that part of history, the most gentle if you ask me. But it worked for me, i was involved in characters, i was moved couple of times and that makes this picture good.Overall, 8/10 for "The Help" as i has some stellar acting (including Oscar winning role), very good directing and i say not traditionally directing, and good script. This is definitely not a gruesome look at those hard topics of our society, and therefore some are going to like this movie even better. Solid picture, definitely of those must see movies not entirely for a groundbreaking movie-making, but for the importance of the subject.

reviews.review_title: who knew maids could be so entertaining
reviews.content: This is a really good movie. It has a funny, entertaining plot. Emma Stone, plays Skeeter, a privileged white girl that attends all the functions and is popular with all the other girls in town. She wants to be a writer and comes up with an idea to write a book with tales from the town's maids. The story takes place in Mississippi at a time when it was illegal to even think about civil rights. So, Skeeter meets the maids in secret.So, the book is about the stories and how Skeeter is ostracized for not being as racist as most people in town. It's just original.FINAL VERDICT: A must see

Tate Taylor's 'The Help' was one of my most awaited films of 2011 and I finally got to see this spellbinding film yesterday. I haven't read the novel on which it was based and yes the film does take place in 60's Southern America when racial tension was high. It also touches on class distinction as is shown in the conflict between Celia and Hilly. The film majorly has a female cast as Taylor looks into the lives of suburban housewives and their helps. But that's not to say it's only for women. After all a film about women doesn't necessarily mean it's audience should be limited to women.The 60's setting is impressive. It seems to have captured that period quite well thanks mainly to the art direction, costumes, score and performances. The editing is brilliant because even though 'The Help' is quite a long movie (longer than the average flick) it doesn't feel that way and I never looked at my watch while watching. The camera-work is good too especially how it brings about the feeling of space and follows the actors.Coming back to its themes, while it deals with various issues, Taylor never spoonfeeds the viewer. He has penned a solid screenplay. The dialogues are very cleverly written and the use of humour is brilliant. 'The Help' has a unique sense of humour. I doubt blackmail, or as Minnie says 'guarantee', has ever been funnier on film. The characters are also a delight to watch. There's the quiet and courageous Aibileen (Viola Davis), the feisty not-to-be messed with Minnie, the fiercely independent Skeeter, the vivacious Celia and so many more.Taylor has assembled some of the finest actresses of the current generation such as a bubbly Emma Stone, a lively Jessica Chastain, a hateful Bryce Dallas Howard and of course some of the best all time actresses that include the magnificent Viola Davis, the remarkable Octavia Spencer, the superb Allison Janney, the terrific Sissy Spacek and of course the wonderful Cicely Tyson (who delivers a powerful performance despite having short screen time).On the flipside, the male cast isn't that impressive. The actors don't get much scope. They are used as fillers.However, in the end, this is only a minor flaw and I could care less when taking the big picture into account. 'The Help' is easily one of the best films of the year and one of my favourites.

reviews.review_title: The movie is about the civil rights in the 1960's and about Skeeter a young, white Journalist who is writing about the life of the black nannies.
reviews.content: The movie is not bad at all, but its way too over-hyped. I guess its because of the theme. Films with the topic "civil rights" or "second world war" and others always get a bit better reviews. The film is touching, but it didn't get me so far, that i would say "wow, that makes me really cry" What really annoys me about the film is the Hollywood/American touch of the film. Sorry guys, i have nothing against America, but its a bit not authentic- and i didn't mean the not authentic behaviour of Jackson Ville, what the author/director intended. I mean especially skeeter, who is that innocent and such a perfect girl, without any appeal of racism or other bad characteristics. The whole impact she achieves with her book seems to me quite unauthentic. And for me the facts about the civil war are even a bit whitewashed or sugar coated. They could even draw more attention how bad the situation for the black people really was.What i did like was the combination of martin Luther Kings parts of his speeches and the impact on Jackson ville.In conclusion i liked the film, but if you want to see a more realistic and for me more touching film about civil rights, than i would rather watch "to kill a mockingbird" from 1962 http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0056592/?ref_=nv_sr_1

In order for a movie to be good, there has to be some good acting. I'm glad to say that this film, The Help has exceptional acting and that is why it's such a great movie. At first, I was skeptical of seeing this but after the great word-of-mouth this film has been spreading, I thought it was time for me to check it out. As a movie that deals with racism, it's dialed down a notch but it's still powerful nonetheless.This film is about a 23-year-old, white Mississippi girl who wanted to change the lives of black people for the better. She decides to interview some maids, Abileen and Minny so she can tell the world their lives from their points of view.The acting is just beyond belief. Viola Davis and Octavia Spencer led this movie with their powerful performances as the slaves. Jessica Chastain is certainly making a name for herself. I can say the same for Emma Stone as well. I also loved the evilness by Bryce Dallas Howard as Hilly because I just loathed the character in the movie.Overall, this is a great, powerful film that will have you cheering at some moments and in tears in other moments. I won't give anything away, but I loved that one scene that involved a funny confrontation between Hilly and Minny. I think that also made this movie great because of some unexpected humor. I rate this film 9/10.

"The Help" is the definition of a drama movie and it has to do with the human rights and it returns us back to time when white families had African-American people to work for them. This movie is based on the book which wrote by Kathryn Stockett and shows all of these and how difficult was for those people to just survive with these situations.I liked this movie very much because of the direction which made by Tate Taylor who I believe that he did a spectacular job. I also liked this movie because of the interpretations of Viola Davis who plays as Aibileen Clark and she was just outstanding, Octavia Spencer who plays as Minny Jackson and she also did a nice interpretation. Another good interpretations made by Emma Stone who plays as Skeeter Phelan and Bryce Dallas Howard who played as Hilly Holbrook.Finally I have to tell you that "The Help" is a movie that makes you feel all the feelings of those people and how difficult times were there. I believe that it's a must see movie and I definitely recommend it.

I love this movie for it's message. It's also a great way to remind people what America was like in that time period. I feel as if this movie extends further from segregation and more towards the fact that we are all created equally. The story is wonderful. The comedy was genius. I love everything about this movie. One person wanted to stick up for those that weren't being treated fairly and so she did. It was a brave thing to do. Especially when it turned her into an outcast. But did that bother her? Of course not. She set her own personal values aside in order to make a difference. This movie had me laughing. It had me crying. It had my heart breaking. Then it had me leaping for joy. I think everyone should at least give this movie a chance. It could change your entire perspective on life.You is Kind. You is Smart. You is Important.

reviews.review_title: A Powerful and Emotional film about Heart-Squeezing Revolution on Racism.
reviews.content: The Help (2011) :A Powerful and Emotional film about Heart-Squeezing Revolution on Racism. American cinema loves making films on thier own cultural disgusting facts from history and there is no shame if the message is right about Humanity. So many films have been made on Racism between White and Coloured people in Hollywood from which many films were Classics and socially important films but even after so many attempts and so many stories the subject doesn't lose its impact. The Help proves it again. The Help is about Racism held between White people and their Coloured Maids in the 60s. The film makes it emotionally accurate by showing how badly the maids were treated even after giving out thier everything for the house. The fact can never be denied that many Educated White people could understand everything in this world because they were taught well by those Coloured Maids. This is very emotional chapter if you really connect to the sentiments. For myself I would say, this was HEART-SQUEEZING. From the characterisation angle, The Help fails to set the white people characters but the other side is drafted powerfully. And that was the only thing i didn't like about the film because the film was about Maids, thier life and their perspective while enduring all the victimization then why hell writer tried to bring useless things like White people's personal issues such as friendship, love life, relationship and social appearances? Thankfully, the narrative is engaging having many funny moments and by the time it ends you have been through couple of tears-rolling-down experiences. Acting, cinematography, screenplay, dialogues everything is perfect and it is Tate Taylor's conviction which makes it a Classic Film. I wish American cinema keep making such eye opening films and the people will never repeat the same sins. Yes, Genuinely Recommended.RATING - 8/10*By - #samthebestest

"The Help" manages to not only tell a powerful story but it also has a lightness about the film. This is seen in the unlikely friendship between Skeeter, Aibileen and Minny. Emma Stone steps out of her comfort zone to play the cleanest character yet, she plays the role of Skeeter convincingly and is great to watch. All the cast were top notch and delivered great performances. At times it felt effortless, in the way the narrative played out, to the chemistry and the development of the characters, it all felt natural and enjoyable to watch. This is like the American version of "The King's Speech" (2011) in terms of how the Americans have taken to this film like the Brits did with the Colin Firth led drama. Yet, you don't feel alienated or isolated and instead you watch a tragic yet heart warming story. A watch for all to see.

This film tells Skeeter Phelan's efforts to write a book based on interviews and testimonies of black servants serving in the homes of wealthy white families of Mississippi. Directed by Tate Taylor (who is also responsible for screenplay, based on the Kathryn Stockett's novel), the film has the participation of Emma Stone (Skeeter), Viola Davis (the servant Aibileen), Octavia Spencer (the servant Minny) and a number of talented actresses.This film deals with interesting questions, starting with the race issue, which is still a ghost hovering over the US, and the issue of civil rights and the rights of employer over the employee. From there, the film gives us to know moments in the life of these servants and we see that, in spite of their humility, they're essential for those families, where women have the appearance of not even knowing fry an egg. The cast fulfills its mission very well but without surprise us with supreme interpretations. The only exception is Octavia Spencer, who touches us and moves us in the role of Minny, justly deserving the single Oscar that the film won: Best Supporting Actress.Our society often doesn't hear the voices of most humble. However, without them, society would fall like a house of cards. We all need each other. This film is about this: humble people in search of a voice, trying to tell their testimony, having right to speak, feel and live.

This film is an emotionally engaging tale about the experiences of black maids in the American Civil Rights era. While the story is fictional, the setting is based on real historical society though its accuracy and appropriateness have been criticised. There is fine acting by all involved and we get a window into the perspective of everyone in the town which really frames the entire situation. It is careful not to lapse into outright demonisation or glorification but there is definitely a feeling of triumph over the course of the film.

The help is a movie about a girl who wants to be a journalist and who writes a book based on the experiences of the black maids that work for her friends. The movie handles a difficult subject really well, bringing lightness to it, so that it won't get tiring for the audience, but, at the same time, it doesn't robes the subject off it's importance and seriousness. The story follows the lives of many characters, not only the main ones, but it doesn't gets confusing, as many movies with more than one stories to show gets, and, as I said previously, it doesn't gets tiring to watch. The performances were great and that helped a lot the film to be as good, but the set and the costumes contributed as well. There was only one thing I didn't like, and that was the ending, because it didn't keep up with the movie and got stuck into the corny happy triumph that many movies have as an ending. Other than that the Help is a great movie, so 8 out of 10.

reviews.review_title: If you loved the book, you'll love the movie.
reviews.content: Set in Jackson, Mississippi, in the early '60s, "Skeeter" (Emma Stone) is a recent college graduate aspiring to be a writer or novelist. Having been raised by a Negro nanny whom she adored, she decides to interview other local Negroes who serve as maids or nannies to white families in the area, and write a book about their experiences. The film shows some of the barriers between whites and blacks; Skeeter's efforts help begin to surmount some of those.I spent a year in Mississippi in the early '60s and, IMO, the film's vision of the (white) Junior League of that era is slightly a caricature--but fairly accurate in flavor. What is quite inaccurate is having a Jr. Leaguer in Skeeter's fact-finding role at that time, or having blacks daring to support Skeeter to the extent they're shown doing. It's equally inaccurate to portray racist whites as hateful; in that era, many white people with otherwise admirable qualities were racists.In a sense, the movie has a fairy tale quality with time traveling mixed in (i.e., as if today's sensibilities travel back to examine the '60s Mississippi scene, inhabit Skeeter and a few blacks, and then begin taking corrective action through them). It's an "ultra light civil rights" version of Mississippi (& similar parts of the South), one that ignores the overlapping memberships of community leaders in White Citizen Councils, police in the Ku Klux Klan, and all those, and many, many others, staunch members in many white churches.But the film's acting was great: Davis, Spencer, Howard, Chastain, & Stone make this fairy tale come alive. It's primarily about relationships between women (and women DO seem to enjoy the movie very much). IMDb's demographic ratings consistently reflect that females, whatever their ages, rate the film about 10% higher than males; it seems much more appealing to women--likewise, for my 2 female companions at the movie, it was a 10 of 10.It's fairly safe to say: if you loved the book, you'll love this movie.

The Help is an Oscar winning drama starring Emma Stone,Viola Davis,Octavia Spencer,Bryce Dallas Howard and Jessica Chastain.A young woman named Skeetch(Stone) wants to do a story of an African American woman(Davis) who is bullied by an uptight working mom (Howard). Will Skeetch put an end to the maid's hardship with the working mom?.Overall it starts off boring and then it picks up. Viola Davis was unrecognisable in this film with no makeup and you feel sorry for her charcther who was treated very badly by Bryce Dallas Howard's charcther.Good
C.

Upset upon discovering that her mother dismissed their longtime maid without even telling her, an aspiring journalist decides to write a book about the experiences of 'the help' in this surprisingly compelling drama, set in early 1960s Mississippi. The film is very message-heavy and sentimental to boot, and yet it makes for an engaging experience thanks to a slew of well developed characters brought to life by talented actresses. Octavia Spencer, Cicely Tyson and especially Viola Davis provide strong supporting turns as some of the poorly treated African American maids who in many cases care more about the kids whom they are helping to raise than the parents themselves. Emma Stone also delivers a fine turn as the protagonist who only gradually realises the seriousness of her endeavour, however, it is Jessica Chastain who steals the show as a ditzy young woman completely oblivious to how maids are usually treated and overly cordial when hiring one of her own. She has some strong dramatic moments late in the piece too. Sissy Spacek is also great as the mother of the vilest and most racist young woman in the film, but as the young lady herself, Bryce Dallas Howard is absolutely grating. She given no likable qualities at all and therefore makes for a rather flat antagonist, and many of the other young women in the film do not come across much better. The main characters of the film are relatable and down-to- earth though. This in turn renders their struggles in the face of inequality endlessly interesting - obvious and maudlin though the messages here may be.

reviews.review_title: An excellent film, but not a great one.
reviews.content: The Help (2011) was written and directed by Tate Taylor. It stars Emma Stone as "Skeeter" Phelan, a young, white college graduate, and Viola Davis as Aibileen Clark, a black maid in a white household in Jackson, Mississippi. The film is set in the deep south in 1963, when the civil rights movement in the U.S. was gathering momentum, but when the outcome of this struggle was far from certain.This movie touches on an important topic, and it is well-meaning and well-acted. It could have been another great film like Schindler's List. However, there are real flaws in the movie that kept me from enjoying and appreciating it as much as I would have liked.First of all, we have to suspend disbelief to accept the beautiful Emma Stone as someone who has been ignored by men because of her unattractive appearance. Then we have to assume that all the white people in Jackson--other than Skeeter--are clueless, brainless bigots. We also have to assume that none of them went to college. Surely some of Skeeter's friends went to the university as well. Ole' Miss was a bastion of white supremacy, but it was also a great university as well as a great place to find a spouse. Skeeter is treated almost as an outcast, because she's been away for four years.Skeeter's boy friend is a brute when the director needs a brute, a sensitive, caring man when that's what's needed, and then a brute when director Taylor again needs a brute. Mary Steenburgen is wasted as a sophisticated NYC publishing executive. The movie portrays her in such a stereotypical fashion that I wanted to cover my eyes every time she appeared on the screen.There are some truly moving parts in this film, such as the scene in which Aibileen Clark, one of "the help," tells Skeeter that she's never before had a white woman sit down in her house. You have to be moved by a film moment like that one. (I was in the "I have a dream" civil rights march, where people of all colors mingled freely. Later, I read a news report that quoted a black woman from the deep south saying that a white person had bumped into her, and said, "Excuse me." She said that no white person had ever apologized to her before.)In summary, "The Help" was a potentially great movie, that could have been one of the most memorable films of the decade. It never fulfilled that potential. However, the movie contains so many important truths that it cannot be ignored, and should be seen. We saw it in a theater. If you read this review when the film is no longer being shown, but is out on DVD, it should do very well on the small screen.

Set in Mississippi during the 1960s, Skeeter (Emma Stone) is a southern society girl who returns from college determined to become a writer, but turns her friends' lives and a Mississippi town turns upside down when she decides to interview the black women who have spent their lives taking care of prominent southern families and showcase their hardships to the world. Aibileen (Viola Davis), Skeeter's best friend's housekeeper, is the first to open up to the dismay of her friends in the tight-knit black community. Despite Skeeter's life-long friendships hanging in the balance, she and Aibileen continue their collaboration and soon more women come forward to tell their stories and as it turns out, they have a lot to say. Along the way, unlikely friendships are forged and a new sisterhood emerges, but not before everyone in town has a thing or two to say themselves when they become unwittingly and unwillingly caught up in the changing times.This is yet another Hollywood output where the story of the minorities is told through a morally righteous white person, but this time its done really well. Skeeter basically disappears after setting the movie up and only appears here and there when the story requires her and she leaves the floor for the others to shine. Institutional racism is fascinating and disturbing to watch, just like the sexism of the modern world which still exists in most countries. Hilly Holbrook (Bryce Dallas Howard), the antagonist in our tale, thinks of herself as a progressive thinker among her peers and yet her actions suggest otherwise. Her club's efforts to save the hungry children of Africa was ridiculously ironic and hilarious.The disparity, hardships and social status of the black people just because of the colour of their skin back then isn't exploited to the maximum. The critiques hurled at this movie for not showing it is simply laughable. This is just a story where none of the women shown on screen got raped or abused, though there are various viewpoints to the term, by their white masters and one should respect the story for it and not judge based on what didn't happen to these characters. At least, this is not a falsification of history like the supposed true story of Argo. Our critics and society are unfairly critical of female-oriented and minority based movies. Nothing is more telling than the hate bashing of the Twilight movies, a simple tale told through the eyes of a girl and her love for a supernatural being.I digress. The Help has a good story at its core, but its the strong performances by all the actors which is a sight to behold. Octavia Spencer won an Oscar for her efforts, though I do feel that her pie thing, though quite funny, was done in a slight distaste unbecoming of the movie, and Viola Davis was overlooked in my opinion. But it was Jessica Chastain, whom I liked in Lawless and Mama, who surprisingly impressed the hell out of me and was nominated for an Oscar for her role here. I was thinking that she'd just be another ditzy, suburban blonde, housewife/bombshell who I'd probably hate, but there was so much more to the woman and she made me empathize with her plight against all odds. She is definitely my new favourite actress. Emma Stone was infectious in her portrayal of Skeeter and the way her character's arc ended was realistic and sad. A charming, yet harrowing tale which doesn't overplay the aspect of racial discrimination to high levels.7.5/10

reviews.review_title: A realistic and often beautiful picture of the decaying South
reviews.content: Based on the 2009 novel by Kathryn Stockett, Tate Taylor's The Help depicts the patience, loyalty, and courage of black maids who cooked, cleaned, and raised the children of white women for many decades and who were often subject to abuse and humiliation by their employers because of their race. Emma Stone's performance as a young writer who records the stories of several maids in a book she is writing plays a prominent, if not decisive, role in the film, yet it is mostly carried by the brilliant work of Viola Davis and Octavia Spencer whose performances as Aibileen and Minny are at the core of The Help's ability to stir deep human emotion.Filmed in Greenwood, Mississippi but set in Jackson, Cinematographer Stephen Goldblatt, aided by Production Designer Mark Ricker, creates a realistic and often beautiful picture of the decaying South with its dirt roads and once stately mansions now falling into disrepair. As the film opens, Aibileen Clark (Viola Davis) tells us that she is a maid like her mother before her and has raised seventeen white children as their surrogate mother. The film is Aibileen's story as well as that of her friend Minny (Octavia Spencer) as told to young Skeeter Phelan (Emma Stone), a college graduate who comes back to Mississippi with the intention of becoming a writer and quickly realizes that she no longer fits in with her former friends, the perky bridge-club types whose racism lies just below the surface.Taking a job at the Jackson Journal as the writer of a cleaning-advice column, a subject she knows little about, Skeeter turns to Aibileen for help. When Skeeter discovers that her mother (Allison Janney) has fired Constantine (Cicely Tyson), the maid who played such a loving role in her life for 29 years, she decides to write a book consisting of interviews with the maids of Jackson, hoping that they will tell their story for the first time in public. Bravely facing the danger of being seen in close contact with a white woman, Aibileen agrees to talk to Skeeter, writing down what she wants to say rather than responding to questions.Although Skeeter's publisher wants more maids to contribute, the risk of putting their lives on the line is an obstacle the others are not yet ready to confront. Soon, however, after a falling out with her employer, Minny agrees to join the project followed later by other maids, fed up with the way they are being treated. The project becomes a cathartic experience for the women, able to say out loud what they have been suppressing for a long time. While the portrayal of some of the white women in the film borders on caricature, for example the villainous Hilly (Bryce Dallas Howard), some of the more interesting characters are fully developed human beings.Prominent among this group are Celia (Jessica Chastain), a rich ditzy Marilyn Monroe type who hires Minny and is taught how to cook and clean house, Skeeter's mother Charlotte (Allison Janney) who seems to be one of the few who are able to learn from their mistakes, and Hilly's mother Missus Walters (Sissy Spacek), who is able to enjoy a good laugh at her daughter's expense when Hilly becomes the recipient of an extremely gross incident which, though it has a point to make (unlike most Hollywood gross-out comedies), goes on much longer than necessary.While The Help is not a documentary and does not purport to present an all-inclusive picture of the racially-motivated beatings, lynching, and routine killings in Mississippi in the early 20th century and into the 50s and 60s, it still accomplishes what it sets out to do – to educate and entertain a generation largely unaware of the conditions of African-American women in the South before the movement for equality gained a foothold. While The Help may be sentimental (an unforgivable crime in some quarters these days), when Aibileen looks a little girl in the eyes and tells her: "You is kind. You is smart. You is important," every tear that may be shed has been dutifully earned. If that is called "pandering" to white folks, so be it.

The performances are brilliant. This is a great credit to the director, who let the actresses, work.So let's get this out of the way. Viola Davis should be given every award on the planet, and others should be invented and given to her. As true a performance as I have seen in a long, long time. Octavia Spencer. Same. Stellar performance. Hand these two ladies every possible award and recognition right now. They are that good. No, better than that good.Cicely Tyson. Transcendent. It is one of those moments where every second she is on screen, you cannot take your eyes off of her.The story. As well written as you are going to get. Ever.Emma Stone. She brought her A game. She had no choice... to keep up with the other ladies who delivered stellar performances. The physicality that Ms. Davis, Ms. Spencer and Ms. Tyson brought to their characters is masterful. Direction. It is excellent when we are able to experience this level of talent. Give the director whatever he wants. Top shelf.Overall, a superb film.

reviews.review_title: The Help gets the job done!
reviews.content: "The Help" needs no help in reaching for more success. It has captured the hearts of critics and moviegoers alike; it has been nominated for a few Academy Awards and was a surprise box-office hit. Writer-Director Tate Taylor's film about an aspiring Mississippi writer in the 60's who decides to write a book detailing the lives of African-American maids through their point of views did sure help uplift my spirits upon watching it. I thought it was a sensational, inspirational movie that was "maid to love". Taylor's tailor-made script and direction helped make it one of the best movies of the year, but the Academy sure needs some help because they snubbed Taylor for both director and screenplay Oscar nominations. Emma Stone stars as Skeeter Phelan, the go-getter young white Southern writer who gets a gig writing a laundry column in a Jackson, Mississippi newspaper; that was the gateway that brought her the idea on having African-American maids detail their challenging experiences as maids in Southern homes of wealthy, white families that even had segregated bathrooms built for the help. Viola Davis also stars as Aibileen Clark, an African-American melancholy maid who eventually decides to spill the maid beans to Skeeter. Octavia Spencer co-stars as Minny Jackson, the vociferous maid who is no Minnie Mouse when it comes to proving her points, whatever that means. All of these performances from the Big Acting Three of "The Help" (Stone, Davis, and Spencer) were remarkable and Oscar-worthy. Davis and Spencer both received Oscar nominations for their grand performances, but I think the Academy was stoned by snubbing Stone. With Spencer as the frontrunner for a Best Supporting Actress win, Octavia will soon be a "Spencer: For Hire" by being offered lucrative roles in major future productions. Other stellar supporting acting performances which helped "The Help" have one of the best acting ensembles of the year come from Allison Janney as Skeeter's sick mother who pressures Skeeter to get married, Bryce Dallas Howard as the racist villain Hilly Holbrook who is simply pure evil, and Jessica Chastain with her Oscar-nominated performance as the scene-stealing southern socialite Celia Foote. How could I have chastised Chastain by not including her in the aforementioned Big Acting Three of "The Help"! So, let's call it the Fab Acting Four of "The Help" with all apologies to Janney, Howard, and the rest of the solid cast of thespians in this movie. There are some touching scenes of "The Help" that will help for you to have your weepie-hankie handy when seeing those heart-tugging moments. So help me help you and let me recommend for you to seek "The Help". ***** Excellent

reviews.review_title: Disappointing after listening to the audio book
reviews.content: The audio book version of the novel "The Help" is award-winning, done by 4 (3 main) different actresses that really bring it to life.I wasn't quite ready to let go of the characters and watched this movie, hoping to prolong the experience. Unfortunately, it's a much over-simplified version of the story and the people involved. The adaptation to be a much shorter on-screen story is not bad - facts and events are shifted around to basically tell the same essential plot.Overall, I found it kind of cheesy, especially coming from the *excellent* read version, which goes much deeper.If you're coming to the film without reading/listening to the novel, it's probably more enjoyable.

reviews.content: Watch and learn. Brilliant actresses, characters well in keeping with that period (or today by many aspects) and awful yet accurate description of the american society.

¨If you can love your enemy, you already have victory.¨ The Help has received a lot of Oscar buzz and I wouldn't be surprised if it gets many nominations, but I was a little disappointed after watching the film since I had such high expectations for it. The Help is a good, solid movie, but it just didn't live up to all the hype for me. Racial and segregation films like this one have been made before with much greater effects. This film felt a bit light at times, and reminded me a lot of Fried Green Tomatoes. I can't help but think this film could've been much stronger considering the strong cast it had and the social issues it was pointing out. The film is based on Kathryn Stockett's novel of the same name, and it was adapted for the screenplay by director Tate Taylor himself. This is Taylor's second film, after having made a small film three years ago named Pretty Ugly People. Taylor, a relatively unknown has jumped to fame with his work in this movie, but considering the material I think a good director could've brought so much more to the story. In a way this seems to be a light drama which is touching a serious and dark period for many people. There are some funny moments, but the movie is really long and drags during some periods of time. I thought that the last half hour was probably the best part of the movie and you end up leaving the theater with a smile in your face. It's a good movie with some terrific performances, but I just was expecting so much more.The Help is a reference to the maids in Jackson, Mississippi during the 60's when racial discrimination and segregation was really strong. Civil rights movements had begun, but separation between whites and blacks was still very much an issue. The movie centers around several Southern society girls and the relationship they have with their maids. Skeeter (Emma Stone) returns home after college to take care of her sick mother (Allison Janney) and gets a job at a local newspaper writing housekeeping articles. Since she has no clue whatsoever about housekeeping she decides to interview the maids. Skeeter is sad to hear that the maid she grew up with and was like a mother to her has left to Chicago, but realizes there might be more to it than her mother is telling her. Skeeter is the only single girl since all her friends are already married and have children. Her best friend Hilly (Bryce Dallas Howard) is president of a local society and has come up with the idea that every family should have a special and separate bathroom for their maids. This of course, because of fear that they will transmit some sort of disease to their children. Hilly is very cruel towards her maid Minny (Octavia Spencer) and one day in a dispute fires her. Minny then finds a job working for a very nice lady named Celia Foote (Jessica Chastain) who's just arrived back in Jackson with her husband and live in a huge house. She is very disorganized, but Minny helps her get the house organized. Meanwhile, Skeeter realizes how terrible most maids are treated and decides she wants to write a book about the help, but written with the maids point of view. Skeeter begins interviewing her maid's best friend, Aibeleen (Viola Davis), who has had a lot of experience working with high society white families. Hesitant at first Aibeleen then begins opening up and convincing other maids to tell their stories to Skeeter and the result might shake things up for the residents in Jackson, Mississippi.The best thing about The Help without a doubt is the performance from the entire cast. Emma Stone does a great job as the lead character fighting for the rights of some of the maids which have been such a great help to her, but at the same time realizes that her friends will probably be upset with what she's doing. She still speaks what's on her mind and isn't afraid to point out the things that are wrong. She is very courageous. Viola Davis is just excellent and will probably receive an Oscar nomination. She also has a lead role in my opinion and she is just good in every movie she's in. She does a great job at repressing the anger she sometimes feels after suffering so much injustice. Her friend Minny, played by Octavia Spencer, doesn't do such a great job at repressing that anger and sometimes explodes. Spencer really surprised me in this film; she does a great job and absolutely nails her role. She will get a lot more job offers after this. It's hard to pick just one performance because everyone in this film does such an outstanding job. Jessica Chastain is excellent in this movie in her supporting role and perhaps gives the best performance of all. She is sweet and naive, but also feels broken due to her incapacity of bearing children. It's really sad considering she probably would be a lovable mother, unlike the rest of the society moms who can't even pick up their own kids and leave it all to the maids. I can't end this review without mentioning Bryce Dallas Howard who is just so good at being bad, mean, and cruel. She truly is scary in this movie and plays an excellent villain. The Help is a good movie, I just was expecting a little more from the story, but still go see it.http://estebueno10.blogspot.com/

reviews.review_title: An enjoyable ensemble cast of actresses
reviews.content: *Spoiler/Plot- The Help 2011, In early '60s Jackson Mississippi, the community is shown with it's segregated state. A young woman observes the inequities of the social strata and decided to become a writer to tell about the conditions there. She enlists, reluctantly a black housemaid to start her book to be sent to New York City to start her writing career. Later after being very careful because these actions are forbidden by law, the word gets out about the book and many more house maids decide to tell their story also.* Special Stars- Emma Stone, Viola Davis, Octavia Spencer, Jessica Chastian, Bryce Dallas Howard, Ahna O'Reily, *Theme- Caring people come in every culture, color and race.*Trivia/location/goofs-Oscar nominated film & cast and won for Best Supporting Actress- Octavia Spencer. Early film release of the Oscar Year. An interesting period film, but goofed with using the modular/plug phone handsets in dialog close-ups and use of liquid "White Out" (not in general use) in critical plot point scene.*Emotion- An enjoyable ensemble cast of actresses that did an excellent job in telling a story about the South in the early 60's. It conveys the segregation and balances that negative with the goodness of the White southern society of the time. The plot was very balanced with humor, pathos and good pacing with several unforeseen plot points through in for additional good measure. A good time at the movies.

This Movie is proof that Hollywood can still produce great films!! The Help is a picture that will have something for everybody. You will laugh, you will cry and ultimately come out of the theatre feeling changed from when you went in. It will be no shocker to see this film being recognized when Oscar season rolls around. Both Viola Davis and Emma Stone truly shine through this well acted and directed picture. I was extremely pleased to see Stone taking on a more serious role that allows the audience to finally discover just how talented she actually is. Overall The Help was a complete breath of fresh air on what has been a somewhat dismal year of film thus far. GO SEE IT!

reviews.review_title: Terrific performances, but the movie "wimped out."
reviews.content: Cautionary comment: My principal complaint is based on having read the book first, and I'm the first to admit that I hate it when people complain, "but in the book . . . ." HOWEVER, The screenwriters/producers/editors CONSISTENTLY took the edginess out of the book. They consistently deleted powerful scenes from the book that underscored the pervasiveness of the racism of the era. What they deleted illustrated so much more powerfully the quiet courage of the protagonists of this fabulous story. I won't go into detail about what they cut so I won't reveal the plot variations, but the consistency with which they sliced and diced shows a pre- determined decision to make the movie "sweeter" and more upbeat. But this decision made the choices of the characters seem "safer" and their decisions therefore less significant. It's too bad, because the film is beautifully acted and filmed.

I choose this movie to watch full knowing what the story is about. A good story. A worthwhile story. But i got bored very quickly by the way the movie just does not seem to pick up pace. I've seen movies on this subject before and, well, it's not my cup of tea really. I kept my mind open and was fully ready to see this movie. Based on the ratings, awards, it's got to be a good movie. Without doubt it's well played/acted, but, the story is where it goes sour in my opinion. What I said in the summary, yawn, it simply does not seem to pick up any pace. There seem to be a lot of flash backs or flash forwards, whatever way you look at it, but that does not add to the story at all, it actually makes it complicated, slowing down the actual story. They should have stuck to the theme and kept it chronological. I was so bored I actually stopped watching it, I never made it to the end, and I'll never will. If you really are in to the theme of the movie and you want to see the story and are not phased by possible boredom, go see it, it's well played. If it's not fully your cup of tea but you have an open mind, try it, make up your mind yourself. If you don't really like that type of stories andare not much for patience, don't bother, you won't finish it.

At the outset, I have to say that I have not read the novel by Kathyrn Stockett. Written for the screen and directed by her good friend Tate Taylor, The Help is one of the must see movies of the year.Strung together on a modest budget of 35 million, it has become one of the sleeper hits of the year with a domestic gross of over 160 million and still counting. Set in the background of 1960's civil rights struggle in America led by Martin Luther King, The Help focuses on the plight of African American housekeeper community and struggles against their racist white employers in suburban conservative Jackson,Mississippi. With an all star outstanding cast, it tells the story of a single independent white woman (Emma Stone) and her dogged pursuit to bring to light the plight of black cleaning maid community. When two of the help of the conservative households in Jackson come forward to tell their story, the struggles threads a thin line between fight for survival and a better future and fear of death from the dreaded and bigoted Ku Klux Klan. Portrayed brilliantly by Viola Davis and Octavia Spencer, the desperation and fear of the marginalised and oppressed Black community comes to fore with outstanding performances which is a sure bet for supporting actress nominations for both the actresses. The ensemble cast includes Bryce Dallas Howard, Jessica Chastain, Chris Lowell,Alison Janney and veteran actresses Sissy Spacek and Cicely Tyson .The performance of Cicely Tyson is one of the most the emotionally poignant scenes of the movie and though she has a screen time of just under two and half minutes, her performance is bound to make you reach for the tissues.The Help is a movie which will highlight how bad it was in the 1960's and how far we have come albeit with a long way to go to still achieve equality for all marginalised communities.The movie will make u get angry, frustrated, it will make u cry, and feel for the desperation of the maids and still manages to have its feel good moments.It is by far the best drama yet this year.

reviews.review_title: Watch it More for the Actresses, than the Storytelling
reviews.content: "The Help" is about black women being employed as maids and nannies in Jackson, Mississippi back in the racially-tense early 1960s. Skeeter Phelan (Emma Stone) is an independent tomboyish young lady who could not help but notice how badly her bridge buddies were treating their black maids. This terrible racist attitude was most exemplified by the pretty but contemptible Hilly Holbrook (Bryce Dallas Howard), who was not even shy about her nasty behavior. Skeeter then secretly interviews maids Aibilene Clark (a serious Viola Davis) and Minny Jackson (a sassy Octavia Spencer), who bravely tell Skeeter their stories of oppression in white homes. How will the town react when Skeeter's book finally gets published?The movie is another example of excellent ensemble acting. Viola Davis and Octavia Spencer have the showiest roles. Spencer, in particular, figures in the most memorable scene about how her Milly character gets back at Hilly using a pie. Emma Stone is also quite good as the modern thinking Skeeter. Jessica Chastain sparkles as Celia Foote, a naive housewife from the poor side of town who was ostracized by Hilly and her friends. The more minor characters of Sissy Spacek (as Hilly's mom) and Allison Janney (as Skeeter's mom) also make their mark despite their shorter screen time. Cicely Tyson has a memorable moment in her brief and silent screen appearance as Skeeter's nanny.The treatment of the serious story is light, with just the right amount of humor. It is a Disney production so we do not really expect this to be "Roots" or "A Color Purple." The subject matter in itself may not really appeal too much for all audiences especially in this part of the world, but the message of hope and redemption will make this movie universally meaningful.

Movies based on books seem to be one of the current popular trends for movies these days. This past Wednesday, The Help released in theaters and quickly has been making headlines left and right as one of the best movies of the summer. My movie posse and I just saw the movie last night and I'm here to give you some info about this good movie.For those who have not read the book or seen the trailer, The Help centers on the lives of black maids working for the elitist class in Jackson, Mississippi. One maid, Aibeleen (Viola Davis), tells her perspective of the life maids' live and their feelings on the jobs they do every day for their employers. However things soon begin to change when aspiring journalist Skeeter (Emma Stone) returns from college and decides to stir up a little trouble for her "friends" while attempting to stand up for the maids by creating a collection of stories from the servants. Once the book is suggested to Aibeleen, the movie portrays the development of the book and the lives and motivational forces that drive the others to participate in the project.So is this movie worth the hype that it has been receiving? In my opinion, yes I think it is worth the hype, but probably not worth a perfect score that some critics have been suggesting. To start off, this movie is an accurate portrayal of life in history that's not too overacted, or loaded with cheesy dialog. Instead the story is brought to life by a great cast of actresses whose characters add their own flavor to the plot of this movie. Emma Stone surprised me with the role she played in this movie, playing the serious, dedicated, and loyal writer instead of some wacky, one liner spewing, teenage airhead role she is famous for. Viola Davis seems a natural as Aibeleen, delivering her dialog with emotional drive without crossing the overacting line too often. Octavia Spencer, who plays Minny, helps bring some sassy, take no crap, humor that had most of the audience, including me, cracking up. Bryce Howard, no longer playing Victoria, plays an evil, arrogant southern witch, who had me seething during the movie as she drove the plot of the movie. Jessica Chastain however, was the southern belle on the opposite spectrum, who was kind and genuinely good as she attempted to do things for herself and those that she loved. The rest of the cast was great as well, but these five really made the movie come to life for me and kept me in to the movie.The acting was not the only thing that kept my interest in this movie though. For one thing the director of this movie found a way to take multiple stories and intertwine them with the main story to provide multiple tales to follow. Throughout these stories the dialog was fantastically written to fit with the scene, often injected with some humor to break the emotional tension building up. Minny's participation in the various tales probably entertained me the most as one instant she was the wisecracking maid and the next at mercy of some other character, a good representation of the two sides to the maid back then. Also laced throughout the movie is background on the main characters, which is slowly revealed over the course of the film instead of all at once. The gradual revelation baits one's attention and keeps you roped into the movie to find out more.Perhaps the biggest strength of this movie though is how everything flows together to capture and bring the emotions of the characters to life. The camera work is beautifully shot from a variety of angles that best capture actions and expressions of the characters. The soundtrack as well was properly selected in this movie, each score/track helping bring the audience into the mood of the scene. Both of these factors, combined with the brilliant acting mentioned early, sends one on an emotional roller coaster ride that may cause one to tear up, as it did to three of my friends. And although I didn't tear up, Taylor and his team managed to really drive the morals and lessons of this story right in my heart, which made me feel good by the end of the tale.There are also some bad aspects to the movie, the biggest for me being the a few dragging parts throughout the movie. Another aspect that is hard for me to enjoy is some of the cruel things that one sees in the film. Yes, I know these scenes are supposed to make you hate, or pity the characters, but too many of these scenes gets me hot under the collar and makes me enjoy the movie less. The ending as well may have been a little bland for me as well and kind of left me hanging and wanting more of a conclusion, despite the strongly delivered monologue.If you get one thing from this review tonight it should be that The Help is one of those movies worth seeing in the movies, particularly with a group. Those looking for great acting will be pleased with the cast and characters of the film. Fans looking for an emotional story and rich character development are also in for a treat with this film. After analyzing the strengths and weaknesses of the film, I give this movie a 9.0. However as a final warning, people who tend to cry should bring a box of tissues. Until next time folks!

reviews.review_title: Most significant film of the year
reviews.content: I didn't read the book prior to seeing this movie and I had no real expectations of what it was about but had heard this movie was worth seeing so we went. The story line was gripping from the first scene and kept my interest throughout. The friendships and relationships that were portrayed were insightful and captivating. I will say this movie will probably garner several academy award nominations. My only fear is that some of the actresses in this film will be nominated against each other. My picks are Octavia Spence for best supporting actress, Emma Stone for best actress and Mary J. Blige for best song. I can also see Alison Janney and Viola Davis receiving similar nominations.I was so overwhelmed with thought and emotion at the end of the movie that I sat there contemplating what I had just seen. Added to this was the song "The Living Proof" that was written and performed by Mary J. Blige that plays during the first part of the credits. MJB perfectly captured the emotion of the movie when she wrote this piece and she sings it from her soul. Check it out on YouTube.I am going back to the theater to see this film again and it will become part of my DVD collection as well. Do yourself a favor and go see this movie. It will change your life for the better.

reviews.review_title: The Help-I Smell Oscar! Best Film You Should See!
reviews.content: You all need to see the Help. It will be up there in the Oscar Race of 2012. As the whole entire cast needs to be nominated. Great ensemble and a great story. You don't get films like this in Hollywood. Great casting, great story.Viola Davis who plays one of the two protagonists, maid Abileen shows she can also carry a film. Long a supporting player, she moves to the front. As she helps out recent college grade Skeeter(played by up and coming Emma Sonte of "Easy A"), and the second protagonist. Skeeter treats her like family. Unlike her family does.Abileen is the first person to speak out about the treatment she and the maids get. By not being treated as humans. Due to this and other obstacles in the South, other African-American women come forward in her predicament.Not surprisingly, not a lot of people are happy about this. As skeletons from the closet come out. Despite the book coming out with an anonymous author.But Skeeter sees Abileen and the people in the African-American community as family and as equals. It just takes sitting down to and listening to people. Not a lot of people take the time to do that. But Skeeter did and does that.Bryce Dallas Howard isn't just Ron Howard's child, but she is now a full-fledged actress as someone has said on this board. And that expect great things for her to come in the future. As the main antagonist, snooty and prejudice Hilly.Octavia Spencer is the one that stills the show. As the outspoken friend of Abileen. Who has been fired nearly twenty times. Despite making the best pies of the South. I expect her to get nominated as well as more future roles to come.Jessica Chastin as a hoot also as the one that is left out of the "girls club" due to being different and naive. But really she also is a good person at heart. Once you get to know her. And her tragedy.Sadly but truthfully these things did happen. And that though nobody can erase what happened in the South in those days. Which wished that we could. Still, how these women have come a long way. And how that we have come a long way, but have a long way to go in race relations.Hopefully you all will see the Help. As these things DID happen. My parents grew up in those times as well. Because the Help will make you see how race relations have come a long way since then. And how you need to remember the only race that counts...IS THE HUMAN RACE!

Kathryn Stockett's book on which this film is based (originally turned down by 60 publishers) and co-writer and director Tate Taylor's movie itself have both been outstanding successes in the United States where this tale of prejudice and racism towards house maids in 1960s Mississippi has clearly resonated in a country which has moved on sufficiently to elect a black president but still exhibits discrimination against African-Americans in so many aspects of its society. It is unquestionably a worthy work, championing an underprivileged ethnicity, class and gender and providing a slew of challenging roles for female actors, both black (Viola Davis and Octavia Spencer) and white (Emma Stone, Allison Janney, Bryce Dallas Howard and Jessica Chastain).But as a film it lacks a strong narrative drive and pacing, while the characterisations are one-dimensional with only Janney's character having any real nuance or complexity. And the book and film have been criticised for representing a white heroine as liberator of the black helps instead of suggesting that they were capable of self-empowerment. In spite of these weaknesses, this is a distinctive and well-made movie that has something to say and should be seen and taken to heart.
The Help is long, and predictable, and kind of safe. With that being said, it's certainly not bad and it has some truly great performances. I would recommend.

I went with my Mother who hasn't read the book, and she thought it was great. I thought it was great as far as casting and acting. Love those women, can't go wrong with any of them, and they nailed it as far as portraying women from the South. Some of the characters hit a little too close to home, having grown up there.Unfortunately for me, and always the case, the book for me is infinitely better. I found myself crying and laughing so much more when reading. I just felt the film didn't build the characters as well, and the few changes made for the film, I didn't understand the purpose.So anyone who has read the book, may be a little let down, but over all pleased, however if you haven't read, I'm sure you'll enjoy immensely, thank goodness a film that isn't another remake!

reviews.review_title: Having read the book, this film was disappointing
reviews.content: I was disappointed when I watched this film. I had just finished the book, which, to me, is an incredibly enjoyable read, and the same day watched the DVD - a big mistake. I don't think a movie can ever have the richness and emotional complexity as the book it came from because readers create an image in their minds about the characters and setting that are seldom realized in the movie version. The Help was no exception for me. Just a few of the disappointments: The Hilly character in the book was an over-weight, scheming, and domineering woman. The film actress was much too pretty and perfect and was not at all convincing to me. The other actors in the film were likewise one-dimensional and not at all real. Whatever happened to real southern accents? I seldom could get to the point where I did not think they were acting. The Skeeter character was not developed well and much was left out of the film about the effect her actions had on her life. And the most puzzling thing for me at the ending was the scene where Constantine's daughter appears at Skeeter's home. The real impact of this in the book was that the daughter's skin color was that of a white person, and that was considered by some at the time to be quite shameful and embarrassing and reason enough to fire Constantine. I wonder how anyone watching the film could be able to get that impression.I realize that film and literature are different and I'm glad that most viewers enjoyed the film for what it was, but I still was disappointed that the film did not have the richness and drama of the the book. I wonder what a really talented director could have done with the story. Part of the problem for me, I suppose, was in seeing the movie too soon after reading the book. I won't do that again.

"A man does what he must - in spite of personal consequences, in spite of obstacles and dangers and pressures - and that is the basis of all morality." - - John F. Kennedy Kennedy, of course, was correct. In this film we get to see a rare presentation, full to the brim with women with more than enough courage to impress even President Kennedy. Of course, that is the immediate thing in the back of everyone's mind who watches this film. In fact, there is so much courage to go around it's hard to decide just who is the most important character in the film. I finally had to decide it's a team of courageous women focused on truth and perhaps, ultimately, change.This story is primarily set in the early 1960's in the town of Jackson, Mississippi. It deals with the subject of the truly bad treatment that black servants received from their white employers and is lightly framed by the growing civil rights movement.The two most prominent characters - protagonists - as we near the end of the film have been Emma Stone as Eugenia 'Skeeter' Phelan and Viola Davis as Aibileen Clark. It's those two characters who are the genesis of everything that happens here. The journey they embark on together, from the staid, old fashioned society they came up in toward a brighter future is the stuff of greatness. Their experiences and the resultant emotions carry us easily along through their trials and tribulations as they work through the story.The greatest thing about the film is watching these two women do what they do best: act. Both Davis and Stone are exceptional actresses and have plenty of room here to exercise their craft. There is not a false note from them in the entire film. Davis, who has already garnered a lot of notice from her previous films, is in perfect form as the overworked and much under-appreciated maid. Stone, who has shown great promise as an actress in lighter roles, certainly makes a terrific showing as a great dramatic actress. Both of these women are fascinating to watch; their styles and presentations so different yet so unfailingly on target. The film is more than worth watching for them alone, but we have many more fine performances here.The primary antagonist is wonderfully portrayed by Bryce Dallas Howard as Hilly Holbrook. Howard is perfect in this difficult role of the saccharine, insincere, self-important, lying troublemaker who serves as a focal representation of all that was bad in their society. She is just as wonderful to watch work as the others and gives a comic edge to a performance that could have gone over the edge into ridiculousness had it not been handled as well.There is also a wonderful performance from Octavia Spencer as Howard's maid Minny Jackson. Her performance shows surprising depth and is worthy of all the praise that could be heaped upon her.It's hard to give appropriate thanks to all of those in the film that gave so much of themselves to make this film as great as it is. There is Allison Janney as Charlotte Phelan, Stone's mother. She is great in showing a transformation in a character. Then there was a small role played by the great Cicely Tyson as Constantine Jefferson, the maid that raised Stone's character and served as her character's moral compass. Her performance is understated and quite touching. Another small but excellent portrayal was from Sissy Spacek as Missus Walters, who is Howard's mother. All of these actresses ad flesh to the film in wonderfully realistic ways.But perhaps the most unusual and very entertaining part was played by Jessica Chastain as Celia Foote, a very ditzy, white trash blond who marries up and is trying to make inroads into the tight social circles of the city. But her portrayal is also infused with warmth and genuine charm, lightening the story and providing an excellent counterpoint to Howard's character. Her performance, although quite different from the other performers, is every bit as good and you can't help but love her by the end of the film.Considering how entertaining the film was, one must certainly praise those who sculpted this fine film. The director, Tate Taylor, who also scripted from Kathryn Stockett's novel, created some excellent material here and is just as deserving of praise as the actors/actresses. The portrayal of the intricacies and hypocrisy in the world around Stockett is brought to the screen with intelligence and compassion.Underscoring the great performances are the technical aspects of the film; cinematography, score, editing, sets, costuming, lighting, makeup, everything, is wonderfully done and presents an overall visual and aural portrait of the mid-twentieth century south.This is definitely a film worth seeing, and although there are a few light moments, it's just as adamantly a drama. It should not be overlooked at Oscar time. Thank you everyone for giving me a great end to a wearisome week.By Bruce L. Jones http://webpages.charter.net/bruce.jones1/

Reminiscent of "Fried Green Tomatoes" in the way it feels, "The Help", directed by Tate Taylor is a strong drama that "tugs at your heart- strings" effectively. Although fiction, it succeeds in being luminescent about past times of segregation and racism in the South. Viola Davis gives an Oscar-Worthy performance and leads a veteran cast of actresses. The developing story keeps your interest piqued for the majority of a hefty runtime (137 min) which is testament to the sharpness of the script and the quality of acting. Indeed, Taylor puts together one of the best movies of 2011 filled with the right touches of humor. See it for the acting, story, and drama. Strongly recommended

reviews.review_title: ....it is good to say something.. and as well to make lots doing so
reviews.content: Lucky #13 for 2011 !! This little film came in right after a dozen blockbuster movies for year's best grossing films. Any guesses as to why.. every talent and casting agent will readily tell you. Great watch, probably won't watch again, and can recommend.To be fair, you should watch this prepared for what it is:
a racial suffrage movie.That means that it is filled with racism and unfair strife, and stupid jerks of the elite class that are under the impression that they can still buy and sell people because they do.This is a fantastic movie, but it is a heavy, serious story, and the humor in it barely makes it more palatable in that regard.The cast is filled with great actresses who give excellent performances, the script is well written, and the production value is great.It isn't going to provide a level of escapism from worldly problems, but I don't have to like a movie to recognize its greatness.
Lived this movie and all it covers. In this day and age we need to remember where we were and surge forward!

Skeeter (Emma Stone) decides to write a book about the life of maids in the old south in Mississippi in the late 1950s. She knows what she is doing is against the law and has a hard time getting cooperation from the maids, but she does get it. This was just before the Civil Rights Movement. I didn't want to take this movie out because I knew what I would see and hear within. I was not wrong, and I am sure that things were much worse than I imagined and much worse than what is depicted in here. So keep that in mind. This was a very hard time for black maids serving white families especially caring for their daughter babies, who grew up to be like their mothers who instilled prejudice and southern ways in their children. Of course, not all white families treated their maids badly,but this story is not about them. Don't let anyone tell you that this was not a true story. It is that and more. It is inspired by true events and handed-down stories by these maids and what is seen is only a small tip of a large iceberg. You come away with the question: how can people treat people like this? But, this is part of our history such as it was. The acting performances by all the cast deserve Oscars. The way this was directed and performed was like we were eavesdropping into the lives of these maids. Nothing was overdone. Well, the pie incident was and I was shocked that it was included in here. Not good. That was an attempt for cheap laughs in a story that didn't see much humor. The standouts were Minny (Octavia Spencer) and Abileen (Viola Davis) and this was basically their story. You liked them and hoped the best for them especially when things didn't go good and you found yourself reaching for that Kleenex box time and time again. When you looked into their eyes you saw, without question, a sense of hopelessness within their lives. Minny says "we are living in hell, our children too. Trapped." You might need two boxes of Kleenex tissues. This is a powerful story and will, perhaps, turn out to become a classic and as such, it should be required viewing in all high schools throughout the land as most children now have no clue to this part of our history. The story aside, I was impressed with the vivid photography throughout, the colors of the maids' uniforms, numerous 1950s cars, and a lack of hard language usually found in today's movies. (10/10)Violence: You see the results of some violence, not the act of. Sex: No. Nudity: No. Language: No F-bombs, only soft stuff and not much of that.
I loved this film. I loved the women in it. The script was wonderful and the casting was perfect. I highly recommend you watch it.

reviews.review_title: 501st Review: Good film about injustice and hope
reviews.content: The Help is more than just the civil rights struggle in the early 1960s. By focusing on a small community but giving us both breadth and depth it covers a lot of territory. We get to see how it is possible for one human to believe it's OK to treat another just because they can, or worse, believe they should.This is a strong well-made ensemble film, particularly notable for strong, well drawn female characterizations - if fact there are almost no male roles here to speak of, but it resolutely not a "chick flick" - this is a good drama with purpose, insight, humor, and shock.All in all this is one of the more rounded dramas of the year and is definitely worth your time - the acting is superb from all involved and make it a rewarding watch.

I liked the book. I thought it was a bit fluffy, but it didn't quite cross the line into schlock. The movie, however, had too many melodramatic moments, especially toward the end. I'd have to read the book again, but I don't remember the scene where Abilene's church has a celebration for her, or where Abilene and Minnie tell Skeeter to not worry about them, that her success in New York will make what they did worth it. I could be wrong. Maybe it just didn't seem as sappy in the book.I also thought the movie actually minimized the attitude that whites had toward blacks by making it seem like the racism in Jackson came from mean-spirited people like Hilly, as if it wasn't rampant among everyone.The whole pie-eating thing trivialized what the maids went through and how they must have retaliated at times. It was too over-the-top in the movie and too much emphasis was put on it to the detriment of other parts of the story that would have rounded it out better.If you're on the fence on whether or not to see the movie, do yourself a favor and read the book. It might take a little longer, but it will be a more satisfying experience.

The Help is one of the best movies I've seen. I am left stunned after watching it.Every single performance in the film was impeccable. Absolutely flawless. Octavia Spencer was phenomenal, her facial expressions are just something else and brought so much humour and characterisation to the film. Viola Davis brought so much life, vibrancy, emotion and poignancy to her performance. Bryce Dallas Howard was on fire in this role, a career high for her. Jessica Chastain was equally excellent, giving such a memorable performance. Then there's Emma stone who brought life to such a fantastic character. I wish every single one of them could have walked away with an Oscar for their stunning work.The story is so gripping. It has so much to offer, from gut wrenching and devastating blows, to heart warming uplifting moments, through to laugh out loud comedy. Finding this balance can't have been easy, as The Help unflinchingly deals with the disgusting and vile racism of the segregated south. Despite this what The Help does so well is to find the heart, hope, and humanity in the situation. The effect is one hell of a ride.The Help also boasts such a great collection of characters, all with something different to offer. They all felt so real and authentic, and this made the film something really special.This is the definition of a must see film. Phenomenal!

reviews.review_title: Amazing .Fantabulous. Very entertaining. You may definitely want to catch it for eve flick !!!
reviews.content: The HelpThe Opening :- The help, based on a novel of same name, was a very nice entertainment which will keep you engrossed throughout the movie and at the same time will make you sympathize for the African maids who went through the trauma of racism in America during 1950'sThe Story :- The help tells the story of African maids working for whites in the early 1950. The story revolves around 3 people . Aebileen is one of them working as a house maid for white. She takes care of the baby girl more than her own mother as Aebileen has lost her own son in a tragic accident. Minny , another African maid , is working for one white household but she makes one mistake by using their bathroom and soon is fired for un equality. Skeeter is a young white journalist who gets the opportunity to write a column for the local newspaper. She gets the idea of putting down the struggle and pain of African maids in her story and turns it into a book. She seeks help from Aebileen and soon discovers that there are other maids as well who goes through the same pain and suffering everyday of mistreatment and racism by high class white. She starts writing different stories about racism including hers as she was also raised by a black maid. The review So , overall , I loved the film. It was a women – oriented flick but I found it to be very interesting. The direction was superb and so were the performances by the star cast. The cinematography was breath taking transforming you into the era of 19th century. The background score was nice. The film could have been trimmed by few minutes. But, the direction and performances compensates for that. The bottom line Amazing .Fantabulous. Very entertaining. You may definitely want to catch it for eve flick. Excellent – 4 / 5

I really wanted to love the movie as much as I loved the book. Unfortunately, the movie fell short of the book by quite a bit.
