While I did enjoy watching it, I found that some of the story lines as well as the depth of some of the characters, especially Elizabeth Lefolt, suffered from the necessity of shortening the story to fit it into a 2 hour and 17 minutes movie. The acting of all main characters was solid, with my favorites being Minnie Aibeleen and Mrs. Walters. It is an entertaining movie to watch, but it does not measure up to the book. What made the movie fun to watch that one cannot experience reading the book was the soundtrack and the gorgeous cars.

reviews.review_title: I Thought the Movie was Way Overacted!
reviews.content: This movie felt so contrived. Emma Stone was okay, but I thought Allison Janney, whom I usually love, overacted. Bryce Howard was awful.Talk about bad overacting! Her character was a cliché joke and of course was the total Southern Jerk so everyone could have someone to really hate! Sissy Spacek was good. I thought it was gross and despicable what the maid did to the pie. So, everyone who has been mistreated should feel entitled do something like that?! Most everyone had horrible, fake Southern accents. I thought Cicley Tyson was her usual terrible actress. I think the whole book and movie are way overrated and Hollywood will likely give it the Oscar because it's right down their alley.

All conquerors make the mistake of leaving the children with "the help". After Strongbow and the Norman-French out of Wales overran Ireland in 1176, the Gaelic-speaking girls raised the children. These children in one generation spoke Gaelic, wore Irish clothing and had Irish attitudes. They became Gaelic lords. The Fitzgeralds of Kerry were an example. "Skeeter" was a result of such upbringing and did not become as obnoxious as her parents and their friends. The little girl featured with Viola Davis's character called her her real mother. At Monticello, a docent spoke with what I can only describe as a Black dialect. Because Blacks were kept away from education, the dialect was almost incomprehensible. My friend from West Virginia said, "It's because they had Black nannies." So I found that part of "The Help" totally believable. It's a novel but novels often reveal the real feel of a situation. Perhaps it was superficial, broad, not intense like Shamaylian or Hitchcock. But Hilly scared the hell out of me. Even in Queens County New York, teenage counsellors at a day camp could urge the Black kids to leave the bus in the afternoon by saying, "Bongo Muchacha, Water Boy Number One, Booga Booga," or the like. In the late 1950's. Maybe that is why so many baby boomers were at this movie. We all experienced the blindness. And the respect for certain loudmouths who could intimidate a kid into silence.

reviews.review_title: Compelling story about racial prejudices. It avoids sentimentality, and keeps our attention throughout the full 146 minutes
reviews.content: I was a bit reluctant to book tickets for this movie, as I assumed a bittersweet story. And that it was screened in one of those multiplex, popcorn riddled theaters did not help much either. I stand corrected, in hindsight, on both counts. It was not overly sentimental at all and the audience behaved a-typical, both in the positive sense of the word.In spite of the considerable, above average length of 146 minutes, the story has a drive of its own and keeps our attention from start to finish. This is mostly due to the ingeniously constructed script. Events initially seeming to leave an open end, are fulfilled later on to be seamlessly integrated in the plot. I cannot think of many suggestions to edit away redundant scenes, or to strike some of the participants.An enormous number of people appear throughout the film, all of them needed to make up the story. For some reason this did not overwhelm us viewers. It was always clear who-was-who and what their role was. One word of advice: skip reading the Plot Synopsis on IMDb for this movie. It certainly will leave you confused behind, by giving a needlessly fragmented view on the story line.The only problem I have with the story is that it not only covers black and white racial prejudices, but also is populated with black and white characters, figuratively speaking. It cannot be that all blacks in the movie are good, and that nearly all whites treat them badly. This one-dimensionality may emphasize the general tendency of the story, but it is unrealistic and uncalled for. Within these confines, all actors are believable and perform very well.The open ending does not leave us unsatisfied, rather the contrary. Maybe it is the best solution to wrap-up the story. You can expect that some of the main characters will face difficult times, in spite of the momentum in the positive direction that is caused by the book that they helped to make. We see an example near the end where one of the helps is fired for the wrong reasons. This sort of revolutionary collateral damage cannot always be avoided, neither in movies nor in the real world. Racial prejudices won't disappear overnight, and may even take a few generations to overcome.

Great movie. Painful situations that hopefully in this day and age are corrected. I wish some caucasian people would have to be maids to African Americans. There should be a movie about that. You will note that I write in the manner of the late Andy Rooney; dry humor and irony.The two actresses who portrayed the main maids looked wonderful at the Golden Globes. I cannot remember their names, but they are excellent. They were both up for awards, I think, and one of them won. They looked so wonderful as their real selves, all glamorous and youthful.Some of this movie reminded me of Driving Miss Daisy and Fried Green Tomatoes. There was a Southern feel to the movie and portrayals. If they say tomatoes are in the pie, watch out for the real ingredients. If you have recently committed some sins toward someone, you will get paid back big time.10/10

reviews.review_title: Celia Foote (Jessica Chastain), Hilly Holbrook (Bryce Dallas Howard) and Skeeter Phelan (Emma Stone)
reviews.content: Favorite scene withCelia Foote (Jessica Chastain) - Embarrassing Hilly at the Party.Hilly Holbrook (Bryce Dallas Howard) - Eating 2 slices of "Special Pie" made by and from Minny and learning what Minny's Secret Ingredient is.Skeeter Phelan (Emma Stone) - Her Heart-To-Heart Scene with her Mother.

My wife had been talking about this great book that she had read called "The Help." Her reading list and mine intersect on so few titles that I automatically assume that any book she reads is not for me. On Wednesday, she told me that she wanted to see the movie being released that day. She also told me that it was over two hours long. I had dreadful memories of the leg cramps I suffered by attending "Wings of the Dove" with her some years ago, so I hoped that our next-door neighbor would want to go with her. No such luck! I prepared for an unpleasant afternoon and more leg cramps. I reluctantly turned off my iPhone as the last preview ended and hoped I wouldn't snore too loudly. As the movie opened, I was immediately completely enthralled. I was college age in the era that the film was set and I had lived for a school year in Tallahassee, a city not unlike Jackson, during that time. I especially remembered the "Colored Only" soda fountain inside of a "five and dime" that refused to let me buy a cold drink on a hot day. This movie captures the time and the place to perfection. In addition, the acting is superb and will lead to some Oscars and Golden Globes for some actresses. I loved the movie and highly recommend it to those other reluctant guys out there.
Too cookie cutter stuff. just an attemp to appeal to a certain nieche. movie is fine and all, but its story and message are void of meaning. so yea, mediocre film.5/10: almost bad

reviews.review_title: Best Movie of the Year So Far
reviews.content: If you read the book "The Help," you will certainly not be disappointed in the movie. The movie faithfully follows the important parts of the book, and it hardly misses a beat. I'd say that both the book and the movie are equally great, and there are so many outstanding performances in the movie that are Oscarworthy for 2012. Most importantly, you will go through many emotions. You will laugh, cry, and most of all, feel intelligent. That is the basis of feel-good movies - to evoke an emotion in you.Emma Stone is Eugenia "Skeeter" Phelan, the center heroine of the story who isn't looking for marriage, is dating the son of a politico, but just finished college and is looking to become a journalist. She is rejected at first in New York, but is immediately accepted as the advice giver "Miss Myrna" for a local newspaper in Mississipi. But "Miss Myrna" is not enough. She realizes that she has been raised by a loving black housekeeper named Constantine (beautiful cameo by aging actress Cicely Tyson, and has been a staple in intelligent black acting), and out of all her old college friends, she is the only one who has never taken her housekeeper for granted. All her other friends have turned evil as they hired housekeepers to raise their babies and do all the hard work for them, while they are hedonistically having fun and playing bridge. The meanest of all of them is Hilly Holbrook. Bryce Dallas Howard, Ron Howard's lookalike daughter, viciously chews up her character of Hilly with boundless enthusiasm, and I hope that she gets an Oscar nomination for her portrayal. Emma Stone is quieter in her role as Skeeter, but I think she should get an Oscar nomination as Best Actress because she played her so honestly and faithfully.The housekeepers are marvelously played and the actresses' performances of them are priceless. Viola Davis will touch you deeply as Abileen, the Oprah Winfrey-esque domestic, who is more loving to Katherine Leefolt's (Ahna O'Reilly) neglected daughter, and convinces her that all people are equal, and they are. Octavia Spencer is a hoot who provides comic relief as the overweight, sassy, blurting domestic Minny, who lost so many jobs, is a heck of a cook, and tells everyone what she thinks of them. She is first booted out of Hilly's house, when Hilly discovered she was using the family bathroom, and then told everyone she stole silver as a cover-up, but then she forms a wonderful relationship with the naive but troubled new girl in town, Celia Foote (Jessica Chastain, looking and acting like Marilyn Monroe, and yet bringing intelligence and complexity to the character). Unlike the book, Celia keeps Minny as Minny forms a strong bond with Celia after her miscarriage, and helps her through her intimidation of her husband Johnny's former lover, Hilly. And of course, there's those hilarious and unforgettable Minny's chocolate pie scenes, the comic relief of the movie and book.In addition to the bright young cast, there are wonderful supporting parts by veteran southern-born actresses - Sissy Spacek plays Hilly's equally prejudiced mother who may or may not dig into the pie. Mary Steenburgen as Elaine Stein, the New York-based editor of Harper and Row who at first is reluctant to hire Skeeter, but after Skeeter's book,"The Help," is published, she accepts her. That makes Skeeter have to leave her ill mother, (Allison Janney, in an icy performance) behind. Her mother doesn't tell Skeeter about the entire truth of why Constantine, the housekeeper who raised her, disappeared, so that is where Skeeter uncovers the truth of domestics and their employers."The Help" is a perfect marvel that is faithful as historical fiction. It speaks the truths of the Civil Rights Era and the beliefs of blacks and whites alike. This was author Kathryn Stockett's first novel, and it is a huge blockbuster. Writer-director Tate Taylor follows the book meticulously, but dilutes it for the 2-hour and 15-minute running time for content. He delivers honest and emotional portrayals from everyone, whether the characters are touching, sensitive, funny, or cold-hearted. Hands down the best picture of the summer, and were not even into the fall, but this movie makes for an Oscar Contender, and I hope my prediction will be right. I would like the Academy to remember Emma Stone as Best Actress, Bryce Dallas Howard as Best Supporting Actress, Tate Taylor as Best Director, and "The Help" as Best Picture. I would also like to add Viola Davis for her tender performance as Abileen for an Oscar nomination as well.

reviews.review_title: Pretty Soap Opera with Magical Negroes
reviews.content: I enjoyed "The Help" but for all the wrong reasons. I loved the high production values, the beautiful lighting, the shots of ripe agricultural fields in the Deep South. I especially loved the exquisite, tailor-fit, vintage, early 1960s dresses worn by the white actresses. I got a huge kick out of the over-the-top performances. Bryce Dallas Howard, though a living person, is every bit the Walt Disney cartoon villainess. You love hating her. You grimace when she cackles and you cackle as she reaches her inevitable, and utterly unbelievable, nightmare, revenge-dream-fantasy downfall. Howard should have won an academy award. Viola Davis, who radiates soul and depth and can make you cry just by walking into a room, is the deep, rich heart of this otherwise silly film. Octavia Spencer is adorable. She's as big-eyed and woebegone as a DW Griffith Gish sister. I have no idea why Emma Stone is the star. She can't act much and she isn't a drop dead beauty. Maybe she knows someone. "The Help" is about black-white relations in Mississippi in the early 1960s. Jim Crow Mississippi was a terrorist state. That sounds like an extremist statement; it is not. The Mississippi Sovereignty Commission planted spies in every nook and cranny of Mississippi life. It aided at least one assassin, Byron de la Beckwith, who murdered Medgar Evers. This deadly serious, tense, historic era is reduced, in "The Help," to a very pretty soap opera featuring magical Negroes – a term used to describe black characters in mostly white films who exist only to provide a means for the main, white character to grow. You notice immediately in "The Help" that the white women are all slim, elegantly and flatteringly dressed, and pretty. The black women are plump, older, and plain. But, this is an uplifting film about Civil Rights, so all the black women are noble, giving, selfless, and saintly, while all, except one, of the whites are vicious, vacuous, selfish, and bad mothers. Also, all the whites are filthy rich. Was it really that way, you have to ask? No, it wasn't. Mississippi has one of the highest white poverty rates in the US. And some whites joined the Civil Rights struggle, performing the ultimate sacrifice, and giving their own lives. Still waiting for a feature film about Viola Liuzzo. Maybe it's not such a bad thing that simplistic and overtly exploitative movies like this get made. If they interest any viewers in the Civil Rights movement, that's not a bad thing. Maybe it will inspire some to see a truly worthy film series, "Eyes on the Prize."

reviews.review_title: Is this the only movie in history that features six women who have won an acting Oscar?
reviews.content: Plus another with an honorary Oscar.I don't know, but it is a bloody good movie as you would expect with so much talent involved. It is not often that a movie has an almost entirely female cast, yet when you watch it you don't really notice because the story and characters are so engrossing.

This movie was never in my watchlist till I found it on OTT and gave it a try. To be honest, I wasn't expecting the movie to be this good. The story was told in real manner and execution was also good making this movie both sweet and tragic at the same time. I think the pacing and the runtime had some problems. The pacing was uneven and runtime could have been easily shortened. Other than that it was a nice watch.I read that many black people criticized saying that movie is told from white perspective but I don't see any problem there. At least they didn't try to whitewash them.Overall, it was a good movie which everyone should give a try.

reviews.review_title: One of the best films of the modern age of cinema
reviews.content:
Not a single bad performance in this film. Everyone is at the top of their game.
Funny, heartbreaking, eye-opening... it has everything.

reviews.review_title: I'm so glad 'The Help' gets the ending it deserves.
reviews.content: Happy ending often gets bad name for being unrealistic or overly dramatic, but not all movies have to be documentary. The literature or film always represent some part of the reality, but the quality of them depend on how the director paints the rest of the picture with imagination and creativity.'The Help' deals with serious subject at the very important time in history. Even many great movies talking about injustice and abuse against the minority are hard to watch sometimes because they break my heart more than I can handle. It still means they are excellent because they succeed in drawing strong empathy from the audience. This film's approach is little more special. It discusses hard and heavy subject, but how it handles that subject is pleasant, upbeat, and hopeful. Content bulky but form slim and trendy. It still saddens me from time to time, but I can smile at the same time.The colors of the movie supports the positive energy. Warm and bright color sand lightings such as yellow and gold are used throughout the movies, so audience subconsciously can maintain optimistic vibe. Great ensemble of cast. Each character brings out the best of her own unique personality, so different from one another that they speak for different perspectives of different people in Mississippi in 60s. Performances are not too heavy and not too light, having the perfect balance of control from all actors. The chemistry among cast is so adorable.

reviews.review_title: Woman Power on the Big Screen
reviews.content: I am happy to write a review for this film. It has been a long time since I have seen a film which actually stood up for something. This entire cast presented a brilliantly acted, honest, sincere depiction of what happened during these troubling times. The humor throughout this film provided the right amount of comic relief, but did not take away from the severity of these horrible issues. There were so many great performances that I could write for hours about each one of them. I definitely do see this movie being up for Best Picture, and well as Best Ensemble cast. The women in this film held their own and produced a KNOCKOUT of a film. Congratulations to the writer, producer and director of this film, please take your bow! And congratulations to all of the women who brought us a dose of reality, you make me happy to be a WOMAN.... Enjoy your moment..You All Deserve It!

The Help made quite a splash when it topped the box office list and stayed there for a pretty long time, fending off horror movies, sci-fi blockbusters and romantic comedies. Enough time had passed, though, to be able to admit that it's really not all that great, and very far from the 'best film of the year slot'.The Help isn't a bad movie, but it treads very familiar ground, on one hand showing once again how awful racism is, while also white-washing history and giving it a very politically correct treatment. The story is pretty touching, in a manipulative sort of way, but it's been seen many times before.The acting is what makes The Help worth watching after all - Octavia Spencer and Viola Davis are both truly terrific, and they manage to crawl completely into their characters' skins take the viewer back through time to the early 60's. Bryce Dallas Howard and Jessica Chastain are excellent too. Emma Stone almost ruins it though, as she really failed to convince me her character was real or that she wasn't a girl from the 2000's playing in a period piece.Overall, a watchable movie - acting, pretty cinematography and costumes, and good editing give it the 7 stars rating - but not a very memorable one.

reviews.review_title: Same old clichés, same old stereotypes, same old story ... its been done before (over and over)
reviews.content: Films like this really make me despair. The contrast between black people and white people's reaction to these kind of films confirms that despite the veneer of living in a post racial world, we merely coexist, are not really integrated in any meaningful way underneath that comforting false veneer. Generally, speaking, overwhelmingly, white people have called this film (and the book its derived from), one of the best things they've read/watched, very funny and entertaining, a must watch film, whilst black people in general have found it "hard to watch", a rehash of old themes and stereotypes, and even humiliating/insulting.Regarding the themes and the content of the film itself, its all been done before (over and over again) ... nothing new here. A movie purportedly about racism afflicting an oppressed community, but actually about the experience of the affluent white person defending that community. "Cry Freedom." "Mississippi Burning.",﻿ the list goes on ... The fact that films like 'The Blind Side' (and now possibly this), receive such wide acclaim and become box office hits (despite the protestation of minorities who feel infantalised by the film), tells an uncomfortable dynamic of existing race and power in our so called post racial world.This film is nothing more than a self congratulatory, self aggrandizing, condescending and patronising attempt at yet another make over of the great white hope theme. Having said that, I have no doubt that this film will at the very least be nominated for an Oscar, and very likely actually win one - after all, we DO like to see ourselves portrayed on screen as the great saviour, or the great WHITE hope - don't we?.

reviews.review_title: Good but Not as Good as It Could Have Been
reviews.content: I wanted this movie to be good but I was disappointed at how we saw more about the white families than about the maids and their families. If the filmmakers wanted to be an historically accurate think-piece, they really should not have made the trailers make the movie seem like a comedy. If they wanted it to be a comedy, they shouldn't have included some of the more vicious racial elements. It ended up being a movie that made you laugh at parts and really made you squirm in your seat at other parts but left you feeling like you were robbed of something that could have been really great. All that being said, however, it was a pretty good main-stream movie touching on the subject of household help and the racial tensions involved in the nascent Civil Rights era of the 50s and 60s that I haven't seen before. It was interesting to see how these women so bonded with their employer's children and how the children saw their maids as their second (or even "real") mothers.Basically, it was a good movie but don't expect to learn much from it.

reviews.review_title: It's a hit for good reasons
reviews.content: It's a hit for good reasons; fine writing where Kathryn Stockett is concerned, based on reviews and info I read of her Novel, great script adaptation and direction by Tate Taylor, fine cinematography from Stephen Goldblatt and a cast that delivered superb performances from everyone. The main actors Emma Stone, Octavia Spencer, Viola Davis and Bryce Dallas Howard were convincing and I liked their performances; Bryce Dallas Howard in the unflattering role of Hilly Holbrook was as convincing as the other more affable characters that we will all tend to remember of course. The short scenes with Cicely Tyson playing Constantine were the most moving.This film is meant to move and inspire; reviews I've read so fare bear this out as do the ratings from the usual sources I consult. The IMDb full Storyline, for those who have not read that, the book or the official site's account, will suffice as setting the expectations. The characters are very well developed and the concept of the story lends itself especially well for that. One hundred and ninety IMDb users have taken the time to write their opinions, in large part if not totally praising the movie for all the obvious reasons. I felt compelled to do the same. It's the first story of its kind, 'what life was like for African American maids in Mississippi in the early 1960s, from their perspective; they raised white children and were more parent to them then were some of their actual parents. Then these same white children in too many instances, later were their employers and treated them like sh*t. This story needed to be told and now is better late than never. Its originality is what makes it special. I expect there will be many more reviews repeating the message expressed by reviews thus far and I would not be surprised if there wasn't at least several Oscar nominations.

reviews.review_title: A noble message and a great cast makes an excellent film
reviews.content: Racism is nothing new. It has been around for several millennia. Films about this topic are almost delivered as much as adaptations of Marvel comics. Of such films, I have only seen two fairly decent ones about racism in the south. These are "To Kill a Mocking Bird" and "A Time to Kill." "The Help" marks the third one on the list. This movie takes a different perspective from the norm. Its focus is through the eyes of a young aspiring writer and a group of maids that work in southern homes. This movie is not down and ugly like "Mississippi Burning" or "A Time to Kill." Nor is there any suspense, action, or death. It is presented as a drama with strong bits of humor, emotion, and sadness.People fail to realize that racism is something that is taught from generation to generation. For centuries, blacks were always seen as lower than the white citizens. It is not by choice; it is what they know. The unfortunate thing is that people choose not to change these ideals. White people in the South are not evil; they are ignorant to see African-Americans as human beings. This is the central theme to this movie and it makes it great.In addition with a great message, "The Help" has properly the greatest ensemble cast of 2011. Viola Davis gives a subtle, but stellar performance Aibleen Clark. It is more than obvious that her character is in pain, yet wields strength and courage in a world full of bigotry. Octavia Spencer as her friend Minnie is easily the most likable character. She has her way with people who cross her (beware of her pies). However, she presents herself as a strong-willed character that is smart and funny; she can take a matter head-on and succeed. Emma Stone pales in comparison between Davis and Spencer, but she makes her character her own. She is not afraid to stand up for what she believes in—which certainly adds in giving her a solid performance. Other noteworthy roles include: Jessica Chastain, Bryce Dallas Howard, and Chris Lowell.The sets, costumes, and cinematography seems a little limited, giving it a more TV movie look rather than a feature film. This isn't bad though—the theme and cast are enough to sell this movie as a success. However, I was little disappointed in the ending. Without giving anything away, it seems to distract from the

reviews.review_title: Several of the performances make The Help an endearing look at a dark chapter in American history
reviews.content: This is an adaptation of Kathryn Stockett's bestselling novel, set in Jackson, Mississippi, during the 1960s. The film follows three different women. The first is Skeeter (Emma Stone), a young woman hired to write a column about housecleaning. She's also wondering what happened to her maid Constantine, who helped raise her, but has now disappeared. The second is Aibileen (Viola Davis) and Skeeter asks her for advice with her column. She's a maid for Elizabeth (Ahna O'Reilly) a snobby woman who can barely be bothered looking after her own children. The third woman is Minny (Octavia Spencer) and she finds work as a maid for Celia (Jessica Chastain), who lives out of town. Celia doesn't want her husband to know that she can't cook or clean so Minny has to help secretly. Bring these women together is Skeeter's plan to write about how African American maids are treated by their white employers. She's upset that one of her friends Hilly (Bryce Dallas Howard) is looking to enforce a rule that will force the 'help' to have separate bathrooms from their white employers. But Skeeter finds the maids reluctant to share their experiences because of the dangerous political climate in Jackson. Tate Taylor's second feature film The Help is an absorbing period drama, regardless of whether you have read Kathryn Stockett's novel. I have read the novel and the essence of the story is retained. It's a moving story that suggests that change is found in people of all ages, generations and races. It believes in the power of literature to inform people and to change the world. And there are ideas of class and the importance of public perception in this time period too. There are no easy divisions in either the novel or the film. Not all the white's are selfish or simply racist. They're willing to alienate their own people too. We see the women's deliberate exclusion of Celia and also learn that Hilly put her own mother (Sissy Spacek) in a nursing home. But nor are all the African American's innocent either. They make poor choices too. An ongoing thread is that after Minny was fired she decided to give Hilly a booby trapped cake, which she later regrets. And off camera it's apparent that Minny is physically abused at home. Though many scenes from the novel have been omitted entirely, it's a very solid adaptation. The film is beautiful in recreating the period, but never glossy. Despite being nearly two and a half hours long the film doesn't linger either. It's well paced and the images resonate with us. One of the most memorable is seeing the 'help' walk out of their homes of a morning, dressed in their uniforms. We see Minny giving instructions to her daughter who is now part of the 'help'. That subtly reminds us that these women weren't just employed for one lifetime. What's missing from the film are the darker elements of the novel. In the novel there's a broader overview of the violent atrocities around Mississippi that's absent here. It is indeed a compromise but more for business reasons rather than a political agenda. This is a mainstream film that has already flourished at the US box office. If the film was uglier less people might have seen it at all. But then it might have been more honest too. It's a great example of the dilemmas faced by the studio system. Instead, the fear and anxiety of the period comes through many of the performances. Almost all of the women in this film are superb. Emma Stone is extremely lively and funny as the oddball Skeeter. But she smartly replaces a lot of her flamboyance and sarcasm from Easy A (2010) with a greater sense of vulnerability. Some of her expressions when revelations about her mother are announced are extremely touching. But Viola Davis is the one almost certain to be nominated for Best Actress early next year. She has the bravest face in the film and yet underneath her internal conflict is so visible and moving. Her performance, particularly when she talks about her son, is painfully genuine. Spencer and Howard are charismatic women too. The latter contrasts the fake smiles of parties and charity dinners with ice-cold looks of suspicion perfectly. The only weak link is, I think, Chastain. I was expecting a quieter performance, closer to her excellent work in The Tree of Life (2011). She's extremely colourful here when her character in the novel is physically deteriorating and spends a lot of time alone in her room. Granted, that would be a lot harder to film on screen. The film might not have the grit of an independent picture like Precious (2009) but several of the performances make The Help an endearing look at a dark chapter in American history.

I'm not a big fan of movies like The Help. I was hearing about it for months and I was tired of it, but I knew deep down that it would be good. Then, I witnessed it for myself, and now i'm... a helper? Well, a fan of The Help.The film revolves around a sweet white girl named Skeeter(of course played by Emma Stone) who, unlike the others around her, likes black people in 1950's Mississippi. So in order to give maids,such as Abeline and Minny(played wonderfully by Viola Davis and Octavia Spencer in possible Oscar glory roles) the justice that they deserve, she decides to write a book from their point of view.The Help sounds like it would be a straight-forward drama. Usually racial movies are pretty serious. But The Help, while being dramatic, blends with humor, and actually has a lot of memorably hilarious moments that stay with you long after.The performances from everyone all around, especially from Davis, Spencer, and Bryce Dallas Howard as the evil Hilly, are fantastic. There are a couple of tear jerking moments, don't get me wrong, but The Help is lighter than you'd expect.It's a wonderful movie, even if it doesn't end as well as it should have. Despite it's ending, it's one of the year's best and is definitely worth seeing. If you're like me and you didn't want to see it, please do. Honestly, you won't regret it.A-

One of my wife's biggest pet peeves is that I typically become bored with movies because usually, half way thru the movie, I can usually predict much of the content and the ending. Most movies suffer from a lack of originality ! Most share the same conversations and plot, the only difference is the title of the movie and the revolving circuit of actors. "The Help" is so very refreshing because there was a new twist or development around every turn. The cast of actors introduced many people that are not on the actor revolving door list and that was exciting to see their performances.

reviews.review_title: That you now this things happened
reviews.content: An Movie that told a Story about black women who stood up for themselves. I think the team shows on a good and impressive way how the black people make true, even in the 60's and in some places even now. The choice for the actors was a good choice. It look like they live in that time en they came of the screen with a lot of confidence. They give you a good feeling so you understand where the movie is about. Even with a bit of humor.
I thought this gave interesting perspectives into a certain place and time in social history. The friendships in the movie were powerful and the performances were strong.

A really poor adaptation of a quite brilliant book. I find it difficult to comprehend how they managed to go so wrong with such excellent material. This felt like second rate TV movie throughout, poorly directed and cast. It was very difficult to feel any empathy with Emma Stone's portrayal of Skeeter, her performance lacked any of the depth and complexity of the written equivalent. Bryce Dallas Howard also overplayed Hilly Holbrook in what could have become one of the great on screen villains. The cinematography was also very bland and poor. Having recently seen the likes of Drive, and Tinker, Tailor, Soldier, Spy at the cinema 'The Help' appears as if it was shot by a 12 year old with his first camera in comparison. Normally I find IMDb ratings an accurate basis of a film's quality. How this Sunday afternoon schmaltz has got 8 stars is beyond me.

If you're looking for an informative Civil Rights movie, this probably isn't for you. Although the movie does give its viewers a good idea of some civil rights issues during the 60s, I think that the dramatization takes away from the history of the era. It's more of a drama about relationships, than a historical film. The movie revolves around Skeeter, a white journalist, searching for black maids who are willing to share their stories with her. I thought it was interesting to learn about the crucial role that the maids played in the families that they worked for. They practically raised the children, and yet they were treated horribly and received very little pay. Despite my interest in the maids' stories, the "white savior" aspect of the movie bothered me. Skeeter rescued the maids, and in the end she advanced in her career as a journalist when she earned her dream job. Although it is powerful and interesting, I think that the movie is a bad representation of important history.

reviews.review_title: A heartwarming serving of humble pie
reviews.content: Even a decade after it first made an impact on society, the civil rights era drama 'The Help' still packs a punch as an important story that needed to be told.It's hard to retain the special formula when translating a book about a book into a film, but Tate Taylor manages to do so exceptionally well here. Of course, aside from a timeless story, the true triumphs in 'The Help' are the performances of the leading ladies, from Viola Davis and Octavia Spencer as black maids who have powerful stories to tell, to Emma Stone as a rebellious spirit, and the innocent and villainous desperate housewives of Jackson, MS, led by Jessica Chastain and Bryce Dallas Howard. These performances were strong enough to yield multiple nominations, including a win for Spencer as the sassy, pie-baking Minny Jackson.It really is this all-star cast that brings 'The Help' to life, but they wouldn't be able to deliver without having such important source material to work with. The range of emotions felt throughout a watch of this film is vast, and it manages to tug on heartstrings in an unassuming way. Because the character development is so thorough, you end up developing an attachment to the individuals whose lives are at the center of the story - a sign of a truly well-made film.'The Help' may not have won best picture, but it will be remembered as a heartwarming, humorous, serious commentary on how things were, and a reminder of how far we've come.

reviews.review_title: Just a bad feeling watching this film
reviews.content: The main characters in this film are stereotypes, which is OK - bu this film had pretensions to delve deep into inter-race relations in the Deep south - the characters are extremely simplistic. The Black characters really are barely above the mammy/maid stereotype - but add to that that the white girls are just mean, the one poor white girl is clueless, then you have the Great White Savior Figure Skeeter - this movie was so depressing to me,, so dirty in it's fundamental assumptions, - it's just a mean, crabby movie. I wish I never saw it, it's like some nasty film on your mind. I will try to forget this as soon as I can .

"Oscar season", as it's typically referred to, is a period of time, usually beginning in late November, and ending in late January. This year, it starts early, with The Help."The Help" is based on the well-known novel by Kathryn Stockett, someone who I had never heard of before discovering this film and book. For the most part, when I hear about a film that I want to see, I try to read the book prior to viewing the movie, to enhance the whole experience. Usually I get bored, or stop mid-way through one of these said books, before I end up watching the movie.But "The Help" grabbed me. Stockett kept me on a leash, dying to know what happened next, and I ended up finishing its 530 pages in a few sittings. And, I'm glad it did, because "The Help" is not only the best movie I've seen this summer, but it very well could be the best one I see all year.The film centers on Aibileen, Skeeter and Minny (Davis, Stone and Spencer, respectively) three very different women in Mississippi, in the year 1962. Skeeter is returning from graduating college with a journalism degree, whose beloved childhood black maid Constantine has disappeared, and no one will tell her where she has gone. Aibileen is a maid who has raised 17 white children in her life. Her outspoken friend Minny has never been able to keep quiet, or, because of this, hold onto a job very long. Skeeter decides to write a tell-all book of interviews from the maids of Jackson, Mississippi, which, as you could imagine, was a very taboo thing in that time and place.One of the reasons that this film succeeds is that not a single character is miscast. In the book, Stockett paints a vivid picture of each character, and the actors clearly got lost in the characters they were playing. Emma Stone is becoming a very important actress. I haven't seen her in a role that I didn't love her in. After getting her first notable role in 2009's Zombieland, and then livening and carrying the otherwise bland teen comedy Easy A, this is her first dramatic role, as Skeeter, one of the lead characters. While she sometimes blends into the background in this movie, she shines beautifully with the rest of the cast. She's definitely one to watch.While Stone is great, this movie belongs to Viola Davis and Octavia Spencer. Davis's Aibileen is perfect. She has a silent sadness about her, a lot of pride, and a great sense of anger, while never raising her voice the whole film. She handles emotional scenes beautifully, reducing the audience to tears in more than one scene. She's a early in the year front-runner for Best Actress this Oscar season.Spencer also does a beautiful job as Minny. Octavia Spencer was the original inspiration for the character of Minny, who voiced the character's section in the audio-book. She was clearly made to play this role. She does a lot more for this movie, than just adding comic relief, but she plays the comedic side the best. The "terrible awful" that her character does in the book, is made into the funniest thing in the whole movie. The supporting cast is dead-on too. Bryce Dallas Howard (Ron's daughter) plays the town's snobby ringleader, Hilly. She's absolutely chilling, nailing the evil character. Her mother, played by Sissy Spacek is a hoot. The town's secretive lush, and Minny's boss, Celia, is played by newcomer Jessica Chastain, who wowed earlier this year in "The Tree of Life". She was completely like I envisioned her character in the book. There's not enough typing space in this review to describe how much I loved the rest of the supporting cast. Everyone was dead-on.I was under the assumption that this would be yet another disappointing film of a book loved by many. The reason for this was the director and writer. I had never heard of this Tate Taylor, and because of that, I wasn't sure that I trusted him. He had a large part in making this movie all that it was. One of the big reasons that "The Help" works as a movie is because it feels authentic. It was filmed in Mississippi, where it's based, it is set in the 1960's, and every feeling about the movie hits the right note. I later discovered that Taylor was a childhood friend of the book's author. Not some Hollywood hack. I forget the many disappointing film adaptations of books I loved that were made by the Hollywood elite. "The Da Vinci Code" by Ron Howard, "Memoirs of a Geisha" by Rob Marshall, "Eat, Pray, Love" by Ryan Murphy. Enough said. After seeing this film, I couldn't imagine anyone better-suited to making the film. What is special about this film is that it is not what a lot of people will probably write it off as. It is not a film to make white audiences feel less white guilt. It avoids this sentimentality, I don't know how, but it succeeds in that, like I thought it wouldn't.While some changes are (intelligently) made from the book, it's almost a scene-for-scene adaptation of the book. Some things are different, because they need to be, and things are a little more concise, yet it's almost like watching an abridged version of the book, on screen. I can't say enough good things about this film.

This, of course, is an emotional and strong subject which is felt greatly in this film. But The Help has some amazing acting, great writing, and an overall perfect portrayal of the struggles faced by many during this time period.This movie was serious and emotional, but it was also hilarious!!! I have not been to many movies where an entire audience bursts into laughter multiple times during one film. The "sassy" oneliners from a couple of prominent characters and the karma that comes back to bite some asses creates so many funny moments!! This is one of its strongest characteristics. We can only take so much intensity. The break-up of comedy gives this movie a great dynamic.The acting was excellent! Emma Stone, who plays the young journalist, once again is kind of broadening her repertoire. She portrays this strong-will girl who doesn't quite measure up to the usual beauty queens of the south. She has the look, the acting ability, and the subtle comedy to support the other great actors in this film. I was really impressed with Octavia Spencer, who plays one of the maids. She had an amazing character written for her, but she could not have acted better! Her character was the source of the majority of the humor and she executed it all perfectly! Throughout the movie I was continually impressed by her performance. The rest of the cast was great. They set the scene and created the characters wonderfully, but I was most impressed with Spencer and Stone.The biggest pull of a film like this is it gives us a peek into the past. This was such a volatile time in history and has been represented in a variety of medias. But The Help shows a more personal perspective. It puts you in the homes and lives of people living during this time and people trying to challenge the current system. Emma Stone's character's mother at one point says, "Courage sometimes skips a generation." This referred to her feelings about her daughter trying to challenge these negatives systems in society when she was unable to. I just wondered how many parents at this time felt the same way. The idea that my great- grandparents or others living during this time could have thought that way makes the depth of the film intensify.Overall, this was a moving, emotional, and funny movie. It shows a great picture of the struggles of inequality during the 1960s, but it's not just about a societal issue or history. It is so much more than that. Plus it was really fun to watch. You feel connected to the characters, because you watch their emotion and struggles play out. The majority of the audience tonight was women and older couples. I think it will resonate most with this audience most, but I would recommend this film to everyone!SEE IT!!

reviews.review_title: A few moments of lumpy throat emotion but no Cry Freedom.
reviews.content: I whizzed through the novel by Kathryn Stockett. It's an easy read and a couple of evenings took care of it without any great aching of the brain. It's no Tolstoy (it's not even as demanding as a Stephen King) but certainly more entertaining. The trouble is, it's popular. Very popular.And then came this; the popular, the very popular, film adaptation.I rail against the hysteria that follows a new fad, particularly films and books. I have a real aversion to being told what I must like and how much I should like it. I resisted Harry Potter for a good few years until my nieces insisted I read it to them. And then? Actually I though thought the first book was bland and distinctly average and, had it not been for the gentle urging of a respected friend, I would have stopped at book one. The Help, apparently unable to speak for itself, is another work being touted by the world's media as a great, a must-see, an Oscar certainty It's another cinematic bandwagon laden with unthinking passengers who are enjoying the mild hysteria they're experiencing and justifying by the ever-growing mountain of awards that is burying the film.For those who walk around with their fingers in their ears, it serves up the story of a privileged white girl who, in a bid to launch her writing career, hits upon the idea of writing a book from the point of view of the slaves, sorry, the help, who keep her home, and that of all the homes of the rich white folk in the deep south of America, going. It's onto a winner from the outset and has no work to do because, let's face it, we all know that racism is evil and, for the most part, the white folk have learned that much of what they did was despicable.I entered the cinema with an expectation, and perhaps even a determined hope, if I'm honest, that the film would fail for me and I'd leave unmoved and with thoughts overloaded with disdain to hurl into this post. I left with a slightly modified view and an emotional tickling i.e. not as severe as a bashing.I strongly suspect The Help is 2012's Driving Miss Daisy, to wit, we'll shower it with accolades now but in a few years we'll realize we've been hoodwinked and, actually, it's not very good. Yes, it serves up a few good moments of lumpy throat emotion but it wasn't sufficient to make me blub. Yes, it has something to say but it lacks the impact of, say, a Cry Freedom in its day. This is a classic case of preaching to the converted and allowing us all to feel good about ourselves because we agree with the message. I'm guessing it won't reach many die-hard KKK members and therefore will have no impact on the persisting issues.But there are plenty of high points, not least of all Jessica Chastain who is rapidly becoming one of my FAIDs (Five Allowed In Dreamtime – more on that in a later post) along with her unofficial sibling (is it only me who sees it?), Kelly Reilly. Her turn as Celia Foote is huggably engaging but, alas, she plays little more than light relief to the weightier roles Aibileen, Skeeter and Hilly. Viola Davis is sincere in her portrayal of Aibileen, the matriarch of her community, and the focal point for those handing out gongs but for me this is an ensemble piece and I don't think any actor stands out as more deserving than another. Although it may earn gold, it doesn't have gold written across it and I'll hark back to my comment about Driving Miss Daisy.Emma Stone is not the Skeeter I imagined as I read the book and she's coasting here, well below the quality and impact she previously promised in Easy A and even Zombieland. Alison Janney, yet again, enhances the group effort and Sissy Spacey has fun in a pantomime cameo.Much of the story is abbreviated for pace but the biggest cause of irritation comes at the end credits in the form of Mary J. Blige's horribly jarring song, The Living Proof, that is saccharine pulp and both too modern and too twee for a film that, despite it's lightweight failings, is a film worth spending a tenner and a couple of hours on.It's good. It's very enjoyable. It'll make you feel good about yourself for being on the side of justice. But it's a little like eating an entire loaf of white Mother's Pride toast with marmalade; it goes down perfectly but sometime after the event you'll realize there was no substance to it and you require something more, well, real. This year it earns four stars from me but I expect, if you ask me to watch it again in five years, I'll settle on three.

reviews.review_title: A Moving Film. More Than I Expected. A Dozen Great Performances.

reviews.content: The Help is a subtle film about black and white women. The absence of men is notable. It was also one of the few American films I needed subtitles for, as some of the language was hard to understand.I guess questions of race, class and nationality are hard to describe, especially in a movie. This particular movie got the point across pretty well. It appeals to peoples' sense of fairness quite acutely.The film has its good characters and bad ones, found some shades of grey too. It exhumed the wealth and lifestyle of the upper-class women of Jackson (site of the movie) in the 60s. It also pictures the society as tightly knit together: everybody knowing each other person. The underlying theme would the lacking equality of opportunity. The historical representation is interesting and seems right. The Help is a very emotional movie and it succeeds in every aspect of it. It's very well focused on one or two topics, but doesn't go too narrow. I wouldn't recommend watching 'The Help' with pop corn and family, as it does get too cruel at times.
Play The Help! It is fast and easy to view! A good way to spend your time. Be the best!

reviews.review_title: Good book, good movie, this movie is going to be a hit
reviews.content: I read the book because the book keeps showing up at the top of recommendation list at Amazon and pops up every time I was there. More than 3000 ratings and counting have been given. The book by itself is already a modern classics. Heartwarming stories and written nicely and partly in the languages of the colored maids. Its narrative is humorous in its own way and never loses the brightness of life even though it took place in one of the bad time for color people in the American history.A strong story makes its way into a strong movie. In contrast to an awful lot of mediocre book-adapting movies seen nowadays, the movie keeps all the essential elements of the book and makes itself a faithful representation. It contains the minor but important events of the book, which to my fear would have been first sacrificed for keeping the film to the normal movie length about 1 to 1.5 hours, especially those historic events are kept to my delight. That makes sure the contemporary pulse can be felt throughout the movie. It shows the fear and the horror to people from different time, countries or races, because they are not likely to image that zeitgeist at that time of madness and racism in USA. Colored people could get shot or have their house burned down just by talking about their situations. Even when their lives were spared from violence, they still had to face all kinds of hatred and discriminations, exemplified by having their separated bathrooms.As to the omitted parts, I feel that they were good cuts: Celia fought off a lunatic and drank those quack cures, Skeeter's invitation to Stuart's house and a few more are in fact not that vital in my opinions. Also, small changes to originals were made and I feel fine about them: Charlotte knew about her daughter's undertaking, Rachael was being dark-colored and more importantly Hilly and Elizabeth's remorse at the end of the movie. The latter was a nice touch even though it dampens a bit Hilly's harshness and her incorrigible attitude to the help, which may not be Mrs Stockett's original idea.All in all, this 2 hours long movie is a must see. I myself had waited since August when I finished reading the book and am glad that it quite lives up to the book and my expectations: and I am a mean critic when it comes to movies.

"The Help" delves into the issue of color discrimination and very sensitively puts the story of social discrimination on the blacks. The story is seen through the eyes of a black maid who brings up the children of whites and ultimately gets fired from her job as the children grow up. The similar faith goes with some other black maids of the surrounding. The plot revolves around few American families where the blacks served as maids and in return couldn't even use their wash rooms. The theme comes quite vividly in this social drama. Slow at times and at times losing its pace, many sequences of the film are quite touching and make you emotional. The film deserves a big applause for the touching drama and a tremendous performances from the lead, especially Octavia Spencer who gets an Oscar nod as the black maid, Minney and Viola Davis as Aibileen.Rating: 3 stars out of 4

reviews.review_title: Good cast in typical feel-good story
reviews.content: It's hard to fault a movie like this, when it seems perfectly aware of what kind of movie it wants to be, and does a great job achieving its goal. Basically it is a typical feel-good story, set in a small town with obvious racial tension. The story is at times predictable - though that often feels irrelevant for movies like this. It has been criticized for being another "white savior" movie, where the white character is needed to help the black characters out of their situation. I agree that it is too bad that there still are so many movies about this kind of stories being made, this movie handles it quite nicely.The highlight of this movie is the cast. There are some great performances in this movie from actors I was completely unfamiliar with. Mostly the "helps" are doing a great job, enhanced by convincing (to me) costume- and set-design.I wish that this movie would have had higher ambitions, gone longer in exploring the good side of "evil" people and the bad side of the good - making the characters all more human. There is a scene near the end where a certain character reveals a side of herself. I wish that this could have been a thread throughout the movie, that this ambivalence was given - not a reveal. I guess it would have been a different movie, but definitely a more interesting one.
This was a great movie! I'm glad this was made. A good story that needed to be told.

reviews.review_title: The Help is one Great Movie
reviews.content: "The Help" is One Great Must See Movie By: Jim Fordyce from American entertainment report August 11, 2011 Rating: 4 out of Fordyce (Perfect) I did something I rarely do. I left the studio in the afternoon and took in a matinée of a movie that wasn't being offered as a preview. I also (for the first time this year) uttered the words: "Best Picture" while the credits were rolling."The Help" is a movie none of you want to miss. GO SEE IT! Set in Mississippi in the early 1960s, the film features a southern society girl who returns from college determined to become a writer. She gets a job at the local newspaper writing the household cleaning column, which leads her to interview black women who have spent their lives taking care of prominent southern families.That description does not do this movie justice, nor does the trailer, which does not entice you to see it. I almost skipped this movie, and that would have been a mistake."The Help" tells the story of another era in a place where things were very different and attitudes were hard to change.The cast is an amazing collection of actors who are so believable you will feel like you are in their homes. Emma Stone is our heroine ready to write the stories; Octavia Spencer is marvelous, as are Jessica Chastain, Viola Davis, Bryce Dallas Howard, Chris Lowell, and Mike Vogel. One of my favorite actresses plays one mom. That would be Allison Janney. Sissy Spacek is the other mom, and the great Cicely Tyson gives a performance that is worthy of an Oscar.This is a great script that is beautifully produced. It will make you laugh, cry, be horrified, and be in love all within a time span of two hours and 17 minutes. There are no explosions in this movie, nor is there a lot bad language and dazzling special effects; rather, what you get is a collection of some real superheroes in the form of the women we meet.This one gets a perfect 4 out of Fordyce, so go see it. CREDIT CHECK: There is nothing at the end of the credits; "The Help" does it all before it ends, but wait a few moments to notice how the credits roll over a touching scene that is the perfect end to this perfect film.

reviews.review_title: Fantastic Movie that Really Looks at Our Society
reviews.content: This movie was fantastic! It was so critical of the 1960s while remaining funny and entertaining. The relationship between Eugenia, Minny, and Aibileen is so heartwarming and beautiful. They lived in a time that discriminated against blacks and women. To be women who took a stand against the injustice they saw and expressed is an example to all. I loved the movie and it's message and will be watching it again.

reviews.review_title: Excellent movie on white mistresses and black helps in America of the 60s
reviews.content:
This is the 2011 movie I had missed seeing earlier. I have now caught up with it and it is indeed a first rate movie. It is an incisive study of the way black domestic helps were mistreated in the America of the 60s. It is interesting to note that the actors of the 2011 movie have progressed into stars of today. Jessica Chastain is presently on top of the world having won the Oscar award for " The Eyes of Tammy Faye " . Viola Davis was a front runner in 2020 for the Oscar award for " Ma Rainey's bottom". Emma Stone played the female lead in " La La Land" a few years back. All three actors have done a splendid job in this movie. Of course not forgetting Octavia Spencer who is also a very talented artist and was excellent in a later movie called " Hidden figures".This movie is set in the time of the civil rights movement in the 60s. (There is a brief mention of the JFK assassination.) Emma Stone is a budding journalist who interviews and writes an account of the revelations of some black domestic helps and publishes a book by that name. The movie shows that while some white mistresses treated their helps affectionately, a few treated them with contempt and hatred. The law also treated blacks in a rough manner. The issue of non availability of bathrooms for blacks dealt with sensitively was also brought up later in
" Hidden figures" . Director Tate Taylor needs to applauded for treating the subject with great sensitivity. Actingwise, all actors have done a commendable job, and rightly deserve all the wins/ nominations of the awards.

There are more than one tear. The black daughter came to knock the door for her mother's life, and she cried and cried in tears..."God said we need to love our enemies, which is difficult. But we can learn to speak our true thoughts first, and no one asked me , As such a self, how do you feel, but when I say my inner feelings, I feel the pleasure of freedom."

reviews.review_title: The most beautifulest film I ever seen.
reviews.content:
So much inspiration in this film..
Must watch it!!

Very well made with a nicely paced plot that always keeps the audience interested. Some great performances also add to the enjoyment; Emma Stone played the inquisitive graduate, Skeeter Phelan with great assurance. Viola Davis as the central character Aibileen Clark was really excellent, as was Octavia Spencer as Minny Jackson. Bryce Dallas Howard was also first-rate as the main villain of the piece, Hilly Holbrook. I also thought that Jessica Chastain as Celia Foote did an excellent job.A film that has a real feel-good factor, it very much concentrates its focus on things from the perspective of the women, on both sides of the story, but in particular the maids. I found there were some very touching moments along with quite a lot of humour. It's set at a time and place where a lot of things were changing very rapidly, particularly in the aspect of race relations and you can see a lot of ignorance and bigotry. I should point out that not all the employers are bad; there are one or two stories that relate how the maids were cared for very well. Over all, I found this film quite uplifting; one I'd happily watch again at some point.SteelMonster's verdict: HIGHLY RECOMMENDED.My Score 8.7/10IMDb Score: 8.1/10 (based on 98,862 votes at the time of going to press).MetaScore: 62/100: (Based on 41 critic reviews provided by Metacritic.com at the time of going to press).Rotten Tomatoes 'Tomatometer' Score: 76/100 (based on 197 reviews counted at the time of going to press).Rotten Tomatoes 'Audience' Score: 90/100 'Liked It' (based on 67,805 user ratings counted at the time of going to press).You can find an expanded version of this review on my blog: Thoughts of a SteelMonster.

reviews.review_title: The movie's set in Missisippi of the 60's where a young college graduate, Skeeter played Emma stone tries to write a book from the point of view of the help.
reviews.content: I love this movie various reasons. One of it being that it deals with a writer who has found a scoop which also means a lot to her. The other element is that the movie is dealt with real events, social problems that were in the following decades abolished. The movie gives the audience the social problems and yet keeps the movie in a light jovial, comic atmosphere.This is true and I have learned it the hard way that the majority of people don't want to end a movie on a sad note, leaving the audience feeling down. We did a production of Romeo and Juliet at our school, the audience was with us when it came to the love scenes and fights but when it came to the star crossed lovers death and the sorrow of the parents the crowd just wanted to leave all that sad behind. I can understand this because frankly I don't want to go home from a film or play feeling pathetic, unless what I have witnessed was a masterpiece of a performance. This movie THE HELP got a brilliant harmony of seriousness and joviality.Know some of you might be surprised to find that the situation from where I write, which is India is still the same. What was the scene of MAIDS in the US in 1960's is the scene of MAIDS IN India TODAY. The Maids are treated the same, I can say this with certainty because right here at my own house I see it. The servant has a toilet in the garden which she can use, separate glass for the maid to drink tea from and off course the maid is not supposed to use the sofas to sit on, only the floor. This is the scene of maids all around the country; you can easily find that out by asking someone who leaves in India. The African American women were so much more defiant than the maids here and cooler too, I am just never having a pie by my Maid :P I Know the scene in India will change in the few decades ahead. All I can guarantee though is that I won't do these things to any human being and this movie is also the FIRST REVIEW I'M WRITING.

reviews.review_title: Interesting perspective, the truth will find its way, always!
reviews.content: A bit long, but it was saved by the ending and how things settled in. Well deserved nominations, I'm amazed by Jessica, her character evolved the most in this movie, almost broke a tear when she showed her intention of saying thank you. Beautiful but horrible story that some lived and had courage to tell. We should make more movies about these situations.

reviews.review_title: To me I saw a group of people ...
reviews.content: To me I saw a group of people who looked like me, but were from a different planet. I found it entertaining and provocative, especially given what is happening in the world today.
Charming story, I felt in love with this movie. Also, I enjoy everytime listening its soundtrack.

reviews.review_title: The Help (2011) - Chance Begins with a Whisper!
reviews.content: Adapted from the best-selling novel by Kathryn Stockett, "The Help" is a comedy-drama adaptation that stole the hearts of many movie lovers. With an all-star cast including Emma Stone, Viola Davis, Octavia Spencer, Bryce Dallas Howard, Jessica Chastain, Sissy Spacek, Mary Steenburgen, and a special appearance by Cicely Tyson, and a beautiful adaptation to a powerful novel, "The Help" is the movie that will steal your breath away. Set during the Civil Rights era in the early 1960s, the movie talks about a young white woman, portrayed by Emma Stone, and her relationship with two black maids, portrayed brilliantly by both Viola Davis and Octavia Spencer. Stone plays a journalist who decides to write a controversial book from the point of view of maids, expressing the racism they are given, when working with white families. This is quite a beautiful masterpiece, and it's one of the best movies of 2011. I was completely stolen into this movie from it's funny moments, to it's heartwarming messages. I loved this amazing casting ensemble, and they deserve total Oscar consideration. Emma Stone is wonderful for her third performance this year, Bryce Dallas Howard is incredible as the character you love to hate, Jessica Chastain is just magnificent, but it's both Viola Davis and Octavia Spencer that deserve Oscar nominations for their performances as the black maids. This beautiful script has helped create a movie filled with heart, emotion, truth, and courage. There was nothing in this movie that I did not like, because I was blown away by the sight of what I've just seen. This movie delivers powerful messages involving the Civil Rights movement, and how blacks should be respected equally. From the powerful messages to the incredible cast, "The Help" is the feel-good movie of the year, and you won't be disappointed because this is a powerful, and beautiful masterpiece for the ages. I hope this gets the Best Picture nomination of 2011. "The Help", in my review, "emotionally powerful, an exhilarating masterpiece".

Powerful, poignant, honest picture of life south of the Mason-Dixon Line prior to passage of the Civil Rights Act and subsequent government sanctioned civil strife/murder in the American south and cities throughout the nation. If you lived it, you will get flashbacks. If you were too young to live it, you will witness a piece of history accurately re-enacted.From hope in JFK and loss of that hope in his assassination, to the murder of Medgar Evers, to the blatant bigotry ingrained in 1963 Mississippi culture, to the heartbreaks and heartaches of African Americans in the South, this film will wrench your gut. And if you compare this movie to today's America, you will be stunned at the similarities. Similarities not necessarily in the racial sense, but certainly in economic policy...be cerebral when viewing this film, it is worth it. Best movie of its genre since Forrest Gump. The lead actors should get Academy Award nominations and this film should be nominated for Best Picture. End of story.

reviews.review_title: Good if you are interested in racism
reviews.content: This film is not a masterpiece by any means. The characters are very poorly constructed and there are clear antagonists and protagonists which follow all the clichés of Hollywood canned products. However, I still though it was a good film, since:1 - Emma Stone is hot. 2 - The acting was very good, despite the poorly constructed characters. 3 - I find racism a very interesting subject.The United States is a country which had a very interesting cultural phenomena: systematic racism between ethic groups. And I like movies that portray this phenomena, such as this one. Even though from a technical point of view, I should have given this film a 4/10 or 5/10, since it is really mediocre and I wouldn't recommend it for someone who harbors no interest in racism.

reviews.review_title: Only white people can save black people
reviews.content: That is the general vibe I get from this film. It's a good movie on paper but it just fails to properly address race relations in the 1960's. I can think of many better movies about racism in America. Movies that aren't afraid like the creators of "The Help" were. This having a higher rating than "Do The Right Thing" proves how watered down IMDB users like their movies.

reviews.review_title: Made for the galleries and entertain it does
reviews.content: Reviewed April 2012Not many movies can be branded clichéd, stereotypical, predictable and at the same time excellent and interesting. This movie is just that, of course some excellent acting and likable characters did help too. I always admire a maker's clarity on what they want to present, even if there are some glitches in execution, but this movie has none. Skeeter (Emma Stone) an aspiring author during the wake of Civil Rights movement, wants to write a book on the African-American maids point-of-view on their masters. The times are dark and for a black person to come forth and talk is also a crime in the State of Mississippi. After a few refusals, Aibileen Clark (Viola Davis) comes forth to talk and share her views. After a few more incidents, another maid Minny (Octavia Spencer) joins. Soon there are plenty of maids who want to share their stories after an injustice after another mounts on them. Skeeter has a neutral point-of-view and is determined to complete what she started, no matter what sacrifices she has to make. As I had mentioned earlier, this plot is completely cliché driven and the characters and sequences align themselves to present a viewer friendly closure to every incident present. But this whole mess is wrapped in such a nicely packed presentation, though it crossed the corner of my mind while watching, I could point them out only when I think of the scenes when writing the review. So in a way the movie has succeeded it's objective of holding the viewers attention and entertaining them too and the portrayal of those stereotypical characters to be likable is another peak to mount, which this ensemble cast does with ease. A special mention should go to Viola Davis and Octavia Spencer as the maids in focus, they are the ones that produce and control the emotional aspect of the movie. There she is, Jessica Chastain again featuring in the immediate movie I have watched, she does her reputation no harm here also displaying another dimension to her acting. She resembles a lot of Julia Roberts to me in both looks and acting wise. All the negative things you might have heard about this movie are probably true. But what triumphs is the excellent presentation and it should be a case study for that aspect, to hide all the limitations and plot holes at least until its runtime. A definite watch.

This film left me with a lot of thoughts in my mind. It is a well-known fact, that superiority of white people over black was called into question years ago. Still, history reveals that the lives of black people were full of humiliations even in the 20th century. The film tells us stories about the relationships between white families and their maids. Let me remind you of some of them.
In the middle of the 20th century, equal opportunities were more of a dream for negro. Just to give you an idea of how much the inequality was, imagine that some houses had a toilet built especially for maids. Whites couldn't stand sharing the same bathroom with blacks because blacks were thought to be of another nature, of another social stratum, and might have some incurable diseases. Minny, one of the maids, was fired for using guests bathroom. By and large, maids significantly affected the day-to-day well-being of the hosts of the houses. They knew how to cook tasty and diverse food, how to clean house, and, I'd like to draw your attention to that, they knew how to raise children. The last picture of the film shows us how much a kid got attached to the help. Unfortunately, white hosts could not put their pride aside in some situations and, regardless of how much their child loved Aibileen, the help, they fired her. What surprised me is that blacks were afraid to talk about their deprivations to anyone, they were threatened by being exposed and were inclined to keep all their lives secret from the general public. It was extremely complicated to Skeeter, the young journalist, to make them believe that her intentions are pure and she just wants to write a book about maid's lives. Luckily, Skeeter sought a way how to deal with the problem and finally established enough credibility with a number of maids and the book has been published. So, we could watch such an incredible film.

I found this movie really interessting about the black woman place in the sixties. It revolted me but it's important to take consciousness about this subject for that it doesn't happen again. The bravery of the woman at this period is well represented by the actresses. It's an era that we must don't forget. I reccomande this great movie ! Good viewing !

reviews.review_title: Enjoyable & Heart-warming at the same time. A Must-watch!
reviews.content: Beautiful, inspiring and heart-wrenching!The movie, based on the controversial best-selling novel by Kathryn Stockett, is enjoyable and heart-warming at the same time. The story shows how in the 60's, even though slavery wasn't there, "coloured" people didn't have much freedom, opportunities, etc. and how so much discrimination still existed.The screenplay could have been a little tighter and challenging, and the characters could have had a little more depth. But, all those shortcomings are overcome by the powerful acting and the interesting protagonists & antagonists. I don't want to point out any one particular actor's performance. The casting is just perfect and couldn't have been better.The last words Aibileen tells Hilly in the last scene of the movie, "You a Godless woman! Ain't you tired, Miss Hilly? Ain't you tired?" had the impact and feel the climax needed.A Must-watch!

reviews.review_title: Lovingly and thoughtfully told - a highly enjoyable story with a wry sense of humor
reviews.content: I did not read the book. That fact did not dull my appreciation for the craftsmanship and thoughtfulness that went into the movies. First of all, this movie basically had co-leads, Viola Davis as Abylene who narrates the beginning and end of the film and whose voice is heard from time to time bridging important moments in the film and Emma Stone (whose 3-for-3 with me thus far in her young but brilliant acting career) as well-meaning and ambitious Eugenia "Skeeter" Davis.This duality of, in essence, having one co-lead as the visual focus and the other as the aural focus, is one that I do not recall having seen before and it works exquisitely effectively here. Ms. Davis' acting was a revelation to me and seemed to come straight from the heart. Abylene's professionalism and perpetual struggle to keep God's love in the forefront and suppress her anger even after she had almost lost her will to live when her son was killed could not have been realized so beautifully and vividly by a lesser actress.The casting seems to deliberately pay homage to earlier films dealing with the segregation subject matter but all in this category were well cast an played their roles to perfection. Sissy Spacek (The Long Walk Home) was a total hoot as the villainess' (Bryce Dallas Howard - Ron Howards' daughter - excellent, chillingly malicious and self-righteous but not over-the-top) mother. Mary Steenbergen (Narrator of same film) was hilarious in a send up of a New York publisher. Cicely Tyson (Autobiography of Miss Jane Pitman) was brilliant as always (How I've missed her) as the maid that raised Skeeter but sent away by her Mom (Allison Janney) why Skeeter was at college. We learn later that she had been sent away by Society President Anna Higgenbotham played by Dana Ivey (who virtually enslaved Oprah Winfrey into being her maid in The Color Purple).The music, cars, and lush cinematography were all perfect from my perspective. A few minor points - the actor playing boyfriend Stuart seemed to lack timing and didn't really fit into the period costume he was wearing. The woman playing Jolene seemed not to understand that she was playing a nasty, not just a vapid, woman. But, these are very minor considerations.Overall, this is not quite a great movie - but is certainly an extremely good one and highly enjoyable.

reviews.review_title: The Book, The Help, Changed My Life
reviews.content:
I have a fondness of reading, rhetoric, words and how they flow. Some books just do not have that flow, to me. I read this book and absolutely fell in love with reading.I had always wanted to be a reader, but nothing held my attention. This book, far before the film, had my heart with every page.As I said, I hadn't been a big reader, but this one was one I couldn't wait to come back to each night after dinner and kids' baths done.
