It was my time to myself. Not only did Katryn Stockett's ability to write as she spoke, she inspired me to write, myself.I grew up in Alabama. So, the language was quite familiar. This book is gripping. It will make you laugh and make you cry. The characters lept from pages, into my heart and soul.Then the film came out, the story that Stockett's friend Tate directed it only adds to the unlikely blockbuster. She swung for the fences and hit a homer. Now, I am patiently awaiting her second book after all this time. Kathryn if by chance you read this, please gift us again with your gift of storytelling. IT IS WHO YOU ARE! And Grandaddy Stockett left you his gift. Don't keep it tucked away. I believe you have another amazing story to share with us if not many. Thank you for the gift of, "The Help."
You encouraged me to write.If you haven't seen this film, do yourself the favor and get the book first. There are many little details you will enjoy. This author tells the story as if you are sitting in the room listening. Oh how I cried at the end, (no spoilers) I was sad because didn't want it to end.

The Help was brilliant and fantastic. The nominations and awards for this movie and its cast are well deserved.I hate that a movie like this should or could be made. I watch in complete shock that a world like this could even exist...such idiocy and hatred. And yet, I have seen many movies similar to this before, and that doesn't diminish The Help's storyline or cast in anyway.As previously stated, the cast of The Help was wonderful in executing the storyline. The movie was written exceptionally with a fantastic storyline/plot. The movie kept me highly interested. Overall, a ugly and beautiful tale worth watching!

reviews.review_title: It's Good because it's Not Bad
reviews.content: Adapted from the book of the same name, The Help explores the relationship between African American domestic servants and their white employers in the southern part of the United States in the 1960s.I enjoyed both the book and the movie, and find the movie to be a reasonably good adaptation that hits each key moment without losing much content. The film is well executed with good acting, a certain artistic quality in set design and cinematography, and it is enjoyable to watch.While I enjoyed the movie, my rating reflects how I find little to complain about in The Help - conversely, I have a hard time finding good reasons to give it so high a rating. I guess you could say this movie is good because it makes a few mistakes, not because it is superb on its own merit.More could be said about the content of the film, and whether it accurately portrays its subject matter (considering that the book's author is caucasian, so her knowledge of the subject matter from an African American perspective is limited). However, that conversation is better suited to reviewing the book, which the movie accurately represents.

reviews.review_title: You is kind, You is smart, You is important.
reviews.content: You is kind. You is smart. You is important.So says black maid Abilene to Mae Mobley, the small daughter of her wealthy white employers. As the little girl repeats the words back her one can't help but wonder if Abilene has ever had them said to her. Living in a world where a black man inhabits the White House is difficult to imagine a time when the same man could be arrested for refusing to give up his seat on the bus for a white person.Set in Jacksonville, Mississippi in the 1960s this funny and poignant film, based the book by Kathryn Stockett, depicts a time, not so long ago, when a black maid couldn't use the same bathroom as her white employers, when black women raised white women's children but could not be trusted not to steal the silver and when telling the truth about your life as 'the help' was akin to signing your own death warrant.Into this world of prejudice and secrecy comes Eugenia 'Skeeter' Phelan a recent college graduate with dreams of becoming a journalist. Skeeter has returned home to find that her beloved maid Constantine, who raised her, has seemingly left to go and live with her family in another state. On top of being devastated and confused by this Skeeter is also trying to pave a career for herself in New York. To do so she must convince the editor that she is a good writer. With this mind she happens upon a radical and potentially dangerous idea; to tell the story of the black maids of Jacksonville, from their point of view, enlisting Abilene, and her best friend Minnie, maid to the cruel Hilly to help her.The three leads are perfectly cast. Viola Davis brings a quite sadness, tenderness and hidden strength to Abilene, Octavia Spencer perfectly portrays Minnie's brashness and loud mouth while also bringing out her caring side and vulnerability and Emma Stone shines as the bright and witty Skeeter, depicting perfectly her determination to change things and her confusion and sadness over the loss of her maid.There are so many outstanding performances among the supporting cast in this film it seems unfair to single anyone out. However credit must be given where it is due and there are three performances' which really stuck with me. Bryce Dallas Howard, who I also thought of as decent but nothing special, really shines in the role of Hilly, the ultimate society queen bee and an out and out racist to boot. You really find yourself disgusted with her actions and attitude. Also a stand-out is Jessica Chastain as Ceila, town out cast and apparent man eater whose Marilyn Monrone-like facade, and pretty rose bushes, hide a tragic secret.And while she has only three or four scenes, Cicely Tyson's scenes as Constantine, Skeeter's, much loved maid, are among the most touching and poignant in the film. Her final scene, in which we learn the true nature of her leaving the Phelan home, would break the hardest of hearts. Honourable mentions to Sissy Spacek as Hilly's slightly mad mother and Allison Janney as Skeeter's mother, a woman struggling with both a serious illness and her actions regarding Constantine.The score and cinematography are amazing but it is the performances that make this film. It is touching and warm, poignant and sad, funny and uplifting. It is also important as a commentary on the dangerous judging people based on physical appearance and deals well with it's serious subject matter, allow the message to come across clearly without being too depressing or hard hitting.All in all this is a must-see movie and one for the Oscars.

A truly wonderful film based in the pre-civil rights South. Impeccably filmed, written and acted. Features a stellar cast playing real, well-written characters and that imbues this narrative with passion, humor and generous dollops of Southern tear-inducing drama. Part "Driving Miss Daisy", part "The Color Purple" - this is possibly the best film of the year for me. Watch for the stage's first Miss Daisy, Dana Ivy in a cameo appearance very much like her role of Miss Millie, the mayor's wife ("Would you like to be my maid?", is her signature line in "The Color Purple". Here maids are still on her mind. The film is a great joy. And despite it all, I still crave chocolate pie.

Never heard of the novel of the same name before, but it's one I will look at. The Help is about Aibileen a hardworking housekeeper in 1960′s Mississipi, who with the help of local white writer Skeeter Phelan talks about her life as a black servant in a time of extreme racism.I really liked it. Some parts moving, some insightful, it's a beautiful looking (and sounding – the score is lush throughout) film cinematography to a beautifully serene score. It has the right combination of tear-jerking moments, pathos and humour. A tear in my eye was found.The female cast are amazing. Bryce Dallas Howard and Sissy Spacek especially, And check out Jessica Chastain who plays Celia Foote – she is BEAUTIFUL and going to be a star.

It's alright, but it's too verbose. Although it talks about how Americans are racially discriminated against, the purpose of the film does not seem to be how black people resist and fight for their rights, but that Americans will always be particularly noble. This film is to glorify racial discrimination, stepping on the pain of black people to promote the brilliance of the noble human nature of the United States, hypocrisy!

I guess the movie achieved what it aimed to achieve: to make me care about the subject, to make me upset, and to make me hate our American ancestors a little bit more. But hating is OK in this case, because it's a proof that I truly enjoyed this movie.The director takes us to Mississippi, around the time of the Mad Men. Although, in this case, it's all about their wives, their lifestyles and the silly habits they developed to look like they have a happy life and a perfect family. The reality though is that around the house, they owe everything to their black maids. A group of hard working and lovable African-Americans, who have to put up with humiliations and hardships on a daily basis, in the fear of losing their jobs. However, a glow of hope presents itself for these ladies: a young and courageous white author who was raised by one these maids decides to take action and sets to publish a book about their stories for the world to read. But will the maids overcome their fear to tell the world what they are going through, or will they carry on with their lives as if nothing was happening? Two of them find the bravery to talk, and that's how we get to discover the social differences of those years and the ridiculous contradictions from a time when no contact was wanted with black people, yet you allowed them to raise your own children! You didn't let them use your bathroom, yet you let them cook and touch your food, etcAll these elements of injustice are the perfect ingredients to make for a touching and often upsetting movie, but it does find ways to be amusing, and it's super entertaining from the word go. I honestly laughed more than I was angry. All in all, I thoroughly enjoyed it, and I am willing to say that i would have loved for the movie to last a little longer. Watch it. Do not hesitate a moment.

reviews.review_title: Superb bittersweet film about how human failings may be overcome
reviews.content: Although this film is set early in the nineteen sixties when race matters were at a nadir, it carries so much that is good about human nature and how we can all help to overcome absurd hatred of our fellow human beings. The film does not pull its punches preferring to hold our attention through profound and enlightened observation of the characters we find in Jackson, Mississippi. The central theme is one of black maids (the help) bringing up white children and it is in this context we see the kind of loyalty, love and affection we are not necessarily expecting.The film has pathos in abundance as we witness the hostility and contempt that is shown towards the maids by their white employers. But there are exceptions to the rule and it is through these we witness the building of bridges between adults as well as children. Built firmly upon drama and strong comedy too, the script keeps us totally immersed in the characters, whether we like them or loathe them. And the acting and direction is as good as it gets, regardless of who you want to talk about.Although it is a long film (two hours and twenty minutes) no shot is wasted and no loose ends left by the film's conclusion. But its greatest success is the chemistry between the characters which is so uncannily profound we can feel it, touch it, see it and hear it. It is so very close to eavesdropping on real events. Full marks to the casting crew then. And this is one of those films that allows you to make up your own mind about what you should think and feel, for whilst it observes very profoundly it does not try to condition. It simply places facts on the table of life and leaves the questions and answers for you to work on.Of its type it is the best film I have seen in a decade or more and I urge you to see it.Full marks because it warrants no less.

I wish we had more of these! The entire audience was both laughing and crying and often simultaneously. Beautifully shot, great Production Design and the costumes were outstanding, all of which complimented the Oscar level acting. Each character stood out in her own stance and journey in the world. Great Job Guys! Great Writing! Outstanding performances. I hope this sweeps the Oscars! I also commend the author for her persistence in this beautiful story which didn't have the good cop bad cop scenario nor the Driving Miss Daisy veil (great movie but been there done that) or the typical southern man portrayed as the evil, controlling antagonist. Instead there were women; flawed and beautiful, rigid and flowing, mothers and daughters, pure and false friendships. But most importantly a message of giving something to the world, lessons learned from those who suffered the worst of human darkness and having the courage to do so. Kudos to all involved in this beautiful work of art.

reviews.review_title: So boring, I want to SMASH my TV!
reviews.content: This movie is a disaster. If you need an honest advice: Don't think about watching it!It is 2 hours and 30 minutes long, feels like 6 hours and has literally nothing to offer. Boring story ehich a 10 minutes documentary video on YouTube would do better. Even more boring characters and the acting is also nothing special.I cannot understand why this movie is rated so high and got into the 250 list on IMDb, but it shows that making it in the list is nothing hard. Thang God this film only won one oscar, otherwise the TV would be broken by now.After watching two 3 hours long movies (The Sound of Music, 3 Idiots) this garbage felt linger than both together and offered nothing.Just don't watch it! Please!

reviews.review_title: One of the best titles of 2011
reviews.content: The Help is one of those rare movies about women and heavy social contents that is pleasant and delightful to watch even when it's not supposed to be. All the credits go to the ensemble cast that knew exactly what to do and gave the exactly tone that each character needed in a so amazing way that seems that the director wasn't important at all.Viola Davis, as Aibileen Clark, once again amazes us with a simple but dense performance about a strong woman with a fragile heart wounded by harsh times, prejudice and ignorance. The same can be said about Octavia Spencer, as Minny Jackson, making both of them a partnership so intense and perfect as Thelma & Louise.Brice Dallas Howard is very different from her previous works and an excellent choice for the role of Hilly Holbrook. Sometimes being tender and comprehensible, sometimes being the worst ignorant people that you could ever met. Her performance is a mix of great small and exaggerated doses, making you sometimes laugh but most of the time wishing the worst for her.Jessica Chastain, as Celia Foote, for sure is the most charismatic and funny character, but being funny doesn't mean that she's just there to relieve audience from the drama, but to show them the other side of it.Emma Stone is a great young actress, but her performance is too modern and for me it doesn't fit so well in the whole context of the time set. Maybe her performance had that clear purpose, as her character is young and ahead of her time, but seems a little dislocated anyway in a movie that cared so much about important details of that time.Even being a little bit long (Chris Columbus is one of the producers, so that could be imaginable), the movie has a huge importance to show people a part of the American history that explains a lot of our present. The racial problems in Mississipi state was just a fragment compared to other places and nations and the movie is also an emergency sign because the movie can be set in the 60's, but it's actually pretty current when we compare the progress and realize that most of what is shown still happening in a disguised way.The Helps isn't some ordinary 'dramedy' nor a chick flick as some people think. It never makes you feel fooled with a magical happy ending. It's sincere, fragile as the main characters are and a very important part not only for American history but human rights history.

reviews.review_title: A few small details after reading the book.
reviews.content: The couple were best sisters in high school, but Skeeter left for college and Hilly married and had children. So Skeeter had a high profile around Hilly in the beginning (Elizabeth gave up her seat while eating at the ice cream shop), and Hilly also worked hard to set up blind dates for her. When Skeeter was found reading banned books, she was warned privately, largely out of kindness.Tying straight hair after the mother is happy to say you can finally wear high heels: tying is too tall, this is one of the reasons she can not get married. In the movie, Constantine looks at the height recorded by Skeeter on the cupboard door year after year before leaving. Of course, Emma is not that tall.What Elizabeth doesn't like about her daughter: she thinks she needs to lose weight because she's too fat. The movie does have a fat little girl to play.Why Celia with another woman on the way of life:with Johnny unmarried pregnancy thing, not just because she is a bitter, from the deep south of the so-called white trash, itself not bred, what also don't understand, so can't type into local wife circles, in front of the black maid also lack superiority (" gone with the wind "with education of black slaves is disdain for the so-called" dirty white "). It shows in the movie, too: all she knows is boiled potatoes and tacos, and she has no problem killing chickens herself.

reviews.review_title: Who are we clapping for? .... We are clapping for you.
reviews.content: A life changing experience.There are few movies out there that are really trying to make a change, to change your point of view, to open your eyes... How amazing it is when you sit in the movie theater, expecting to watch a normal movie, well with an amazing cast, not knowing what it is about, and you just spend 2 hours stunned, moved, shocked, amazed, laughing, having every single emotion there is in just one movie. This movie is by far one of the best movies i have ever seen, i can't even describe the quantity of feelings i had watching it, yes, it is almost 2 and a half hours long, but, i didn't want it to end.I found myself moved, it really changed me, it has amazing performances, once aging Viola Davis had an amazing character, with an amazing story, and delivered an out of this world performance, as she always does.Emma Stone, wow. I have no words for this girl, she is stunning in every single meaning of the word. The rest of the cast, deliver amazing performances, every single second of this movie is absolutely well written, absolutely well directed, and absolutely well acted. It is so real.This is a movie, with a really original point of view, i have never ever seen a movie like this. It is a movie about love, about fighting for who you are, about defending your believes. I recommend this movie for EVERYBODY. This is a really true masterpiece, and i really believe everybody should see this, see that the "perfect world" we live in, was or, is, not perfect at all. Watch it.

reviews.review_title: The HELP and the Women Behind the Scenes
reviews.content: Based on the best seller by Kathryn Stockett and adapted and directed by her childhood friend Tate Taylor, The Help is a personal film that is affecting in its depiction of social injustice in the treatment of black females who served as nannies and maids in the Old South during the turbulent 1960's. As an ensemble piece, it features a host of memorable, Oscar caliber performances.A black female, Aibileen (Viola Davis), in Jackson, Mississippi, during the 1960's relates a story of life during that period where white families relied on black housekeepers to cook, clean and even raise their white children. These housekeepers in effect became second mothers to these children and did so for generations. Aibileen works in one such household, as does her combative friend, Minny (Octavia Spencer), who works for the stern Hilly (grandly played for nastiness by Bryce Dallas Howard). Fresh from college, Skeeter (Emma Stone) has a reunion of sorts with her old friends (including Hilly) from the community. Absent is the local outcast, Celia (Jessica Chastain), who is shunned by the group. Dreaming of being a writer, Skeeter has been curious about the life of these house servants and the injustices and humiliating treatment they must face that border on outright racism that has been passed down from family to family. Even as a child, Skeeter has fond memories of her own housekeeper Constantine (Cicely Tyson) who left one day under mysterious circumstances. Encouraged by her publisher, she decides to write a book based on the experiences of these servants. Under the fear of being discovered and fired (or worse), one by one these black women come forth to tell their stories. When civil rights activist, Medgar Evers, is murdered, it creates a firestorm of violence as these women risk everything to get the truth in print, and the results will forever alter their lives.As a chronicle of a lesser known civil rights issue and injustice, this film offers some interesting insights into a modern form discrimination. While most of the white community is portrayed as villains and almost caricatures, perhaps that's just the point: that such a backwards culture existed not that long ago. There are a number of subplots including the attempts to set up Skeeter on a blind date and Celia's awkward attempts hide her domestic inadequacies from her husband by hiring a maid. Then there is the fate of Skeeter's Constantine that is heartbreaking.As much as the acting is superior across the board, the film does not quite work as a whole as well as one would hope. The narrative seems a bit uneven so things don't flow smoothly from scene to scene. It's the only thing that keeps the film from being even better than it is. In a way the parts or scenes are better than the whole, and many of those scenes are quite good and authentic. Despite its serious subject, the film does have its humorous moments especially in the infamous confrontation between Minny and Hilly where justice is served! It is the highlight of the film.There are any number of performances that shine particularly Davis (a standout), Spencer, Howard, Chastain, and Stone. Even Sissy Spacek has a witty, offbeat role as an elderly mom at odds with her daughter Hilly. But it's the film's moments that will stay with you; they buoy The Help into our hearts.

"The Help" is many ways a paradox. It is both a feel-good movie while still being a bit of a downer. It is typical Oscar bait material but done in a very crowd-pleasing way. Characters are both absolutely despicable but others being the nicest people you'll ever meet. It is a movie with some of the biggest laughs and some of the biggest tear-jerking moments.The movie takes place in the south during the 1960's. It focuses on the hardships African American maids had to endure during the civil rights movement and southern racism.What is at the heart and soul of this story are the characters. Octavia Spencer rightfully won the Oscar for best supporting actress. She, along with all the cast, does a terrific job bringing in the emotions and feeling real.Helping with that sense of realism comes from the well written dialogue. Sometimes when a movie tries too hard to make these inspirational quotes it comes across as artificial, written by a committee as opposed to just a human having a conversation. But in this film, the combination of writing and acting work together to make things sing.If you are looking for a film to teach you about race, friendship, acting or writing: this film will really help.

reviews.review_title: If I could give it a zero rating, I would
reviews.content: So, we are to believe the writers know something about the Black perspective? Like "Fried Green Tomatoes" it's alright to take revenge on people by feeding them something vile and disgusting? I can't believe people really enjoy films like this or that they're even made in the first place.

If this film were total fiction bearing no relation to reality, it would still be worth seeing for the fine acting and production values--even if some of the young white women approached "Southern Gothic."But it wasn't fiction--at least, the depiction of Southern society wasn't. As I watched I kept drifting back to small-town South Carolina in the 1950s, where I grew up. It was moving and disturbing to be reminded how black people were treated then--loved and yet "kept down in their place." Our neighborhood was all middle-class and every family had a maid. There were plenty of boys my age, we visited in each other's homes, and called every maid by her first name. One even started a baseball team for the little white boys, for which her reward was a visit by the Klan.Our maid helped my mother cook and clean. One of my parents picked her up and took her home every day--and she rode in the back seat. She ate her lunch in our kitchen--without being allowed to use our utensils. I remember her eating with her fingers. I do not remember ever seeing her use our bathrooms. I thought about that during the movie and truly cannot recall what she did, an embarrassing gap in memory.I do remember when my father was out of work and our maid had to be cut back to three days a week. I actually cried; she was a member of our family. When talk about civil rights began in the late 1950s, my mother became annoyed at our maid for getting "uppity." And so it went. We moved to central Florida in 1961, where there were no maids.Travel back in time with this film. It's quite real, and I highly recommend it.

reviews.review_title: A movie from the point of view of the help a movie that deserves a nod at the Oscars! Title: THE HELP
reviews.content: Although Kathryn Stockett struggled with over 60 agents and had her novel rejected repeatedly the 2011 summer release THE HELP is been widely accepted even as you read this. Summer 2011 is not one of the best we have experienced in the lines of cinema. With just a handful of movies that would remain in our minds I consider THE HELP an exhilarating and heartwarming production that contains emotions and laughter from a time not too long ago. I have not clearly lived during the timelines the plot has been set. In fact the Civil rights movements and the efforts to create equality between color, race and religion is something I have just read during history lessons. To see it been brought to life at a time where racism and religious discrimination is frowned upon and where equality is boasted of is quite interesting. Especially to read the uprising debates the movie seems to have caused within some communities. If THE HELP is fact or fiction is irrelevant at this point. However the beauty and the depth the movie is revealed to me should not go unnoticed. There is an aura of near perfection that seems to hover around this title. The screenplay that has been adapted by the novel itself is said to be doing extreme justice to the original text the experts say. I have not read the novel. In fact I have not read the Harry Potter novels. However this does not stop me nor did it stop those who passed judgment on the HP franchise. The magical screenplay and direction that is done by Tate Taylor who is said to be a childhood friend of the author is key ingredient. Taylor's vision and heart is in the right place when he tries to extract the emotional lives of the black women of Jackson Mississippi. I have read many write ups about the racial atrocities that has taken place around the world. In fact I have seen with my own eyes the ethnic conflicts that stir up from some of them. THE HELP is just one of those stories that made it to the light! Viola Davis and Octavia Spencer clearly stood out with one of the best performances I have seen in recent times. They drew tears to my eyes. To be the help at the said time and to be in their situation is something that I am unable to even imagine myself in. Yet Spencer and Davis took me to 1960s Jackson. They showed me the pain and discrimination. They showed how much they gave up just making sure their children could have a better life (Although the outcome was not what they expected). The most important lesson I learnt by being in the year 2011 from the movie is that even with all the imaginable hardships of the world are upon them, they will not give up! Viola Davis and Octavia Spencer you ladies nailed it! There convincing performance was not too far away from Bryce Dallas Howard who places the other extreme end of the racial white house lady. Her ultimate goal of creating equality from within separation, Brilliant performance! Tate Taylor wanted her to come out as being mean insensitive and callous and Bryce Howard did Taylors expectations Justice. Between the help and the lords of the house there is a common ground. This is where Emma Stone comes in. I need to be honest; I was not a believer that Stone could pull through the perfect Skeeter. To my amazement she did. This Performance of Stone holds the Davis-Spencer Vs Howard battle in a balance. Aibileen Clark who has raised 17 white children is a black woman from Jackson Mississippi. She loves the children she raises just as if they were her own. In fact the children love the help more than they love their own mothers. This is only fair since the mothers of the time showed seem to have got their priorities pretty mixed up! Minny Jackson who works for the Holbrook house walks out one day after failing to tolerate the cruelty of the lady of the house. Jackson Journal writer Skeeter returns home after her graduation to find out that her maid Constantine who has raised all her life has been sent away by her mother. Skeeter who does not respond to this very well takes up to write the stories of black women and their emotional struggle for survival. However she is unable to find a volunteer who would share with her. THE HELP is a must watch drama and is indeed one of a kind. Guaranteed to have you balling out by the end of the movie and will make you look harder into yourself. A movie from the point of view of the help a movie that deserves a nod at the Oscars! Title: THE HELP Directed by: Tate Taylor Starring: Emma Stone, Viola Davis, Octavia Spencer and Bryce Dallas Howard Rated: PG13 for thematic material Rating: 09/10 146 Minutes

reviews.review_title: Worth seeing, especially if you have not read the book
reviews.content: Had I not just read the book, I would have loved this movie. It made me both laugh and cry. Octavia Spencer was the perfect choice for Minnie and Viola Davis nailed it as Abileen. Emma Stone, although very short to be playing Skeeter pulled it off so well I forgot how short she was except when next to her mother. The story line is such a good one that even with the changes they made it stood up well.As far as the changes. They were disappointing and really not necessary. What it ended up doing was sugar coating things that did not need to be sugar coated. We all know that in the South in the early 1960's not only was it illegal for anyone white or black to tell the truth of how unjustly blacks were treated, it was also very, very dangerous. By sugar coating that fact it takes away the impact of what a book such as The Help would have truly been.Having grown up in the South and being of the last generation of white children raised by wonderful black women I wish they would have left in more of what a real risk any person of color took going against the "rules". The people in real life that took part in bringing about a change were all heroes that do not get enough recognition for what they did for all of us.
The Help is progressive on the surface but is actually your standard white savior movie that reduces racism to a few bad apples and perpetuates the stereotype of black women as mammies.

I thoroughly enjoyed this movie. It's a nuanced depiction of a certain aspect of American racial segregation (domestic 'help' provided by black women to white families) on the journey into the civil rights movement.Unlike other films on this topic, this isn't a dark or unsettling movie. None of the characters meet a tragic demise. The Hell is moving, yes and doesn't shy away from realism, but it's produced in an upbeat, often very funny, style.In fact some of the scenes are laugh out loud funny. There's a brilliant, pivotal moment where the disturbing practice of getting black women to go outdoors when they need the toilet, is turned into a hilarious opportunity to humiliate a domineering white socialite.It was also nice to see a film in which all the lead actors and the main supporting actors were female. I thought they all played their parts perfectly, including a deserved Oscar-winning performance by Octavia Spencer.This is a great little gem of a movie that really surprised me.

reviews.review_title: Fine acting and a great story make this a recommended watch
reviews.content: Based on the best selling book of the same name by first time novelist Kathryn Stockett, we are transported back to a lightly fictionalized Mississippi circa 1960.This is a time when folks were either white or coloured, simplistically whites had the money, privilege and law on their side and used that power however they goddam pleased. Of course, rich white folk would need "Help" running their large houses and bringing up their children whilst they pursued more worthwhile pursuits, like Bridge and gossip.The story is fictional and focuses on a group of rich white ladies and their "negro" maids, Abileen (Viola Davis) and Minny (Octavia Spencer - Oscar winning for this role). To counterbalance the institutionalized and accepted racism clearly on view, we have Skeeter (Emma Stone), who whilst not totally convinced, is at least asking the question why everything is like it is. Skeeter acts as the modern audiences window into this strange and rapidly changing world.Skeeter is an aspiring reporter gently teasing out a story from the reluctant maids, in the hope of producing a book detailing what the "Help" really thinks of their life, work and those employing them. There are huge and life threatening risks for those involved in helping to write the book. Starvation, trumped up theft charges and worse, are all real possibilities in a world that Skeeter can never truly enter.Some employers look after their staff with respect and dignity over many years, treating them as family. However, seemingly the younger generation, do not. For many, the line between slave and employee is a fine one indeed, lives blighted or destroyed at the passing whim of a rich woman's choosing.Notable characters are Celia, ostracized and desperate to be accepted by the "in crowd" yet doomed to fail, Hilly (Howard), a vicious and small minded woman and the easily influenced Leefolt (O'Reilly). Skeeters mum (Janney) is a good woman but is tied to the past, despite her own humanity and intelligence desperately chafing at the conventions of the time.This is a film that has been embraced by book clubs, schools and history teachers and it is easy to see why. The acting is uniformly good, especially Davis and Spencer who bring a quiet dignity and respect their roles, acting as representatives for all those that had no voice at the time. Davis whose brief turn in "Doubt" with Meryl Streep, again proves her acting ability.Perhaps the most shocking realization is that this is not ancient history, such events are only fifty years ago. Separate bathrooms for "them coloreds", who may bring bring different diseases to the house and yet can be trusted with the families supposed prize possessions, their children.The film is uplifting, funny and poignant in parts although not as hard hitting as the book and does on occasion appear somewhat "airbrushed" to avoid offending current sensibilities. Whilst not a Hollywood ending, loose ends are tied better on the screen and justice seen to be done, the book exists in a more realistic shade of grey.There is much to enjoy and much to be ashamed of but overall this is film that deserves to be seen and discussed. We are never too far away from such events to take the freedoms, acceptance and tolerance that most of us enjoy, for granted.Summary A film that any audience can enjoy, serious, well intentioned albeit somewhat sanitised version of the book which in itself perhaps only scratches the surface of what life might have been like for those in service.Fine acting and a great story make this a recommended watchhttp://julesmoviereviews.blogspot.co.nz/

reviews.review_title: Chix Chat on Film review: The hired help in an anonymous revolt.
reviews.content: I was anxiously anticipating The Help my interest peaked after having seen the trailer for the first time. I was not at all disappointed. This film held me captivated for the entire running time, and I have to give credit to the amazing ensemble of actors and certainly to the director. The era was to say the least a very difficult period for people of color, but every time the story started to get racially heavy handed there would be a divergence to bring the focus back to the story at hand rather than the cruelties that Black Americans endured during the sixties. Kudos to director/screenplay writer Tate Taylor for bringing this adapted story to the big screen with thoughtfulness, sensitivity and class. Eugenia 'Skeeter' (Emma Stone) Phelan, Hilly Holbrook (Bryce Dallas Howard), Aibileen Clark(Viola Davis), and especially Minny Jackson (Octavia Spencer) had a synergy that at times had me sitting there with my mouth open, agasp at some of the things that came out of Hilly's mouth and satiated with Minny's actions. I had recently seen Ms. Spencer in the silly Dinner for Schmucks and she had me cracking up at her role as an animal psychic, but I had no idea at that time that she was such a great actress. The other lead females have been showcased in other films so their talent was known, but I must say that this is the first time I have ever seen Ms. Howard in a movie and I was thoroughly convinced that she was an absolute b!tch. Her performance was spot on, as were the performances of them all. The ladies made this film pop, but the story was only made richer with their male counterparts. I sat there watching as Preacher Green (David Oyelowo) spoke his 'Courage' sermon and I kept trying to figure out where I had recently seen him, and then it dawned on me that he was in Rise of the Planet of the Apes, I think the British accent in that film must have thrown me, I'm usually pretty good at recognizing an actor I had just seen barely a week prior. This was a much better look for Nelsan Ellis (Henry the Waiter) than what I see weekly on television, it would have been nice to have a little more insight into his story, after all he was also hired help. I was glad though to never lay eyes on Leroy. My mother lived through many of the injustices of the sixties first hand here in Texas, even though the story was based in Mississippi it was pretty much the same throughout the South. She was neither angry nor embittered at what we watched intently on screen, she was as entertained as I was. Great movie, green light.

reviews.review_title: Weird Hollywood movie trying to be feel good with all selfish horrible characters
reviews.content: Now this is an unpopular opinion and I'm sure I'll get downvoted to oblivion, but hear me out. Notwithstanding the "white saviour complex" which has some merit, even though a story should be left to be a story, even the "good" characters are horrible. Bryce Dallas Howard plays a one-sidedly bad woman, and now she's even recommending people don't watch the film to educate themselves on black history (although I don't see her donating her movie film cheque to any black causes). But the treatment she receives (one gross incident in particular) is still wrong - but Hollywood is always happy to sink to the lowest common denominator for humour against the "baddies". And stupidly this makes the films two main African American characters, Minnie and Abileen the long suffering and loyal maids look bad also. Viola Davis and Octavia Spencer Are very good however even with this, and the only redeeming thing about the movie. Emma Stone is absolutely insufferable also. Both the black and white characters and lifestyle are stereotyped and unsurprising.The film goes for a big meaningful ending, leaving some things open but it honestly is flatter than the earth. Film is also too long - very indulgent. And I know it got various film nominations and I love action movies, but we know how Hollywood is - it loves melodramatic movies about various minorities it perceives as persecuted by our horrible grandparents, but Only if they're written and directed by white guys.

I grew up in Alabama and was in my early 20s at the time of this story. I can understand some of the criticism from Black Female writers when they talk about the extension of "Mammie" stories, and, not exposing the real horror and violence of the period. But, most of us in that era were shielded from the bad. But we did experience the everyday life of the love and life of our "maid". The real fiction is that no one had the courage to write the novel at that time, instead of 50 years later. The movie was true to the book. It is just wonderful to see a movie that exposes history and teaches us lessons in life, with humor, sadness, great dialog, and no sex nor violence.

This movie is good but not great. reviews.review_title: My memories of this time in our history
reviews.content: I think the strength and measure of this movie is not in how closely it followed the book, or whether the characters were one-dimensional or fully developed, but rather in what memories it evoked in the viewer. I was a college freshman in 1963, so I well remember and was reminded of the unfairness of that time. I particularly remember a heated discussion I got into with a Sunday School teacher. I don't remember how it began, but it devolved into her saying to me, among other things, "Well, you wouldn't a colored person to spend the night in your home! And surely you wouldn't want to eat a meal in their house!" I thought this was just plain stupid, and said so. In fact, the maid who worked for us had spent several nights in our home when my mother was at the hospital with my grandmother. And she cooked my meals at our house, and I truly couldn't see the difference in that and eating at her house. By the time I met up with Mother for church, word had already reached her of my disrespect to the SS teacher. She just looked at me and said, "MUST you do things like that?" But she never told me not to. I think she was torn between agreeing with me and not wanting me to be disrespectful of my elders.Incidentally, I was informed that one referred to "coloreds" as "women," not "ladies." I asked why, and was informed that that was just the way it was. Once again, I replied with, "Stupid!" I also remembered the water fountains in the local Montgomery Ward. The shiny, new, water cooler had a sign above it that said, "Whites," while the old, stained, chipped water fountain (not cooler!) had a sign that said, "Coloreds." How reprehensible! I did not know from those days that some whites did not want or allow their maids to use the toilets in their homes. So I actually learned something from the movie.When I saw this movie today, sitting on the row behind me were 3 black ladies who were about the age to have been maids during the '60s. I felt such shame, wondering what painful experiences they must have been remembering.I would have liked to have seen more comments in these reviews about people's personal reactions and memories, and less synopsizing of the story.This is one movie I will look forward to purchasing when it becomes available on DVD.

'The Help' is definitely one of the top films of 2011, a triumph in a year where so many films have been awful.The acting is the strong-point, actresses like Jessica Chastain, Bryce Dallas Howard, Emma Stone, Viola Davis and Octavia Spencer have all excelled themselves in this film. Stone's performance starts off pretty weak but gets better and better as the film continues. Octavia Spencer definitely deserved her Oscar but Viola Davis' performance should have been awarded too. Jessica Chastain's character is simply delightful, she plays this nervous, giggly person very well and I can't wait to see more of her acting in the future. My favourite performance in this film was Sissy Spacek however, despite her role being very small, she was just hilarious.The script was pretty good, I never got the chance to read the book but as a film I would say it's good. There are some real laugh-out-loud moments and there are also some scenes which could make you cry. Sometimes it can feel as if the characters are being portrayed very simply.Overall, I would recommend this film. It's pretty good and didn't get the amount of hype it deserved, particularly during the awards season. I wouldn't describe it as a feel-good film because of its topic but it discusses the issue very well but provides a lot of comedy too.

reviews.review_title: Should be required viewing for everyone in America
reviews.content: The Help is an incredibly important and impactful film that should be a required viewing for everyone in America. It has an incredibly compelling plot with phenomenal acting and direction. The value of a different perspective is priceless, and we could all stand to benefit by being kinder and more understanding.

reviews.review_title: A movie packed with powerful performances by women
reviews.content: I am no critic to read the book and then watch the movie and list out the discrepancies. I do read a book if i enjoy the movie, if i felt something was out of place and could have been better in the original form.As for The Help, i don't have to read the book to understand the plight of colored people in the most bigoted state in US. It's a movie that has all the center characters play a pivotal role and it's hard to draw a line between lead actress and supporting actress. And everyone has played their part exceptionally well.Octavia Spencer is the one that impressed me with her "sassy-mouthing"; Viola Davis with her bereavement and a will to survive without a son despite the prejudice; Bryce Howard for her Holier-than-thou attitude and if one asked me if the character Skeeter was in some way impressive, i would say "Nay!". Everyone else seemed to fit the role except for Emma Stone.The movie is powerful in the way it brings out a overtly denied truth of discrimination, set in the time when the movement culminated. Minny Jackson provides the much needed humor with her "sassy-mouthing" and Octavia Spencer totally deserved the Oscar.And now it's time to do justice to the literature; to read the book the movie was based on.

reviews.review_title: Shallow Treatment of a Complex Subject with Strong Performances
reviews.content: I haven't read the best selling book the movie The Help is based on. Nor have I paid much attention to the controversy about a White central character telling the story of black maids in Jackson, Mississippi. I can only judge the movie by what appears on screen. You get the sense the audience is being manipulated. This is where you're supposed to laugh; this is where you should cry. It feels like a paint by numbers movie lesson about the ills of racism that comes across as a bit shallow and sunny despite the subject matter. There is a moment in the film where you see a newspaper headline about the Freedom Riders who were pioneers in the civil rights movement. If you've seen the powerful and unforgettable PBS documentary about these real life heroes, The Help will come across as a flimsy and pale attempt at depicting a complex and disturbing issue that still reverberates today. What the movie does have going for it are the strong performances of the mainly female cast. Emma Stone is earnest and full of luminous spunk as Skeeter Phelan the author of these women's tales. Viola Davis is understated and deeply touching as Aibileen, the first maid to open up to Skeeter about what it's like to serve in a White household. Octavia Spencer in a standout role as Minny Jackson is funny and fierce as the maid abused by both her husband and employer Hilly Holbrook. Bryce Dallas Howard as Hilly conveys the essence of a cold heart wrapped in femininity to perfection. Jessica Chastain takes her character, Celia Foote the girl from the wrong side of the tracks and imbues her desire to be accepted with both sweetness and pain. Cicely Tyson is unforgettably moving in her flashback scenes as Constantine the Phelan family's lifelong maid and Skeeter's surrogate mother.The Help is designed to be a crowd pleaser that leaves the audience saying can you believe how these people used to behave in the South and that's the problem because segregation and discrimination were not only problems confined to the South. And, although we've come a long way since 1963, I couldn't fail to note that many in the audience where I watched the film have Black nannies raising their children. The movie is just a little too satisfied with itself and I don't think we're ready to be patting ourselves on the back just yet.

reviews.review_title: Very warming , comedic and gives a lot of lessons for the only animals on planet which are the racists!
reviews.content: A lot of movies talked about racism and it all contained that much violence and blood and agony while this movie simply says it all at a more difficult part than physically but psychologically living in racism. The story was pretty good and the cast was absolutely tremendous with their excellent performances. The only weak part and problem was that Emma's lead role wasn't as good as the others even you can feel it is an easy character to play with very little details about her all the movie was filled with ordinary details of her that was repeated. The rhythm was slow but towards the end everything want very funny and warming that was just beautiful. A very good movie with a lot of emotions and a not to miss one.

Let me first say that my normal type of movie involves lots of tits, guns, and explosions. I went to an early screener of this movie with my sister because she got the tickets from her Junior League and I'm always down for a free movie. I did not expect much more than a nice dark place to nap. Boy was I wrong. This film was absolutely great. I was honestly enticed from the very beginning to the very end. It has a perfect balance of comedy and emotion which at no point is heavy handed. I would recommend this movie to absolutely anyone, and am confident that everyone will enjoy it.

This is the first time in my life I have ever liked the movie version better than the book. I finished the book the night before seeing the movie. The book left a lot of unanswered story lines, and it also left Hilly on top, with no one really telling her what a piece of trash she really is. The film does an excellent job of incorporating a majority of the book, while adding two scenes where Hilly finally has someone tell her what an a$$hole she really is. I rank the movie a 9 out of 10 because it really is almost perfect. It has Emma Stone as Skeeter trying to break out as a writer by tackling the hot button topic of segregation from the view point of the help. Both supporting characters-Viola Davis and Octavia Spencer-carry the wisdom and truly make you question how racist morons in the south as high up as the governor were able to reign supreme for so long. Skeeter's mother-Allison Janney-lit up the screen. She is the souther belle that has also been dealt a pretty harsh case of cancer that has left her losing her hair and her speed, but she still pushes for the best for her little girl, and in the end proves to be proud of her daughter for being such a courageous writer and human being. Now we have Hilly Holbrook-Bryce Dallas Howard-the villain of the film. I LOVED her in this role. The very sight of her on screen turned my stomach every time. She is a self proclaimed Christian southern belle, but is in reality an ignorant racist that enjoys controlling all her friends and pretty much everything in her life and everyone else's life. She enjoys treating the help terribly, it appears to genuinely make her happy. This is where the book failed terribly. The book had Hilly come out on top, with no one ever really giving it to her. The movie is redeeming, and I cried numerous times throughout. I see numerous Oscar nominations in its future.

"Steel Magnolias" without the syrup? It's better than that, but it looks like that. Too many pretty people, too many scenes with heavy-handed and romanticized art direction, a bit sugary at times, but how can you complain when the acting is terrific and the story is so compelling? For the first time in a major film, the focus is on how white women treated black women during the era of Jim Crow. Rather than another harrowing portrayal of the horrors of racism involving white men treating black men badly, very badly, we see something that is every bit as disturbing. White women, many of them, degrading and demeaning black women, many of them, in so many small and cruel ways that it makes you ashamed. Much of it is painful to watch, and it's mostly done with soul-killing looks and words, very ugly words. All of the insults, dirty looks, callous remarks...it's a shocking reminder about the banality of evil. Amazing performances. Hope it's shown in every high school in America.

Just finished watching this. Wow.........You might have already read the official storyline, yes, thats exactly it, a young white girl writing the story of the oppressed negro women.The white girl is Emma Stone (Easy A). With her Japanese cartoon like large eyes and exaggerated expressions is a sweetheart to watch.Viola Davis is the first of the black women who agree to tell her story. She is just simply brilliant. We can literally feel her pain in her eyes. This is the first time I am seeing her and she just blows you away with her acting! Jessica Chastain is the main villain in the story, a quirky narcissistic character, who almost sees a black person as an animal from some other species - fantastic performance.This film reminded me of the Gandhi movie. Its that moving. And I was left wondering, why do we have so much conflict in this world. Its just like in those mid 1900s as portrayed in the movie. Aren't we just being silly? Is so simple to be loving and accommodating. Instead we live a life of constant tension and conflict! Its so very very sad.........Go see it and have a beautiful time. :-)..............Cheers!

reviews.review_title: A beautiful story very well told!
reviews.content: OK, so I am not a regular film critic, but having just seen this beautiful movie and then ten told it had had some negative reviews I decided to have my say.Firstly I will say that I had not read the book.The acting in this film was all very well placed. The story was very well told and the director and the producers all had a very balanced vision for the story to be told.I thoroughly enjoyed every minute of the film, and found it to be very humane. If you like films that tell a story giving you perspectives of all the players in the film then this is definitely one to watch.The color and lighting, the staging and the wonderful cars of the early 60's all 'help' to set the scene for this period.It's funny, touching, sad and a little informative.If you like films like The Rosa Parks Story, The Secret Life of Bees, and The Colour Purple then this is a film you will enjoy. Well done to all involved with 'The Help"

reviews.review_title: Pulled short on any real content or poignancy
reviews.content: Mmm. Oscars buzz is in the air like the smell of fresh baked pecan pie! First slice is The Help, a sort of alternative history of Jackson, Mississippi in the turbulent civil rights era.The Help has three main heroes: plucky Skeeter Phelan, serious Aibileen Clark, and feisty Minny Jackson. Skeeter returns to Jackson with the goal of being a writer. The story that interests her the most is that of The Help (ding!). She attempts to get Aibileen to divulge tales of running the households of white women, but Aibileen fears for her safety and refuses. However, circumstances surrounding the mistreatment of her friends leads Aibileen to begin spilling the beans. Other maids soon join in and BAM - best seller!At first glance this film is everything it attempts to be: a story touching on the racism of the day, a heartwarming plot driven by strong characters, and a bit of good fun in the process. However, I felt that the characters played as mere stereotypes, and the true feeling of the era was softened either by nostalgia on the part of the author, or intentionally as a means of selling a feel-good story.Each character's role, while well defined, never allows for any real change. Skeeter didn't ever have to build up courage to write The Help; she simply took some screen time convincing everybody else to get on board. It didn't change her already super-modern, open-minded viewpoint, and it didn't make her a champion of civil rights. She sold her story, reaped the benefits (with surprisingly few downsides), and moved on. Aibileen stayed the strong central figure behind the idea of getting African American maid's stories heard, but didn't stray from that serious face she wore so well. There were a few moments of laughter, lightness, but she took little convincing to put herself in harm's way and in the end, payed a very mild price for her revolt against the white system that controlled her life. Minny Jackson – comic relief. Hilly Holbrook – the racist villain. Celia Foote – silly woman too simple to understand racism. Obviously a drama such as this will have some stereotypes, but it went all the way to the top.Hilly Holbrook seems to be the only real racist in the picture. She's young, angry, and determined to keep those sub-human colored people out of her bathroom, but not from handling every other part of her life. The movie portrays every other young elite woman as just following in step, not really concerned with race, but more with being socially accepted. Add to that every male and person over the age of 40 seems perfectly well balanced in their views on race. I'm not asking the movie to be a venom-filled, dark affair, but I think it paints Jackson in an untruthful light. I'm from the South, so is Queer. I know racists and they don't delicately prance around the issue today, and I'll put good money up that they didn't back in the '60s. Every bit on Kathryn Stockett talks about her upbringing in Jackson and her relationship with the African-American who raised her through the 1970s and in to the '80s. New York Times admits she pulls her punches on attacking the racism she witnessed, although they spin it as her being more "interested in the affection and intimacy buried beneath even the most seemingly impersonal household connections." I didn't get that from this 2 hour 20 minute film, but maybe the book covered the "affection and intimacy" in more detail.With all its problems – minor plot lines wrapped up with a cheap line, a complete lack of any character growth – it wasn't a bad film. It was heavy-handed (Oh look, a copy of To Kill a Mockingbird!), but it had some charm, entertainment value, and the southern accents didn't irk me nearly as much as I had expected. I do feel that my criticism is warranted. If you're going to tackle an issue like racism in the heart of the most racist parts of the country, you've got to commit. The Help simply lacked courage.Maybe I wanted the civil rights version of Inglorious Basterds, but this fictional history pulled short on any real content or poignancy.

reviews.review_title: Powerful stuff but I needed subtitles.
reviews.content: Change begins with a whisperStarring Emma Stone, Viola Davis and Octavia SpencerScreenplay by Tate Taylor.Novel by Kathryn StockettDirected by Tate TaylorBased on the bestselling book by Kathryn Stockett, this movie is powerfully evocative and really makes you think. It's not a fun movie, it's quite disturbing and pulls at your heart strings. The acting is top class all the way through and the attention to detail is superb. We are transported back in time and there's no way back until the final credit.Having said all that I found it a little bit boring. For all the emotional impact, I like my movies to excite me in some way. And this didn't to be honest. For me it lacked a little bit of something to keep me hooked, to keep me on the edge of my seat. And there was one extra problem. I really needed subtitles. I couldn't understand half of what was being said. When you can't hear or understand every other line that's being spoken it doesn't help!But I'm in the UK and that southern drawl ( or whatever it's called) was pretty hard to follow!7.5/10 Mainly for the acting and the attention to detail.
As entertaining as it is educational, thought-provoking, and heart-wrenching. The Help is a must see for everyone - regardless of your age, gender, or race.
This Movie was great and amazing I really did enjoy it one my favorites.

One can't help but cheer for maids everywhere. This wonderfully adapted screenplay is leaving audiences everywhere with a heavy heart and a clean mind, spotless actually. Director and Screenwriter Taylor Tate transfers the reality and accuracy of the book, The Help, exceptionally and also maintains emotional congruency that leaves this movie masterful. The quality of actors and the acting in this picture supersedes every conceivable disappointment. During the somewhat clichéd version of a 1960's setting, that leaves something to be desired, an upper class white woman, Emma Stone, writes a tell all novel of black maids and their point of views of working for white families. Emma Stone as Skeeter Phelan is exactly what every audience needs, a good old fashioned beating heart, underneath a beautiful complexion. The believable love portrayed by Viola Davis, as Aibileen Clark, is remarkable and one can't help but feel for the black maids who dedicate their lives to serving these families. Along with beautifully exercising the relationships surrounding Jackson, Mississippi, The Help provides comical arousal. The "Terrible Awful" is probably one of the funniest practical jokes ever portrayed in a film of this nature. The comedic timing is just like a perfect slice of chocolate pie. It would be impossible to purchase what this movie provides, which is the raw emotional passion that you can only find with "The Help."

reviews.review_title: Get your scraggy ass off my porch
reviews.content: Awesome movie!!! Made me sooo angry and embarrassed. Fantastic characters. Loved the outcast belle and her husband. Shouted so much at the telly. It lost a point for the ending which I thought was pretty weak and bland. Could have been tied up so much neater. It was long but didn't feel it. So happy I watched it.

reviews.review_title: During segregation, some black women protest, by getting help from a white reporter, and writing a book called, "The Help".
reviews.content: It was an okay movie. The Help certainly has a point on how bad it was in the time of segregation. However, I think that The Help could have used some changes however. The movie could have used less cuss words. They also showed a little to much cruel treatment against some of the people. Speaking against what I just wrote it was fine. I still think they could have showed less bad stuff. It was good because it showed that we should do what is needed when something is going wrong, and needs to be changed. It also shows us how we should remember how segregation is wrong. In the end of this, The Help has a point. A very good point.

This movie is one that chronicles intimate relationships between children and maids. These children were raised by maids and developed a sense of right and wrong in a time where these loving replacement mothers were nothing more than servants. It's a story about a young woman raised by such a loving woman who goes against the grain to do what is right in an attempt to change the status quo. It's an act that is dangerous to all involved. There is some historical information as well as lots of laughs and some tears. This movie is deep, complex and has the ability to evoke emotion across the spectrum. We need more uplifting movies like this. I say a hearty THANK YOU to Kathryn Stockette for having the courage to write this book on which the movie was based. Well done!

Review: This movie was absolutely terrific. I have to admit I went to this movie thinking it was going to be boring. Boy was I wrong, It blew me away. I cried, I laughed, I had a great time just listening to the many stories of the black maids, it was incredible. Emma Stone, Viola Davis, and Octavia Spencer really made this movie fun to watch. Now if you have read the book i'm sure this movie was a lot better. I did not read the book but the person with me had and she said it made it ten times better. Storyline: This movie is about Skeeter an aspiring young writer who wants to write a book from the maids perspective. Of course this is back in a time when maids were black and Martin Luther King Jr was fighting for the racial peace. She talks Aibileen Clark her friends maid to talking to her. Little did she realize the publisher's in New York would need at least 15 maids stories in her book. It takes a long time but she gets that many maids and her book is published. This Movie really gives you a glimpse into the past to see what it was like, believe me it makes you sick to think that people were treated that way.Overall it was a great story that I think you should see. I wouldn't recommend this for younger children. 8 out of 10 stars.

reviews.review_title: This feels so real - like it was in the Louisiana in the 50s
reviews.content: I don't think this has a spoiler but be warned, it does mention a couple of plot points in the story. Knowing about them will not ruin it in any way for you but stop reading if you want to see this without any preview.This is the best movie I have seen in quite some time. It will make you cry and it will make you laugh. It goes in my top 100 list. It claims to be set in the early 60s but and, just maybe, Mississippi might have been 5-10 years behind. This is the way it was in the 50s in Louisiana.We were not rich but had an African American maid who was accused of stealing after being with us for some time. I really loved Annie Mae but one day she was gone. I don't know if she stole something or not. I was too young but well remember the devastation of her departure to my young life. Expect that to come up in this movie.The movie is really full. It never lags a bit. You are involved and have to watch to keep all the characters straight. There are shenanigans going on and some are supposed which are not going on and it is a bit confusing if you are on the computer or otherwise diverted from really watching. And for that attention, you get a full story with multiple plot lines going on at the same time but without the choppiness that frequently comes with multiple plots. It is all woven together and feels so natural and flowing that I did not even think about it until I was writing this.This is a must see for those who lived in that time and for those who would like to understand a bit more about how it was and never should have been. It is not over the top in any respect. The abuse leveled on the maids is just the right amount for the story and not overdone, either. They could have gone farther but it would have not been right and would have ruined the story. I am not saying it was right for them to be abused this way, but, sadly, it was accurate for the time of this story. It hit home with me and I highly recommend it. It is a well crafted, full story that will leave you feeling that you have not wasted your time, not even a second in watching it as you watch the evolution of lives on both sides of the "color fence".

reviews.review_title: You is kind, you is smart,you is important.
reviews.content: A beautiful movie with so many moral messages. Talks about the racial discrimination (black and white people) , the social status and the love in every kind of relationship(friends, strangers, family,lovers). Unique characters and main roles make us feel sad, angry ,happy , get touchy with their lifes and sometimes incidents make everyone laugh too.An excellent movie for everyone, regardless of age. Worth to watch it.

reviews.review_title: sorry to break it to everyone
reviews.content: I watched this film without any presumptions as to what it would show me. And have no prior knowledge of the text. So after watching The Help i thought i'd go and do some research, naturally the first thing that pops up is IMDb and i am genuinely shocked that everyone is so gushing about what to me was at times mere dross and at others actually insulting. But mostly quite sad.If i was to rent starship troopers then it would be fair for me to assume that depth, pathos and any kind of layered motivation wouldn't be on the menu. yet when you watch a film set at one of the most volatile and important eras of the last 500 years and it basically is a Rom-com by numbers except black people are the shy guy who gets the hot girl in the end and the 'mean-girl-who-doesn't-get-her-way' is the symbol of indolent white middle-class racist. I expected better, clearly i'm looking in the Wong place and i apologise i will stick to books in the future. "i loves me some fried chicken" - "you can have a job here for life" oh really thanks.

reviews.review_title: Couldn't Quite Capture the Nuances of the book
reviews.content: Well, I loved the book. I liked the movie, but it's tough to adapt a book that has multiple narrators into a compelling two hour movie, esp. A story with such sensitive issues as race and civil rights. The movie felt like an overview at times of story points that felt deeper in the book. Performances were great and I still enjoyed it, but I was hoping for something epic.

And Miss Skeeter remembers what Constantin told her. Her mother did not choose her life, it picked her. But you, you're gonna do something big with yours. You wait and see."
