reviews.review_title: If you've seen Driving Miss Daisy, you've seen this movie
reviews.content: This movie, much like most of the movies about Jim Crow is about the white woman, not "The Help". This movie is more of a cautionary tale for wealthy white woman that do not take care of their own children, than a real revelation about black maids in the south during Jim Crow. What's the revelation here? Black maids had a life outside of their jobs? What can I say I rolled my eyes ever since I heard the subject matter. I have rolled my eyes at least 15 times since the movie started. You know what gets me? When people start reviewing movies about this subject-matter they say they don't want to talk about it, just the film itself. What a punk, talk about it. Let me see you and hear your opinion.

Located in Mississippi during the 1960s, Skeeter (Stone) is a girl from Southern society who returns from college determined to become a writer, but turns the lives of her friends - and a Mississippi city - upside down when she decides interview black women who have spent their lives caring for prominent southern families. Aibileen (Davis), the governess of Skeeter's best friend, is the first to open up - much to the dismay of her friends in the cohesive black community. Although Skeeter's longstanding friendships are at stake, she and Aibileen continue their collaboration and soon more women come to tell their stories - and in the end, they have a lot to say. Along the way, improbable friendships are formed and a new brotherhood emerges, but not before everyone in the city has a thing or two to say when they become unwittingly - and against their will - caught up in the changing times.

1. This movie called the help is set in a White House hold in the town of Jackson, in the Mississippi during The Civil Rights Movement in 1963. Starring Jessica Chastain in the role of Cecilia, Viola Davis as Aibileen Clark, Cicelely Tyson as Constantine Jefferson, Bryce Dallas Howard as Hillary, Allison Janney in the role of Charlotte, Octavia Spencer as Minerva "Minny" and Emma Stone as Eugenia "Skeeter". The story is centered around the character of Skeeter, a white recently graduated woman that came back to her parents house. She rediscovers the racist discrimination very present there and while talking to her friends and entourage, decides to write a book, or at least an article explaining the lives of the « help » . Which was the term used in these times to describe the black domestic workers. She interviews two maids, Aibileen Clark and Minny Jackson which both struggled through their work.2. In this movie only black women are maids, also they all clean and take care of the children. They are considered inferior by their employers. There is even the story of the separate bathrooms, one outside for the help. We can say that they aren't even considered human. I talk about this as a gender stereotypes because it is clear that black women are treated even worse than the men. In these times men were authorized bigger influence on women than today. And we clearly see that through Minni who can't leave her violent husband because she never knew if she would loose her job also her pay was insuficient. I would like to add that violent boyfriends and dependent relationships are still present nowadays.As we saw in class, all of Skeeter's friend are housewives, under the authority of their husband, or single but pressured to get married. Skeeter herself is under such a pressure by her entourage. Also her studies and future job aren't perceived well at all. During the entire movie we see mostly women, the men, husband only come back at night, when their shifts are over. Of course even in the middle class white women's class, the husbands have the highest authority and the wives are only underlings. Except the mother of the protagonist, most of the stay at home women are depicted air headed and are ridiculed by their behaviors.The fact that all the women were dresses and all the man were pants fits my expectations of this period of time. Also a bit out but not completely of what we study, I noticed that there is no transgender people. No other relationship than heterosexual exclusive (for the women, that is, I don't doubt that husbands kept their vows), and that is part of the proves that we were during a masculinity crises. Men needed to feel a sense of superiority on 'their' women so they used the excuse of exclusivity and mariage to keep women entangled to them as if they were mere puppets.3. If I were to have to recommend this movie, I think I would make it clear that the film is only the version of the story of a white protagonist when the title of the movie and the book is the help. You would therefor expect a movie where the main protagonist isn't a middle class white person. Though I do appreciate the fact that it wasn't, at the very least a man, I can't seem to understand why all this must be perceived through the gaze of someone that isn't relevant. On this point I would therefor say that the story isn't very thoughtful.Morever I was outraged to discover that the movie comes from a book which was written by a white woman. The fact that she's white doesn't really matter since she's written it from the point of view of someone like her but I was curious so I looked up Kathryn Stockett. Apparently she has written her book from her personal life and that of a maid of her brother's, Ablene Cooper. Hum, that kind of shocked me, she even used her name. And from the looks of it she didn't really ask her permission since the one in question filled in a lawsuit against this fabulous author.Now I'll finish with a final point, I truly dislike the husband of Minny's second employer. He makes himself seem as a 'good' guy when he accepts that Minny works for them. But actually he knew that his woman was hiding this fact from him and didn't talk to her about it when he found out. He appears as an understanding and open character without racists thoughts or sexist believes but he's just like the other husbands. He's keeping his wife at home and treating her like someone stupid, that is, when he talks to Minny he clearly states that her that.And I'll stop beause I've been criticizing this movie for a while now.

This movie is true to the spirit of the book which is very important to me. Yet the film also brought to life characters and places that I could not clearly envision until I saw the film. This is one of those rare times when I prefer the film over the book. The script captures the danger of what the women are doing. Even though I knew what would happen, I still felt anxiety as I wondered what the fallout would be if they,and their "illegal" activities, were discovered. This is a history lesson without being preachy. A film that reveals the history of women that historians in the 60's did not think were important. As for the acting, many of the other reviewers have mentioned standout performances. Viola Davis and Octavia L. Spencer deserve Oscar nominations for their portrayals as "the help". Cicely Tyson's powerful portrayal of Constantine was truly a standout- she broke my heart. Jessica Chastain's characterization of the "poor white trash" woman who is shunned by the women of the town was luminous. Bryce Dallas Howard does a glorious job of presenting woman driven by ambition to do whatever it takes to hold on to her power and status. Finally, the costumes and setting were really well done. I was transported me to a time and place I had not visited in a long, long time. Kudos to all who had anything to do with the making of this film.

reviews.review_title: A great ensemble cast, great story
reviews.content: I loved this story and looked forward to seeing the movie. Emma Stone is great as Skeeter Phelan, a young twenty-ish woman living in Jackson, Mississippi at the cusp of the civil rights movement. She is a graduate of Ole Miss and wants to be write professionally. She is surrounded by her Junior League friends, who all "work" on Junior League activities. Their days are all spent playing bridge and supervising their maids. The Junior League is run by Hilly Holbrook. Hilly is very conservative and aware of staying within her own race. She speaks with her looks and tells the other friends in her circle how to handle "The Help". Skeeter wants to write a book from the point of view of the various maids, both bad and good in book form. This poses a problem for all of them, considering it is a huge risk. Abilene is the first maid to tell her story, Minny Jackson soon follows. Once events unfold, many other maids join their group and tell all about working in Jackson during the early 1960s. Once the book is published, all women of both races are reading the book. They are trying to see what the fuss is about and identify townspeople within each story. Minny Jackson puts a particular story as an insurance policy, so that Hilly will say it is not Jackson. This story is truly odd, funny and shocking. Skeeter finds her way out of Jackson into a life she feels is best for her. Abilene, Minny and the other maids all deal with the aftermath of what happens in the book's publication. Some small stuff may be in the movie or book but not enough to change the story. Those who know me also know how I follow the differences and have hated stories, when the movie cast is not connecting the same way I pictured it.

reviews.review_title: Tries to do too many things
reviews.content: The Help could have been so much more than the confused, contrived mess that it ended up being.With whom are we supposed to connect? Should we care about the poor old maid, so brutally dismissed for inviting her daughter to visit? I certainly didn't.Or the disillusioned writer, who eventually connected with a male friend, the result of which was neither here nor there? I certainly didn't.The maid, who supposedly defecated in a pie that tasted so good it was worthy of two slices, was beaten by a man we'd never met, and had a daughter we barely knew? I certainly didn't.It tried to be too many things and failed to be any. A shame

When I first heard about the movie and listened to people talk about it, I had expectations. I expected that it would move me, capture me and take me a place only few movies do. And it did. It is the harsh reality of which real circumstances people have lived under. It gives perspective in those peoples life, and most certainly in how they got treated. The fact that humankind saw and perhaps still see some people as nothing, and that they wouldn't become anything... It is horrifying. And this movies has an amazing message. Which entered directly in my heart. One of the best movies I've seen, and every time people ask me for suggestions of movies to watch I always say this one. And my entire opinion about the subject. 10 of 10 !!

I'm currently studying the civil rights movement in my history A level at the moment and specifically, women, and establishing the difference between a leader and an organiser. To me, this film leads the way in highlighting how brave, strong and incredible black women were in this period. First of all, the film is flawless, albeit a little long and maybe sometimes slow. The only main criticism I'll give this film is that it's emotionally exhausting. I've cried at a few films but this one had me balling all the way through. To me, it was so real and because women went through this just tears me apart. Not being able to say anything, to do anything wrong or else you will face torment and fear from white people and in the character of Minny's case, their husbands.The acting is by far my favourite thing in this film. Viola Davis produces an Oscar-worthy performance, she had everything down to perfection: her accent, her mannerisms, she was the character. The character of Minny, though stereotyped, was a brilliant representation of black women in fear and under the thumb of not only their employers but their husbands, something that was so true at the time. Octavia Spencer's portrayal is hilarious and heartbreaking and the arc that was portrayed was magnificent. Jessica Chastain was another actress who shone in this film, her character had my eyes streaming and my heart breaking. The only performance that falls short is Emma Stone's. Although convincing, at times she's awkward and her accent is flawed. Nonetheless, she gave a very satisfying performance. However, to me, there is one scene that is embedded into my mind. The scene in which Yule Mae asks for a loan from Hilly, the performance of Aunjanue Ellis is convincing and truly heartbreaking as you see the hope in her eyes shattered by the cruel employer.The visuals are something else that make the film even more refined. The colours are gorgeous and the quality of the film making was impressive.This film, although fictional, is a true depiction of life for a maid. There are two words that I'm in danger of overusing in describing this film, but the content and substance is on par with the standard of the film making, ultimately making an incredible, heartbreaking film. I am singing this film's praise because there are not many films like this nowadays, films that make you think, make you feel, make you angry. The Help is a gem, that should be shown to everyone.

The most disappointing part about this film is that although its based around real life events it isn't a true story. There are parts that are so satisfying you can't help but wish it really happened. At its heart this is a film about human relationships and the intense bonds that are formed when people face adversity. It's a very emotionally driven film and pushes you from feeling anger, to sadness, with some delightful and even funny moments in between. The acting throughout was top notch. I particularly enjoyed the performances from Viola Davis and Octavia Spencer both played their characters perfectly. It's an ideal film for modern audiences through its combination of historical events, drama and connection to current issues. Making it an engaging film for people of all ages and walks of life. Seeing how much society has changed from the times depicted in this film you can't help but wonder what needs to happen to cause the changes we currently are in desperate need of. Also giving you a sense of hope that no matter how bad it gets humans care enough about one another to stick together and see it through

If ever a Movie/Book has bared the soul of red neck America it is The Help. And the person to thank is Kathryn Stockett author of the book The Help a fictionalised account of life in Jackson,Mississippi seven years before Stockett was born. This marvellous story which could apparently apply to the 1990's or today about attitudes in Jackson had no blacks consulted in the writing of the book according to the author in a recent court case where Abilene Cooper a maid from Jackson who had worked for Stockett's brother failed in a lawsuit for $50,000 to have it recognised as her story. So we know it's fictional and nothing has changed. The story is of an aspiring newspaper reporter come writer returning from New York to Jackson and see's the opportunity to write a book on 'The Help' the black maids who raised the white children of the south but were unable to look after their own or indeed use the toilet facilities within the house. There is no doubt this is a well told story and to not be moved would possibly put you amongst the red necks. Their were some very funny moments and the screenplay by Tate Taylor has picked up the essence of the ongoing attitudes. If there is one thing I would like to see is a redistribution of the wealth of this film/book to the people of this story and a fitting memorial in Jackson for the people to reflect on their attitudes.

The Help is a story about how one person can make a difference in society all by being an advocate for change. It is a story about a group of people who think they are better than everyone else. It is mostly about a group of people who are downtrodden and spit upon by the other group of people. It is a timeless story that will make most Americans embarrassed about our past history and it will also ring a familiar bell in regards to the injustices of today.For this film, I have decided to not write my normal review. This movie is a serious Oscar contender for Best Picture and I truly believe that this story should not be summarized by someone with a blog. The story is too amazing to be limited to so few words. I will say that all of the cast performed with excellence. There was feeling and emotion in every character. The only fault that I find with the film is the lack of resolution. The film's villains seem to remain in that vile state rather than experience life change. However, I don't see how anyone who views this film can not have an emotional change within them. So maybe the resolution actually lies within the viewer.10/10

reviews.review_title: A great film that benefits from it's cast.
reviews.content: Wow.Have to say, there isn't a movie this year that played on my emotions as much as this one. Sure, there might have been better film this year, but this one really pulled the heartstrings. Based on the bestselling book by Kathryn Stockett, the Help is a darn good film.The film is set in the early 1960s in Jackson, Mississippi during the Civil Rights era of America. The cast is superb; it's what really makes this movie. Emma Stone stars as Skeeter, a young writer intent on writing a book from the perspective of the black maids during this era. Viola Davis and Octavia Spencer star as two of the maids that Skeeter interviews. Viola is excellent as Aibileen, an older maid who has seen much through her time. Octavia stars as Minny, a very funny character who provides great comic relief.The rest of the cast is just as excellent. Bryce Dallas Howard (50/50) portrays Hilly Holbrook, the town's racist and 'villain' of the film. Jessica Chastain (Tree of Life, The Debt) is amazing as Celia Foote, a sort of outcast in the town, despite her fancy home and clothes. My favorite character of the film, even though she doesn't really fit into the main plot all that much. Sissy Spacek also stars as the hilarious mother of Hilly.The plot is fairly simple, and plays it very safe in the racism aspect. Really, what makes this film is the varied performances by it's all star cast. Viola Davis, particularly, deserves an Oscar nomination. & dang, give Jessica one as well! I mean, if not for this, then the Tree of Life. Ah, but enough ranting. GREAT film. Watch it for yourself.

The film brings to life some of the most well written characters and scenes in 2010's, making it a favorite amongst filmophiles. Emotional charge throughout the film is summed up perfectly by chemistry between the actress'(!!!), which really is phenomenal. To be able to show this disgraceful part of our (American) history and put it into drama that outgrows its genre (with comic additions) is something not many filmmakers did. So many emotions and shocks are served, that you really wish it to be fictional. The sad part is, this really happened not so long ago. Fascinating as it may seem, realness of the situation makes a film soulfull and even better. Connection between characters and viewers are "awarded" with real explosions of emotions; that just shows what masterpiece this motion picture really is, standing from a viewer, that can connect perfectly with "the help". Maybe, I will find myself writing another review of the film, but certainly after I read the book, which, as I learned, has to be even better like in every other book-to-screen adaptation. If this is possible...

reviews.review_title: In-depth Extension of the movie, The Long Walk Home
reviews.content: To me, The Help is an in-depth extension of the older movie, The Long Walk Home, with Whoopi Goldberg and Sissy Spacek. I think that's why Sissy was included in the cast of The Help. I loved both movies, however, the reason I gave The Help only 9 stars instead of 10 is because I did not find the little white 2-year old baby (the last one that Abilene raised) logical and believable. In other words she was too young to be saying and understanding words like, "You're my real mama, Abby." "Please don't go. Are you going to go take care of another little white girl?" Those lines are meant for a child at least 5 years old. That is the only character in the movie where I feel the writer screwed up.

its one of the best movies av seen in a long while....a mixture of humour, friendship, courage, sorrow, anger, trust...all in one piece. It tells a story about black women as house help and their stories about their journey as maid where a courageous woman organised a and wrote a book about the suppression and inequality shown towards the maids who helped raised and loved them as their own....believe me it was acted very well, you get to laugh out real loud after you also shed some tear and had some heavy heart scenes.....i am not surprised its audience went back for more and the movie is now number one beating debuts like canon the barbarian and company.... It is a must watch!!! get to theaters now

Based on the book by Kathryn Stockett, The Help takes place in the deep south (Mississippi) in the early 1960's. A well-educated, White college graduate, Eugenia aka Skeeter, (Emma Stone) comes home from college to find her beloved "maid, or nanny," Constantine is nowhere to be found. She comes home with a new perspective of her other high-class socialite friends and family, and begins to take notice of how "the help" or the African American maids are treated. After getting a job at the local newspaper, Skeeter decides to write an article that is in the point of view of "the help," that becomes a book and turns the whole town into a frenzy. Although Skeeter is technically the "main character," the maids (Led by Viola Davis and Octavia Spencer) are what make this movie magical. Their portrayals are intimate, and emotional. Their stories are touching, beautiful, sorrowful yet so profound. The picture painted of the South is not a pretty one, when integration was a new concept, and the lines drawn between whites and blacks were thick. When ignorance was at its peak, and hatred was hiding behind every corner. Still, somehow, these beautiful African American women had hope for a change & for a better future, and courage enough to make a difference.The best movies, in my opinion, make you laugh, cry, and leave you with a morsel of wisdom or inspiration when the credits begin to roll. The characters are so real, so honest that you sincerely FEEL for them, and your heart aches or jumps for joy at their every sorrow of victory. When you leave the theater, you are left thinking about it long after it is over, and you are enriched.The Help was one of those movies. The film was well organized. I was transfixed within the first scene, and it gripped me to the very end. The characters have so much depth and insight, that you sincerely love them, or in some cases, hate them. There were numerous times that I laughed out loud, and other tender moments that made me shed a tear. The actors did such a wonderful job in making their characters real, that their emotions were dripping from every scene. The wisdom the maids carried with them resonated in my mind, and I am still thinking about it. All in all, this is a wonderful film. I can't think of one thing to criticize about it. It is a movie needed even today, that everyone, regardless of race, deserves love, respect, and equality. Please, do yourself a favor and see this movie!

The Help is a 2011 movie, starring Emma Stone and Octavia Spencer, and the film revolves around Skeeter (Emma Stone) writing a book about what life is like for the black maids that work for her friends in 1963 Jackson, Mississippi. As you can tell this movie is a drama, and it's an amazing one. Emma Stone's performance is wonderful, and you can see that everybody had to learn a southern accent for the role.I recommend, because this movie will stay with you long after the credits, and it shows how much change one person can make. It's a definite watch, and I don't think I'll ever stop recommending this movie.10/10.

"The Help" is a must see. It tells of the extremely uncomfortable to watch, racist, beyond 'Jim Crows', mistreatment of all the maids in Jackson, Mississippi. The acting is great. The picturesque setting is in contrast to the ugly goings on in the domestic lives in the households of the middle class southerners life. The good 'White Folk' are evil doers when it comes to matters of race, and the blacks are all angelic good innocent victims. I find it hard to believe that even in the deep south's racist capitol of Mississippi, their wasn't a righteous family to be found in Sodom... But sometimes you need to exaggerate to the extreme to get a point across, and Hollywood is good at that.

reviews.review_title: The author stole the story of Abilene Cooper
reviews.content: The author stole the story of Abilene Cooper and didn't credit her. For this reason alone I hope no one watches this movie. Every awful white saviour complex, manipulative, taking advantage, patronising thing a person could do she represents. Simply a dreadful human.
What a truly beautiful and moving film. Powerful story about extraordinary women, their friendships and personal growth.

reviews.review_title: This movie would NEVER be made in 2021
reviews.content: Even Viola Davis regrets performing in it. I'm white old and female and while there were some good "moments" the portrayal of the utter subservience of the maids however feisty is no longer acceptable. EVEN THOUGH the mostly one dimensional white wives are total monsters and their husbands personify white privilege. The sets and costumes were fabulous totally realistic right down to the sleeveless Lilly Pulitzer frocks. But it is no longer 2011 it is ultra woke 2021 where even a temporary half black princess can whine about racism.
I love the cast, the story, the humour and drama. One of the best movies I've ever seen and highly recommend.

I know I'm late to the game but, i just want to say i loved this movie. At times it was very hard to watch. I was a child in Jackson, Mississippi in the 50s and early sixties and I still remember the days of whites only here. We were not rich, very much not, but my Mom had a made I think once or twice a week and Gertrude kept us whenever Mom and Dad went out. We loved her. She told us funny stories, rocked us and tucked us in. We were always kind to her. I never knew about this side of her life ... I was a child and not aware. The stories here moved me very much and sometimes I smiled and laughed and sometimes I cried. It was sooo well done and in spite of the hardships shown here, really heart warming at times.

reviews.review_title: How this movie did not sweep all the oscars is a mystery to me!
reviews.content: Fantastic movie, maybe my top 5 of all time. Very emotional movie, made me and my wife cry!

reviews.review_title: Guilty of glossing over its bigger themes, but still entertaining.
reviews.content: I felt like this was trying to be an epic drama but at times descended into triviality.Though the topic of race relations was obviously prevalent in the film, it wasn't put up to much scrutiny or analysis. I've heard some people drawing similarities to The Blind Side in regards to this topic, which is in some ways true because it refuses to delve into the issue more and the characters are very flat and not prone to change of any kind. The dialogue was also very sparse at times and had a hard time keeping me interested.That being said, I enjoyed how they did take on another topic more thoroughly, and that's how the lives of suburban mothers rotates solely around gossip and every person seems to be constantly on their guard, waiting to point out something that they find irritating amongst their fellow neighbors. I don't think I've seen a film cover that topic successfully since 2006's Little Children.There were also some good performances in the film, including those of Viola Davis, Octavia Spencer, and--even though her character was very one-dimensional--Bryce Dallas Howard. Thomas Newman's score was also brilliant--prevalent when it needed to be and subtle the rest of the time.Is it perfect? No. Will it please the wider audiences? Most likely.

reviews.review_title: Heartwarming, but a bit self centered
reviews.content: I thought 'the help' was a great movie, especially when it stuck to the theme of civil rights. It really expanded my mind to help me to see what life was like for black people in the 60s.Apart from this, the movie got very sidetracked with minor characters. Skeeters fling added nothing to the movie. Zilch. And Cecelia Foote was an unneeded character that added a solid half an hour to the film.The parts about the maids themselves are excellent, top notch. But it ended up being too much about Skeeter and her white friends in the end. Still worth a watch imo.

I am deeply touched by this movie! It goes without saying that it is superbly made in every aspect regarding movie-making standards, no need to comment on that. What I like the most about it is that it doesn't aim to shock you, there are no scenes of open physical violence, no extremes of any kind yet it gets to you and very much so! It is a serious, sad, and painful subject and takes a truly talented and skillful artists to show all that but still make a movie that you enjoy watching. Although you get soaked in and emotional and can't avoid thinking about pointless cruelty of human nature, injustice, selfishness (and questioning yourself on those issues) while watching this movie doesn't live you depressed and negative - on the contrary.

reviews.review_title: A must see film...and very close to the book!
reviews.content: *May contain a few spoilers* I went to this movie with low expectations. Very rarely does a movie follow the book so closely! Yes, there is some artistic license, but overall I found the subtle changes to be delightful.This movie makes you look deeper than the "white woman and her maid" relationship. The novel "The Help" made people open their eyes and see the maids as (for once) people. Yes, some people got angry and lashed out, but that happens when they are forced to face unpleasant facts.By telling their stories the maids had an outlet. Their own voices rose above the sirens and mayhem to say; "look at me! here I am! I am no longer 'just the help.' I have feelings and dreams." And when Minnie is told she has a job for the rest of her life, it isn't pity that drives the couple, but compassion and a feeling of friendship. There weren't many job opportunities for women --let alone women who weren't white-- so those that she had no way out of being a maid really need to keep that in perspective.As for Skeeter: She moved on to NY both to pursue a dream AND because she had no choice. To stay in Jackson would have been fruitless... perhaps even dangerous. If Hilly had as much influence as she seemed to, the latter is more likely! THE HELP is both inspiring and thought provoking. And may I add... I LOVED the scene where Hilly gets hers! If you read the book, you know what I mean! If you don't know, read the book and/or watch the movie!
Love,love,love this movie I have watched it several times it never gets old. Great story line great loveable characters all and all great movie definitely one of the best I've seen.

This is what a Tyler Perry movie should be. Funny, insightful, and well acted. All of the characters belonged in this film, the church seen made since and was relevant to the story. I enjoyed it from start to finish.Further things Mr. Perry can learn:1. Not all white are bad or the villains. 2. Not every movie needs a rape scene (or a implied rape scene) 3. Black women do not need a "man" in order to be happy and complete.So please Mr. Perry, if you want to stay in the film business... Watch, take notes and learn from this film.

First off let me say I was not overly excited to see this movie. It looked like a chick flick, I didn't read the book, and I felt like the stereotypes in this movie would just set me off. However, I walked out of the theater not only wanting to see it again, but wanting to go pick up the book immediately. I was thinking here we go, another "Blind Side". Typical white character helps poor helpless black character as they build a bond. I was wrong. The Help is so uniquely crafted and wonderfully written that you pay more attention to the difference in personality of the characters, instead of the difference in race. The movie showcases some of the best veteran and new female talent out there. Emma Stone, who seems to be on her way to super stardom, is perfect in the role of Eugenia "Skeeter" Phelan, a unique, intelligent aspiring writer who works up the courage that none of her friends have. That it except for Aibileen Clark (Viola Davis), a middle aged maid who breaks out of her shell to help Skeeter with stories of what it's really like to be a maid. After racial tension rises and the maids are subjected to struggling times, mostly thanks to the villainous Hilly Holbrook (Bryce Dallas Howard in a scary good performance), more and more maids come on board. One of these is the out-spoken, sassy Minny Jackson (Octavia Spencer). Davis and Spencer steal pretty much every scene and are so realistic in their portrayals, you would swear you could see their characters in a Jackson, Mississippi grocery store. I would say at least Oscar nominations are much deserved for Viola Davis, Octavia Spencer, and Bryce Dallas Howard. But also honorable mention for Jessica Chastain and legends Sissy Spacek and Cicely Tyson(who brings tears to your eyes in only 2 freakin scenes!)What I love most about The Help is that it truly did portray the life and times of that period through the different characters. Through Skeeter, Aibileen, Minny, Hilly, and even the hilariously pitiful Celia Foote (Jessica Chastain). The Help is one of those rare, touching, old- fashioned feel good movies that will make you LAUGH, CRY, and THINK.-No matter what color or sex you are....GO SEE THE HELP

reviews.review_title: The Help is Worth Your While
reviews.content: Watching The Help is an exercise in absorption and immersion. From the first frame I could feel the muggy, sticky summer drip out of the screen. There were scenes where I could taste and smell the chicken, the pies, and the diner milkshakes of Jackson, Mississippi. In short, the set pieces are tremendous, and the cinematography is crisp and warm. Yet, the era is not only depicted by the outfits, classic cars, and antique-stuffed houses, but the tense, near boiling-point relationships that permeate the film.Our first introduction in the film is to the voice of the film's star (who is not the white, auburn-haired Emma Stone as many of the movie posters and promotions might have led many to believe), African-American maid Aibileen Clark. Clark, portrayed subtly yet passionately by Viola Davis, has been a caretaker for several white children for her entire adult life, and simply has to swallow all of the racially-charged realities of mid-20th century America. Davis is nothing short of a dynamo in Help; she becomes Maya Angelou's "caged bird." She emotes an intelligence and dulled anger that have both been stifled by years of "yes, ma'ams" and "of course, ma'ams." Davis' Aibeleen Clark is baffled by, yet forced to graciously accept, the way Jackson's sons and daughters grow up to mistreat and dehumanize the very women who spent their lives raising them. In this world where Clark has given love and kindness, and received only disdain in return, she feels she has no agency. And indeed she alone has none.This is where we need Stone's character, "Skeeter" Phelan, to turn the tide slightly in Clark's favor. An aspiring journalist, with a moronic local paper job, she decides to undertake the writing of a tell-all book from the viewpoint of Jackson's black maids. She is a digital-age woman stuck in a relatively barbaric place and time. Skeeter is all moxie and ambition, while her cancer-ridden mother and high society friends just wish she would shut up, get married, and start churning out babies for the maids in town to take care of. Just naive enough to believe her book can succeed, and having not nearly as much to lose as the maids she asks for stories, Skeeter is the perfect catalyst to provide Aibeleen Clark with the dignity she's resigned to having lost. Stone, who has swiftly ripened as a can't-miss leading lady, plays the part aptly; she has just enough quick-tongued retorts and wide-eyed eagerness to endear the audience to "Skeeter" (who could have just as easily been a grating character).Where the movie truly shimmers is in its meditation on hate and injustice, occurring within the characters aside from the predictable plot structure. Help shows how, contrary to what most film and art shows us, hate is much more simple than love and virtue. As illustrated by the film's venomous Hilly Holbrook, played with maniacal fervor by Bryce Dallas Howard, it sometimes takes only a single person to perpetuate odiousness. Mrs. Holbrook, looking as if her head could explode at any moment, is at the head of Jackson's high society table, and the other white ladies in town absorb her every hostile word. As is true of all of history's great villains, and especially Hilly Holbrook, they gain great followings because it's easier to bend to hate and fear than resist it. Opposing spite requires courage and sacrifice, while abetting it only requires that one steps out of the way. In contrast, none of the heroes in Help can accomplish their goals alone or without sacrifice. Aibeleen can't act alone because no white person in Jackson will listen. She must also put her well being in danger to help Skeeter, who in turn can't write a book without Abileen's words and endurance. Neither of them can succeed without the help of many other maids: Skeeter's book won't be published unless at least a dozen maids give her their stories. As shown by the maids in Help swallowing their pride and showering their future oppressors with affection, love is often courage while hate can simply be acceptance of the world as it is.There are a flew flaws in Help, mostly minor. One moment that stands out as particularly horrific came from maid Minny Jackson, otherwise played with gumption by Octavia Jackson. The line spoken, word-for-word, is "I love me some frieeed chicken." While it's not necessarily racist to portray a Southern black person liking traditionally Southern food, the line as written feels cheap and unnecessary, as if the audience is too stupid to deduce that Minny likes fried chicken from the action of her cooking it enthusiastically. There is also an oddly forced love interest for Skeeter's character. I believe the writers place him there to show what Skeeter would have to sacrifice to reach her goals, yet the character is so small and underdeveloped that the romantic subplot seems expendable in a movie already approaching an 150 minute running length. Yet, despite a few ignorable mishaps, The Help is a welcome break from much of the other inane drivel Hollywood rolls off of the conveyor belt and passes off as drama. The ensemble cast is fantastic, most notably Ahna O'Reilly and Jessica Chastain. O'Reilly plays the emotionally-battered second fiddle to Hilly Holbrook, and steals one of the Help's best moments in the closing sequence. She is the perfect vessel to display Holbrook's parasitic effect on Jackson's white residents. Chastain, portraying the painfully sincere housewife Celia Foote, gives a career-making performance. Celia hires Minny, and they repair each other's lives as outsiders in a world they feel helpless in. Their relationship is probably the most stirring in an exceptionally poignant film. Celia's boundless innocence and Minny's seen-it-all steadfastness combine to give both women the fortitude to withstand all that is 1960's Mississippi.

After seeing two extremely disappointing movies recently, I had given up all hope that Hollywood could produce a good film these days. However, when I saw the commercials for 'The Help', I saw a glimmer of hope for the film industry. I decided to give it a try, as I also know people who have read the book and loved it.It's one of those movies where you will find yourself laughing, crying, and everything in between. Not only was the storyline great, but the phenomenal acting brought it all together. It was incredible how much emotion was brought to all of the roles, making each character so real. It's an inspiring story that you won't forget. It is definitely a must see.The only downfall of this movie was that it seemed to drag on a little too long. I found myself wanting to get up because my rear end was hurting. At a certain point I found myself thinking: "Ok this is a great movie, but it's time for it to end." But all in all it was a fantastic film.

When Oscar time comes around very few of the movies that I actually watch get nominated for awards (thus why there are award shows for thoses movies like Harry Potter and Twilight).Most of the time the movies nominated for best picture I would care less to see, however, this movie is defantly one that grabbed my attention from the start and defantly deserves Oscar and Golden Globe Gold. Not just for best picture but for best actress and supporting actress.Very touching story that allows you to connect to many different characters. This is a movie that I will be seeing again and buy when it comes out.

reviews.review_title: Best film I have seen in a long time
reviews.content: If you have not seen this movie, RUN RUN RUN DON"t WALK TO YOUR NEAREST MOVIE THEATER TO SEE THIS MOVIE!!! The movie itself is a great story but all the actors in it seemed to give life within the character and you really felt the pain and anguish of what they all felt back then. For someone to have as much courage as it took for "Skeeter" to write it and "Aibilene" and "Minny" and all the others to tell it, was just great. It so reminded me of how crazy and misguided white women were back then, and yes, I am white. I had an "Aibilene" growing up in the 60's and 70's and my parents treated her with nothing but respect. We ALL ate together. This movie evoked so much emotion in me from crying, to laughing, to cheering about "the pie". I loved absolutely every moment of this movie! Awesome cast, fabulous acting, and truly one of the most memorable movies that will be in my DVD collection!!!!

reviews.review_title: A rainy day film, a sunny day one and a just overcast one too.
reviews.content: The Help, directed and screenplay written by Tate Taylor, is one of my new-all-time-favorites. It was nominated for the most prestigious Academy Award earlier this year and overall, was nominated for another three, two of which were for an 'Actress in a Supporting Role'.The Help resonated with me and will with most women, because one could identify oneself with either group of society.One sees little truths popping-up everywhere (and without sounding unpatriotic, this film portrays parts of my country so well, it's scary). The Help does not disappoint, humorously or dramatically.Skeeter Phelan (Stone) a newly graduated journalism student returns home to Jackson, Mississippi, during the African-American Civil Rights Movement (a movement aimed at gaining racial equality). Skeeter, having been brought up by her family's maid, Constantine (Tyson) and having had great admiration for her, is determined to reveal how the maids, working in white households, experience their jobs and daily lives. With the help of Aibileen Clark (Davis) working for Elizabeth Leefolt (O'Reilly) and Minny Jackson (Spencer) working for Hilly Holbrook (Howard) and then for Celia Foote (Chastain), the three start writing their book, friendship and new lives, together.This is a tail of how well people from different races can work together to create promising futures, and I believe, while The Help only lightly touched on how exactly it was back then, we can all learn something from this film. Personally, Viola Davis's portrayal of what it was like to be a black woman and maid in the 1960's, overpowered all the others' acting in the film. Emma Stone had the quirky, smart girl persona once again. When she cried during this piece though, it was more heartfelt, unlike when she cried in Easy A, when she sounded kind of, well, um, weird. Even though one becomes aware of Minny's (Spencer) hardships, the attention is drawn to her way of just turning anything into something so unbelievably gut- busting without even breaking a sweat. To my delight, Spencer walked away with the Oscar for the Actress in a Supporting Role. As mentioned before, she plays Celia Foote's (Chastain) maid – helping Foote accept her reality as a housewife and societal outcast. Chastain being the other actress in this film who was nominated for the above-mentioned award caught me WAY off guard – sure her character's reality made my heart ache now and then, but other than that I just don't get it (maybe the panel of judges were all fans of Marilyn Monroe and hourglass figures? – the second reason being seemingly padded, to resemble the figure of the former reason.)I realize that I might just like this film because I'm one of those justice-types, but The Help surely is a rainy day film, a sunny day one and a just overcast day one too.
Great story. Great movie. Highly recommended. Exciting story, portrays the suffering of black people during the time of segregation.

reviews.review_title: Wonderful portrayal of complicated intercations reflecting the complications of real life situations.
reviews.content: I recommend this movie. The story, the production, the casting and the film techniques are wonderful. The story is easy to follow and entertaining and at the same time it presents a portray of real life that is full of complications. A young women writer approaches the difficult task of presenting the lives of the "help" in a southern town from the perspective of "the help." A group of rich ladies who like and dislike each other are presented as real life persons who need to carry out expected roles with aggravation, with respect and with lack of respect in their interactions with the help. You feel like you were there seeing the story develop but at the same time the movie allows you to be critical of the reality of the time. The southern ladies are portrayed in a manner that shows their pros and cons. They are the well dressed, dedicated wives who have to have a perfect home and at the same time they are the daughters and wives of less than perfect family members. The maids are hard working, dedicated, and they love the children they care for but at the same time they feel trapped and it is hard for them to be loyal to their bosses. The movie manages to show several sides of the same story with a nicely flowing rhythm that is captivating and does not allow the viewer a brake. You are in the movie for a whole two hours.

reviews.review_title: Why did i not see it earlier:Superb performances and brilliant storytelling..don't miss it
reviews.content: This is the first time that I am attempting to write a well analyzed review for A MOVIE AND ABOUT HOW THIS MOVIE MADE ME LAUGH AND CRY. The Help according to me is one of the best movies to have come out in recent times. Right from the performances to the storytelling everything was just next to PERFECT. There are moments in the movie when you will cry and there are moments when you will laugh and isn't that what storytelling is all about. The movie is about how the African American maids were treated during the time of the civil rights movement But the movie has so many layers that it hits at so many levels. Most of the stories in the movie are about how there existed discrimination during that time and how the African American COLORED maids were treated by the families they worked for but it also gives beautiful examples of some employers being good to their maids and a different kind of discrimination which exists for a girl who has just gotten married rich and is considered WHITE TRASH. So you see discrimination in so many forms: discrimination because of skin color, discrimination because of wealth and other forms. The relationship these maids have with the children that aren't theirs is also beautiful. There are so many scenes that move the viewer especially the one in which Constantine is fired and Cicely Tyson is just so fine in the scene where she makes an impact without even opening her mouth with no lines at all. This one is sure going to my favorites list. Please don't miss it. It would touch you at so many levels that you would feel that why you hadn't seen it earlier.

reviews.review_title: The movie brings the book to life
reviews.content: I loved this movie. It brought the book to life for me. I thought the casting was so good. Emma Stone as Skeeter was just perfect and so was Hilly, Abilene and Minny. Brave women such as these were the backbone of the civil rights movement. This movie acts as a powerful vehicle to show us all how senseless and stupid racism is; look out your ignorance is showing. And I noticed that the men in the audience were just as engrossed in the story as were the women even though the plot revolves mainly around women. Lastly, I was impressed with the baby girl in the movie. Anyone know who she is? She's going to be one h@ll of an actress someday.

The movie states the life of people in Mississippi state where there are human description on the basics of color.This movie tells the side of the story of being a colored help.The hero characters are Aibileen and Minny who works as maids . These character are played by Viola Davis & Octavia Spencer. Emma Stone plays the role of a struggling journalist "Skeeter" who encourages these women to speak up. The Coloured people are underpaid and ill treated , and as there is no scope of there development their next generation suffers too. The shocking part is this discrimination is legal. Thus leaving the colored people no room for hope.The actors have justified their character thus giving life to the movie. Its a must watch!!

This movie is the break though film of the year. Set during the Civil Rights movement, the story follows two African American maids and an aspiring writer as the try to make a Change by documenting the lives of the minority race and their place in a white run society. At this time, this movie has won 4 major awards ( one at the Golden Globes, three at the SAGs), all which are well deserved. Octavia was fantastic as the Caring,but domineering, Minnie, and Viola Davis lead the the movie with a role so convincing, it completed the atmosphere. Actually, the entire cast deserves recognition for their great work. Defiantly a movie worth watching, as Spencer is as funny as she is serious. Wishing the cast and crew luck at the Oscars, even though, with a movie such as this, they need to luck, they've got it in the bag.

The Help is a story about a young woman who goes to Jackson, Mississippi. She goes in search of a job, especially journalism. When she arrives she meets her childhood friend, who is a complete utter racist. But she then shows sympathy to the black maids known as the help and has an idea to write a novella about the p.o.v of the help. But her meticulous friend has other plans.Now, this movie is show stopping, the acting by Viola Davis and Octavia Spencer is FLAWLESS. With Oscar buzzing all over the place for this movie, I wanted to know why? So I went to see this movie with high expectations from all of it's five Oscar nominations and I found it to be a wonderful, beautiful account about racism and chance and most of all revenge for nothing. I hope this movie will come along the lines of such classics like Forrest Gump.This movie is a "thematic" movie. Although this movie is not perfect, it is still a great movie 4 1/2 movie reels from me. I hope you like my review. Thatmoviecritic101.

Films like these, get under my skin, and I love, hope, and get scared with the characters. The film also inspires you to stand up for yourself, and leaves you feeling stronger, and full of hope. I may shed a tear or a few, but this is what makes a film great. In the end, she proves herself to be the best kind of person, who sees the good in everyone, and treats her maid with love and respect.All in all the film tell a scary story about how maids were treated in those days, but inspires as it each of the characters find their own happiness. A must see for everyone. If you are anything like me, get a box of tissues.

reviews.review_title: Just What We Need: Another Movie Where Blacks are Victims

reviews.review_title: Enough to be really good, but not really great
reviews.content: There are only three films I saw that ever reached the same level of greatness as did the books they were based on: "To Kill a Mockingbird," "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest," and "The Exorcist." Coming close, but just missing were "Jaws" (no fairy-book ending for Richard Dreyfus's character in the book) — and "The Help."Yes, Viola Davis and Octavia Spencer do a fabulous job. Yes, Emma Stone is vivacious, spirited and fetching. But Bryce Dallas Howard makes a caricature of the sinister, racist-to-the-core Hilly, and the movie never gives enough time to see the poignant turn-around Skeeter's mother accomplishes, nor lay out the real dangers the servants faced by telling tales out of school. Much of the book's comedic effect is also lost. Some great lines in the book are dropped. ("He was drunker than an Indian on payday".) Celia's white-trash ferocity as she possibly saves Minny's life was also skipped over, diminishing an already diminished role in the movie. These are just a few of the several disappointments with the cinematic version, none of them fatal to the experience, but letdowns nonetheless.Still, this film can't help but satisfy because the book it is based on is so incredibly strong, and the times it depicts are so indelibly emotional. Wisely, the movie takes full advantage of being able to do what a book cannot; the real-life footage of the Medgar Evers murder, TV clips of civil rights marchers being beaten, the rousing news reels of Martin Luther King — all hit on a gut level where a book cannot, especially for those of us who lived through them and saw them first-hand.My overall advice: See the movie first ... then really treat yourself by reading the book. One is a great appetizer; the other is the full meal.

reviews.review_title: "Actually, I can choose what I believe."
reviews.content:
..."The Help" is a 2011 Tate Taylor film nominated for Best Picture at the Academy Awards and Golden Globe Awards."The Help" - the film is definitely worthy of attention. My rating for the film is 10 out of 10. Adapted from the book of the same name, the film hits all the right emotions that the author wanted.The film is about the American town of Jackson in the 1960s, the good, decent girl Skeeter trying to achieve something more than being the perfect wife, the wise woman Abeline who has spent her life as a servant in the homes of white children, her friend Minnie, the best cook in town and the path that brings these three women together to achieve one goal.The film explores one of the most important themes in the world: racial segregation. Discrimination against colored people is one of the main problems of the film, but it is not the only one. It also reveals the problem of the relationship between parents and children. "Children have children" or "It is not easy to live when your own mother thinks you are not beautiful," are the cruel words the characters use to describe the subject of parenthood in the film. The children are brought up by servants, the mothers themselves do not know how to take care of their own child, and subsequently do not understand the bitterness of their own, unloved children in their direction. Another problem is the ideology of women as good wives for their husbands. The ability to be happy only in marriage also haunts the main character Skeeter. Another problem that can be highlighted is the tendency of people to go out of their way to appear happy. "Underneath all that happiness, she's definitely unhappy."
The film evokes a storm of emotions, you do not always have time to understand and accept the actions taking place on the screen. But you have to accept it, everyone has the right to make mistakes and everyone chooses what to believe. But in any case, it leaves a pleasant residue.As for the cast: it's delightful. All the actors are very famous, both in the main and in the secondary roles, it is a pleasure to see familiar faces on the screen. The only thing is that the main character, Abelin, gets lost, drowns in the colors next to the supporting character Minnie. It felt like I was only looking at Jackson's best cook, Minnie, for the entire movie.Looking at the camerawork, you can see that mostly static shots were used. It is also noticeable while watching that the characters in the shots are often positioned on the edge.The main task of the sound part of the production was to create the atmosphere of the '60s, and the sound engineer did a great job. The songs playing in the film were very '60s American, even though there were not so many songs in the film itself.Editing is the creation of a single picture from the many scenes shot. In this project it was consistent and well done.The most important thing for me in the film was the mise-en-scene. The colors in the film were lush, bright, the picture yellowed, but it all created a great atmosphere. The main colors in the film were yellow, green, blue and pink. A perfect color combination for a film describing women breaking the boundaries of their own world.The characters in the frame did what was peculiar to their characters. The maids in the frame were sure to clean or cook; it was not in their nature for them to sit idle. The housewives, living their best lives, frankly, made no sense. And Skeeter, who is assigned the role of writer of the book, of course was always with paper and pen.The film, despite the heavy themes it carries, is as positive and kind as possible. The fine line between happiness and tragedy was apparent throughout the timeline. Loss and discrimination run parallel to the light and warm moments of the main characters. Which shows all the strength and will of these brave women.By the end, I can say that the movie is really a 10 out of 10, but the ending is a little depressing.After a small victory you get ready to see a triumph, but you see only life, because a small victory does not mean the end of the war, but all great things start small.

reviews.review_title: A satisfying film with superb acting
reviews.content: So I finally watched "The Help", a movie which, considering the precursors, has good chances of earning a considerable number of Oscar nominations next Tuesday. And it sure didn't disappoint me.The story revolves around the society of Jackson, Mississippi, in the 60's, focusing on the relationship between the black maids and the white women they work for. There's Skeeter (Emma Stone), a modern young woman who, unlike most of her lady friends, has graduated from University and has aspirations of becoming a writer. As a result of his job as a "homemaker hints" columnist in the local paper, for which she asks maid Aibileen (Viola Davis) for help, she decides to write a book about the Help.The film, hence, has a powerful message about tolerance and equality. I felt that, though this works well and gives the film depth, sometimes it gets a little too obvious and makes it falls into the sentimental, tear- jerking territory. It's not like it bothered me, because it didn't, but I just thought it could have been handled a little more subtly. But hey, Disney's involved in it, so what did we expect?The strong point of the film is the female cast. The actresses are perfect in their roles and they truly shine throughout the film. Emma Stone, as Skeeter, brings really well the modernity and the wit her character requires and Bryce Dallas Howard, though a little "cartoonish" sometimes as the evil and despicable Hilly Holbrook (which is understandable) really delivers too. But I found the following three performances even better: Viola Davis, as the suffered Aibileen, does great in the most heart- breaking scenes and shows once more what a good actress she is, after her short but top-notch role in Doubt, where she outshone everyone (even Meryl Streep!). In spite of this, I'm having a little problem about her being considered the lead for all the awards. Though she's one of the centers of the film, she is missing in a big part of it. Secondly, we got Octavia Spencer, as the sassy Minny Jackson. It's true that hers is not a difficult role to play, but she's really really funny and one of the best parts of the film.And last but not least, the wonderful Jessica Chastain. Her Celia Foote could have easily been played as an over-the-top, one-dimensional bimbo, but she brings a depth and humanity that make her character the most endearing and likable in the film, in my opinion. I enjoyed her scenes with Minny the best.Overall, "The Help" is a perfectly enjoyable film, with amazing performances and an interesting storyline. It doesn't get tiresome at all, despite its considerable length, so I really recommend it. Regarding the Oscars, though, I do not think it should win best picture, but I'd be happy if one of the ladies took home the award, which seems likely.

You will hear people critique this film on the basis of race among other things. Let me be the first to tell you, these critiques are without merit. People may say it is too watered down and doesn't convey the violence of the African American experience. This film does NOT depict the experience of all African Americans. It depicts the experiences of a subset of the race as seen through a white woman's eyes. This is how the author related to the story. As the audience, we see it as she sees it. Other people may say it is just another movie depicting black women in subservient roles. They were! Especially these women! While the story itself is false, it closely mirrors the stories of many southern families. Perhaps what these critics should be concerned with certain other films marketing racist images toward a largely black audience! The performances in this film are incredible. The writing is strong. It is sensitive to issues of gender and race alike. Overall a very moving experience at the movies.

Recently the other Dude and I were discussing that not many award worthy movies come out during the summer; then I see The Help. To say it is not a story that I am normally interested in would be an understatement. I wasn't around during the time of segregation to fully appreciate the depth of this story. Additionally, if there was ever a movie that screamed "chick flick" it would be this one. In spite of that, I've heard wonderful things about the book and decided to view the movie. I'm happy to say that I'm glad that I did. Virtually unknown director Tate Taylor put together a cast of relatively unknown actors and actresses that truly made the story go.Taylor, whose last movie was the little seen Pretty Ugly People, grabbed a familiar actress to join him in making The Help, Allison Janney. Other than Janney the only other familiar actresses in the movie are Cicely Tyson and Sissy Spacek. The rather unknown cast has a fresh feeling on the story and there are no preconceived notions based on a past actor or actresses work. That being said Emma Stone (Easy A), and Viola Davis had a true coming out party in The Help. Both women played fantastic parts, which really made the cast mesh nicely together. Bryce Dallas Howard, Octavia Spencer and Jessica Chastain were all spectacular in supporting roles alongside Stone and Davis.When a movie doesn't have the explosions, crazy action or crude humor that we've become accustomed to seeing in newer movies there has got to be a great story attached in order to maintain your interest; The Help had that great story. There aren't many movies that have you laughing, crying, or getting angry and end up still being fantastic and that is where this one had me. With my common rule of no movie should be over 2 hours unless it is special; this one is very special. I would be surprised if there aren't a number of nominations coming.Children: If they can handle a lot of dialog it is age appropriate for 10+ Award Worthy: YES! Nominations for: Best Actress, Best Supporting Actress, Screenplay, Picture, Director Entertaining: Yes Summer Movie Grade: A+ Is it Worth the Price of a Movie ticket: Yes Would I watch It Again: Yes

The most important thing was the hardships they go through every day. Aibileen and Minnie were brave enough and they could demonstrate how they were treated by the white people. They made a big change. Reflection: Through the film and the text we read, we learned how black people were treated in 1960's. Racism and discrimination were the most important themes of that period. The film showed us that if you really want something, you have to fight for it no matter the consequences. It also taught us to love our enemy, not to fight with violence. The best way to overcome any problems is praying for them. White and Black people are the same, because we were created by God with the same dignity. For that reason, we have to love and respect each other. What I really like about this movie, is the portrayal. It's not just the beautiful dresses they use in that era. It's the point of view we see all this. This movie give us all a little more understanding about the apartheid. We meet this young girl, Skeeter who's brave enough to listen to a voice who's not normally heard. It meant much at that time to not being friends with the "blacks" and Skeeter is then interviewing them anonymously. The movie shows us also the heartbreaking relationship Skeeter have to her "house-helper". She comes to a shock in the movie where she finally gets the explanation why she left. The movie shows some clips about their relationship and it's so heartwarming and so kind. What I also liked about the movie, was that you learn you have to stand up for those who don't have a voice, and how important it is to make a difference, no matter how small or big. What I missed was that some of Skeeter white friends should have stand up and join her in some way. There's much portrayal of what is fair and about consequences.
