reviews.review_title: After aspiring writer, Skeeter, returns home from college, she interviews African American women who work as "the help" to find out what their treatment was really like.
reviews.content: After some resistance, Skeeter is able to record the testimonies of several African American women who work as "the help" for white, Southern families. They reveal how they are treated as well as the secrets of the families they work for. This film in set in the 1960's Civil Rights era. It is two-sided in that it shows there were white families and people that were in favor for equal treatment of African Americans. The film is able to convey messages of equality in an uplifting tone through use of comic relief. The scenery of Mississippi provides beautiful views throughout the film. Emma Stone is a fun character and seems really genuine with the interviewees. Viola Davis (who plays Abileine, a maid) is an amazing actor making the film more realistic. In summary, I would recommend this film to those who are interested in historical films as well as people who enjoy Emma Stone as an actor.

The Help is an amazing movie. It incorporates relationship struggles, historical events, and funny comedy all into one, two hour movie. I have now watched this movie two times and have decided there are two ways to watch the film. One way is you can watch the film by seeing it as a cute story about black and whites becoming friends during a time of inequality and oppression. There are plenty laughable parts of the movie making it light hearted and a feel good movie for the weekend. Another way to watch the movie is by looking at the more complex issues of the movie. This movie is set during a time when there was not equality. Not only were black people oppressed, but so were women. This movie focuses on both black and white women and the struggles they faced living in a society dominated by white males. The fear, hopelessness, and courage shown in this movie illustrates the times of the Civil Rights movement when so many black people were afraid yet felt the need to fight for a better future. There are plenty complex issues of feminism, racial injustice, and relationship struggles introduced in this movie making it very meaningful. However, the comedy, amazing acting, and outrageous characters makes this a movie accessible and enjoyable even to those of us who are not history buffs. I would recommend watching this movie!

This was a wonderful and moving film. Throughout the duration of the movie, I laughed, I cried, I clapped, I cringed with discomfort and squirmed with anticipation. The range of emotions I experienced can be credited to not only the excellence of the story writing but the quality of the acting and the personality of the actors chosen to portray each role. I especially appreciated that the focus was to develop the characters of the maids as opposed to the white ladies that they worked for. This allows for a consistency between the main character's goal to write from the Negro perspective and the goal of the film itself. Unfortunately, it seems that some critics think that this film and storyline are not realistic. It has been criticized for simplifying the complex race relations and omitting the various forms of violence that characterize the time period.

The help is a film full of emotion, and hope, telling the story of the black housemaids in southern Mississippi and their relationships with their white employers. A college graduate of Ole Miss, aspiring journalist and society woman of Mississippi, Skeeter Phalen, goes to work on a piece that evolves into a sort of exposé on the help and their relationships and feelings toward their white counterparts. Throughout the movie you are taken on a journey of highs, and lows, that is very emotion evoking. Aibileen Clark and Minny Jackson are the two main maids that Skeeter gets her information and stories from, however once they start talking, many more women tell their stories as well. There is a background element of the secret that Skeeters mother is keeping about the mysterious disappearance of Skeeter's family's own housemaid which is just another one of many elements that keep you wrapped around the story and wanting more. The whole story serves as a kind of hopeful element of this time, among the tragedy that is touched on throughout the movie, it doesn't seem to focus so much highlighting the very terrible ways that whites treated their black slaves in this time, but rather on the fact that through the use of Skeete and her sympathy and interest toward the help that not all white people were terrible people back then, which serves as the element of hope for society throughout the movie. Overall I was very impressed with this film and would definitely recommend it to anyone who is interested in historical happenings of this nature, or are just in the mood for a heartwarming story.

Thought this film, there are many main ideas that bring out the reality of the Solid South during the times of civil rights and integration. Although the reality of the South was much worse than the movie portrays, I believe the movie carries out all the ideas it involves with great proficiency. The Help shows an attitude of love even towards those who hate and hurt those you love and even yourself. It shows a persevering way of life and creates an environment of hardships and despair with JFK's assassination and the death of the main characters son, to demonstrate how awful life was, especially for African Americans, in this time. Furthermore, nonviolent ways of life is shown, allowing the historical fact that nonviolent actions were what changed generations (ie, the actual book The Help written in the movie). Overall, I greatly appreciate the timeline and plot of this movie and find it to be incredibly inspiring.

reviews.review_title: Eye opening and inspirational with a touch of humor
reviews.content: The Help was an amazing movie but was slightly difficult to watch at times due to the poor treatment of the colored maids and how strong of an influence society had on how they were treated. However, the movie was inspirational and brought an onslaught of many different emotions. I loved how they incorporated events such as Kennedy's assassination into the story to give a feel for the time that the movie was set in and even the struggle of Skeeter having a job instead of a husband and family which showed how people were still adjusting to women's rights. The actors and actresses did a phenomenal job of portraying the struggles of being colored as well as the ignorance and 'better than you' attitude of the white employers. The humanity of the characters was outstandingly developed and showed that during this time period, even though blacks were treated as though they were trash, their actions and emotions showed that they were faced with the same situations as whites plus had to deal with discrimination to top it all off.

reviews.review_title: Tells the story of black maids in the south before the Civil Rights movement
reviews.content: The Help is a story about black maids in Jackson, Mississippi who are mistreated by their white bosses. However, there is a young white journalist who wants to help them by writing a collection of stories of what their life is like. Originally she has a hard time getting people to volunteer to share their stories, because it is very risky. However she manages to get lots of volunteers in the end and she published her book. Fortunately for the maids, they aren't punished because their bosses are afraid to admit that the stories are about Jackson, because there are embarrassing stories. Specifically about how one of the bosses ate a pie made out of her maids poop. This is a great movie for seeing how African Americans were mistreated in the South for so long. It is ridiculous that the whites believe that they can't use the same toilets as blacks because they carry certain disease, yet they allow them to take care of their children.

reviews.review_title: Good movie about discrimination in the South
reviews.content: This was a very good movie. It was interesting to see what's life was like for African- Americans back then and what they had to go through. It was crazy that they were treated that way and that they couldn't even use the same toilets because they thought it would spread disease. It was cool and inspirational to see how one person could make a difference just by telling other people about what it was like. It was also strange to see how dangerous it was just to share their experiences and how it could have very serious consequences. It was inspirational though that they were brave and did it anyways, especially Skeeter who didn't really have anything to gain by challenging the norm. Overall it was a very good movie, even though it was pretty sad.

The Help is an extraordinary film that makes the viewer laugh, cry, and has every minute of their attention. Unlike some Civil Right's movies that take a more serious route, The Help is more light hearted where it ties together an "unlikely" friendship that would occur during its time period, yet is still very effective to get its moral across. Together, Skeeter's ambition, Aibileen's generous heart, and Minny's wit, spark a "revolutionary" movement across Jackson, Mississippi. The Help not does not just focus on the life of the 3 main characters, but draws attention to their help and support to main people in their lives, such as Aibileen's nurture in trying to boost little Mae Mobley's self esteem, who is imperfect to her mother, (Aibileen' tells Mae: "You is kind. You is smart. You is important"), Minny's own nurturing of her employer, Celia Foote, as well as Skeeter's attempt to nurture her relationship with Stuart. The Help is truly a beautiful film that captures the concept of equality for all, and that friendships matter solely on acceptance and care, rather than race or ethnicity.

reviews.review_title: "Courage sometimes skips a Generation," Not so in 'The Help'
reviews.content: "Courage sometimes skips a generation," Skeeter's mom tells her in the movie 'The Help.' It's a movie, if you've not seen it; you need to add it to your to-do list now. Go! Add the book to your summer reading list along with 'Murder Behind Closed Doors,' by Jere Myles, a similar story about characters who refuse to be invisible in a society that would be more comfortable if they were. It's a simple story, set in Jackson, Mississippi, during the early 60s. You don't need a history lesson about what's going on, but it's an education for those who've never heard the word colored used to refer to anyone who was not white. I grew up in Tennessee, and it was like a walk home, and when Aibilene tells Skeeter, who wants to write about the help, she'd never had a white person in her house, it was like "I can't either." Ironically, the movie for me was somewhat reminiscent of Whoopi Goldberg's "The Long Walk Home." "The Help" is definitely a movie to go see. Award winning performances exist all around. The quote tells the story, and you are in for a two-hour plus treat where courage is an underpinning theme throughout. The movie might make you a bit angry, but it will make you think. The acting, the story line, I read the book, and the characters have all been masterfully recreated and put on screen for you to see, and I strongly suggest anyone who's not read the book, to read it. And if you've seen the movie, get the book anyway, available on Kindle. This is a movie about a time period today's generation has totally no concept, and the storyline interweaves the historical elements essential to understand why the story about black maids would even be interesting. They raised most of the white people in today's elevated positions of authority. People care for each other in this movie, especially the black women, while other characters only care for themselves, especially the younger 'society' driven white women.There are so many superlatives I could use for this movie, and I suggest even the men take along a couple of Kleenex, if not for you, the date you may choose to take. Provocative, timely and moving. I loved all the characters, especially the matriarchal white women like Sissy Spacek, who ironically was in "The Long Walk Home." Viola Davis restrained role of servitude is on target and Octavia Spencer's Minnie's spicy yet tempered insolence add dimensions to the movie and flavor to the characters. They are excellent, as is Emma Stone as Skeeter, a southern defiance that's so atypical of the southern women of this time and the perfect foil to a rap-artist incantation of Hilly which Bryce Howard inhabits right up to the hairdos she sports. The men in the movie are just dressing, but Skeeter's potential beau gives you something to resent besides the 'queen' bee Hilly, and a knight in armor in a nicely underplayed Johnny Foote by Mike Vogel. There is comedy and definite drama, and presents a time that reminds us of an ugly truth we should not ignore, particularly in today's climate of racial tensions.Alas, I cannot end this review without a comment on the touchingly sensitive handling of Constantine Jefferson by Cicely Tyson. She's not on screen much, but such a talented actress still has that quality that so resonated in "Sounder," and 'The Autobiography of Miss Jane Pitman.' Great movie. Great cast and a great song 'The Living Proof,'at the end by Mary Blige.

A very well developed story. It is definitely bound to move you and it puts across beautiful messages that defy any racist stereotype about colored people. I recommend it to anyone who is fond of social movies and want a happy, funny and cozy film with tremendous meaning behind it though.
Finally watched ! Have heard so much about this movie. Excellent movie .... watch you will not regret!

I LOVED this book and I couldn't wait to see the movie. Often times the movie isn't as good as the book, especially one like this. I was pleasantly surprised and loved the entire move. My teen kids loved it as well. I can't wait to see this again
A deep and exciting story full of humor and feeling is strange in any season, especially in summer. This makes 'Maids and Ladies' an amazing gift.
Emma Stone one of the greatest actresses in hollywood now, she diserves the best in her career.
The movie was overall great! octavia spencer had a terrific performance in the movie

Just watched The Help on DVD after hearing all the hype and also hearing how my mother and her sisters 'forced' my grandmother to watch it (i'll come back to that later).I read some previous reviews and several said how 'unreal' the threat of danger was. People, lets keep in mind this is a Disney affiliated film. Disney would never let a lynching, a brutal attack or a rape be shown in this film (although ALL these acts occurred during that time). They will IMPLY, but never show. Hence when Milly is attacked by her husband all we hear are screams thru a phone. But I will commend Dreamworks for doing a good job of IMPLYING the REAL threat of danger. When Aibileen (Viola Davis) and the other black man are asked to get off the bus b/c 'some n*gger got shot', they both become nervous, they both hit the street with motivation and intensity. Even though neither once of them said "we might die tonight, hurry home", They both KNEW they had to get home quickly or they could end up dead/injured themselves. It was a very touching scene for me. Almost a little too real.But going back to my 88 y/o grandmother, who helped her mother clean houses before she became the FIRST black employee who worked at her local JCPenny's in the 1950's in TN. My grandmother has always had a hatred for white people but do to the era and her upbringing, she would always smile in a white person's face when spoken to, even in the face of true ignorance (like when a white man asked her where he could find a 'n*gger red' flannel coat within her department). Ultimately grandma watched the film, she didn't cry, but she did share that when her white employers were out of town not only did she use their toilet she also took a bath in their tub. But really, who cares?? Is she not the same person who had to clean it anyways!?!?!? The bathroom issues in The Help are quite true. Racist southerners have been around for ages and their idiotic thoughts have been around even longer.I'm sorry if ya'll were looking for a more technical review of this movie but I can't give it to you. The movie is great. A little watered down but I think its out of necessity. Watch it and judge for yourself. But even if you don't like it, I hope the movie at least makes you think about your actions and the actions of those around you, past, present and future.

The film itself is a great watch. Nothing too lifechanging if you've seen similar films but still a great watch, didn't get boring even once. I feel like the film really excels in the way it handles conversation. The pauses and expressions held during each conversation follow real life so well its almost like pointing a camera at real life. They ate.

The Help is a film that takes place in Mississippi in the 1960's, a time in which civil rights and social acceptance are no where near what they are today. In they film key actresses, Viola Davis and Emma Stone who play Aibileen Clark and Skeeter Phelan respectively, not only recognize but do they're part in acting out against the treatment of colored women in their neighborhood; specifically, those who work in town as maids.Skeeter, a white female, is able to recognize this cruelty and greatly disagreed with it as she and most children her age were raised by their colored house maids. Unlike most however, Skeeter did not forget this and is now unhappy with what she sees happening as an adult to the women who had cared for her and her friends their whole life. These women were treated poorly and were nearly always expected to use a separate outside bathroom while at work. The treatment they endured was not only unfair but just cruel in how people should be treated. Skeeter's and Aibileen's plan were to recruit other maids to assist Aibileen in telling Skeeter their story to be told by Skeeter and published by a famous article in New York, thus allowing all its readers to see just how cruel some of the white women in Mississippi are. To help in the initial punch and prevent later backlash from the women whom they were employed by the maids had shared some embarrassing details about their employers from which they had learned by being in their house so often.While Skeeter was out to help the local maids, she was not the only one who showed respect and kindness to them. Celia Foote played by Jessica Chastain ended up befriending her maid Minny represented by Octavia Spencer. The local atmosphere was so strictly adjusted to how these women were treated that at first Minny was uncomfortable with how well Celia was treating her. So much so that she discouraged it and attempted to get her to behave as the rest of the maid's employers.One way in which the film does an amazing job of giving insight as to the treatment of the maids is how they are able to let the viewer see things from the maid's point of view as they are being degraded. This is done through a narrator, Viola Davis, who is also a charac6er in the film and is able to attest to how poorly they are treated. Another is by allowing us to see and hear some of the colored maids' reactions to what the white women are saying right in front of them. The Help is truly a great film and serves as a reminder as to why we must treat all of those we encounter with dignity and respect
Good movieRecommendedOverall: 8.1/10-----------------

reviews.review_title: Lighter Fare than the Book, But Still Remarkable
reviews.content: For those of you who read the book, you may as I did often compare the differences within the movie. However, I still truly appreciated the performances, the funny moments and certainly the heartfelt moments that elicited some of my tears. The two biggest differences between the book and movie were the tone and lack of character depth, save the characters of Aibeleen and Minny. Although Skeeter was lovable, Celia cute and Stuart, well, he just made a couple of short appearances, none were captured in a way that truly showed the core of who they were nor explained their treatment of others within the story. *SPOILER* In the movie you see Minny showing Celia how to cook fried chicken, however in the book, their cooking lessons took place every day and cemented their bonding and friendship. As well, the side story in the book where Celia literally saves Minny's life is completely left out of the movie. All in all, the movie was a beautiful story filled with laughs and extraordinary performance by the lovely ladies who played Aibeleen, Minny, Hilly and Celia. I would recommend seeing this to anyone with sensitive sensibilities. Although there were a few men in the full theatre I was in, I am hesitant to say that "even your guy" will love it. So, men be warned that this may be your idea of a "chick flick", or perhaps shame on me, this may just be a movie for everyone.
I remember watching this movie and it was very well made and written. I believe it was a book that was turned into film.

« The Help » was realised by Tate Taylor in 2011. The story takes place in the city of Jackson, Mississippi, in the 1960s. Starring Emma Stone, Jessica Chastain and Viola Davis, it is a portrayal of 3 women who have a secret project : writing a book that challenges the most sensitive social conventions of the time, in particular the condition of black women, who often worked as maids or nannies for rich white families.As we studied it, gender stereotypes in the 1950s and 60s depicted women as submissive women who raised children, did the housework and cooking, sometimes read a book but didn't occupy important positions in society.
Compared to what we studied, this film's heroines are not submissive but struggle to make things change. They take risks by defying the social and racial norms of the time.
« The Help » also differs from other films dealing with the status of women in the early second half of the 20th century as it introduces a new dimension which is racial segregation.After seeing the trailer, I would like to watch this film because it deals with themes that I find exciting.In fact, not only it deals with the condition of women in the american society of the 1960's, but also and more precisely the condition of black women, who were doubly penalised, on the one hand because they were women, but also because they were black.Indeed, in this state where racial segregation was still very much alive, black women were generally employed as cleaners or nannies, allowing wealthy white women to escape the chores traditionally assigned to women. Restricted to the least rewarding tasks, these black women allowed white women to emancipate themselves.
As a conclusion, I think that this movie is of public utility as it shows what real discrimination was at a time, ours, when everyone claims to be discriminated against.

I loved this movie a whole lot. This film opened up my eyes on how black people were treated in a time period when I wasn't born. I have a feeling that if people look at this film from a historical context with its setting of the 1960's, this films displays the story of how many blacks were treated like their ancestors of the civil war of 1861-1865. I about burst into tears just watching this film. Viola Davis and Octavia Spencer pull an excellent performance as Abileen and Minny. I also enjoyed Skeeter's performance pulled very successfully by Emma Stone. This film also shed a little light on the assassination of John F. Kennedy and his funeral in 1963.I believe this film should be viewed in schools during a U. S. history class for many reasons besides the fact from being touched upon racism and the death of JFK when people stopped and turned to the TV screens for the viewing of the funeral for the president.There are some heartwarming scenes and the ending is very sad but also the ending quote is very meaningful. "You is kind, you is smart, you is important." This 2 and a half hour film is worth the view. I haven't read the book but this film is just wonderful and a little bit of a tearjerker.

The Help.The movie The Help is based on the book by Kathryn Stockett. The movie was directed by Tale Taylor. It stars Viola Davis as Aibileen Clarks, Octavia Spenser as her best friend, Minny Jackson, and Emily Stone as Eugenia Skeeter. The movie won Oscar for Best Actor (Octavia Spenser), Best Woman Role, Best Cast.The movie is set in USA in 2010-2011. It was filmed on location in Mississippi, Jackson.The movie is about African maids who is working in white household. Skeeter and Aibileen start to write down all stories that she has. And soon more women come to tell their stories. It was incredible situation. White families were shocked by this book. But Skeeter and many black women were very happy, she understood that now it will never be the same.I recommend The Help. It has drama, comedy. An important message that we should be politer and more careful to people who spend all of their life for us, and everyone has the chose. I am really exited by this movie.

I didn't have high hopes going into the theatre and I wasn't really sure what this movie was even about, but I was blown away by the end of it. This movie was incredible. It had so much emotion. One minute you're laughing your face off and the next, you're crying or you're super angry. Emma Stone was brilliant. Her accent was even great. The entire cast was fantastic. reviews.review_title: "Actually, I can choose what I believe."
reviews.content:
"The Help" is a 2011 Tate Taylor film nominated for Best Picture at the Academy Awards and Golden Globe Awards."The Help" - the film is definitely worthy of attention. My rating for the film is 10 out of 10. Adapted from the book of the same name, the film hits all the right emotions that the author wanted.The film is about the American town of Jackson in the 1960s, the good, decent girl Skeeter trying to achieve something more than being the perfect wife, the wise woman Abeline who has spent her life as a servant in the homes of white children, her friend Minnie, the best cook in town and the path that brings these three women together to achieve one goal.The film explores one of the most important themes in the world: racial segregation. Discrimination against colored people is one of the main problems of the film, but it is not the only one. It also reveals the problem of the relationship between parents and children. "Children have children" or "It is not easy to live when your own mother thinks you are not beautiful," are the cruel words the characters use to describe the subject of parenthood in the film. The children are brought up by servants, the mothers themselves do not know how to take care of their own child, and subsequently do not understand the bitterness of their own, unloved children in their direction. Another problem is the ideology of women as good wives for their husbands. The ability to be happy only in marriage also haunts the main character Skeeter. Another problem that can be highlighted is the tendency of people to go out of their way to appear happy. "Underneath all that happiness, she's definitely unhappy."
The film evokes a storm of emotions, you do not always have time to understand and accept the actions taking place on the screen. But you have to accept it, everyone has the right to make mistakes and everyone chooses what to believe. But in any case, it leaves a pleasant residue.As for the cast: it's delightful. All the actors are very famous, both in the main and in the secondary roles, it is a pleasure to see familiar faces on the screen. The only thing is that the main character, Abelin, gets lost, drowns in the colors next to the supporting character Minnie. It felt like I was only looking at Jackson's best cook, Minnie, for the entire movie.Looking at the camerawork, you can see that mostly static shots were used. It is also noticeable while watching that the characters in the shots are often positioned on the edge.The main task of the sound part of the production was to create the atmosphere of the '60s, and the sound engineer did a great job. The songs playing in the film were very '60s American, even though there were not so many songs in the film itself.Editing is the creation of a single picture from the many scenes shot. In this project it was consistent and well done.The most important thing for me in the film was the mise-en-scene. The colors in the film were lush, bright, the picture yellowed, but it all created a great atmosphere. The main colors in the film were yellow, green, blue and pink. A perfect color combination for a film describing women breaking the boundaries of their own world.The characters in the frame did what was peculiar to their characters. The maids in the frame were sure to clean or cook; it was not in their nature for them to sit idle. The housewives, living their best lives, frankly, made no sense. And Skeeter, who is assigned the role of writer of the book, of course was always with paper and pen.The film, despite the heavy themes it carries, is as positive and kind as possible. The fine line between happiness and tragedy was apparent throughout the timeline. Loss and discrimination run parallel to the light and warm moments of the main characters. Which shows all the strength and will of these brave women.By the end, I can say that the movie is really a 10 out of 10, but the ending is a little depressing. After a small victory you get ready to see a triumph, but you see only life, because a small victory does not mean the end of the war, but all great things start small.

Absolutely fabulous movie. Wonderfully written (both book and movie). Beautifully acted. Viola was brilliant as Abilene. Hilly was a wonderfully hideous character who, sadly, really does exist. Minny was a joy to watch. Her spunk made us want more. Skeeter was the wonderful innocent who is appalled by the reality of what is happening in her life.All the cast did a wonderful job but if Viola doesn't win an Oscar the academy is dumber than I thought. Thank you for time and money well spent. I definitely will see this again and again. The closing song was a beautiful recap of what we needed to take away from this film. This will be a wonderful addition to my film library.

reviews.review_title: Emma Stone takes the Town's maids to the cleaners. in" THE HELP.".
reviews.content: EMMA STONE TAKES TOWN'S MAIDS TO THE CLEANERS in "THE HELP"A night at LA's newly renovated Kodak theater hosting the Cirque du Soleil for my daughter and I would have set me back a couple hundred dollars...When in Rome do as the Romans do...See a movie, that's what we do best here in Los Angeles, and a friend happened to have tickets for a film which a had just been released. "The Help" didn't conjure up any real expectations, and movies I tend to like the most have always been surprises. So, Tommy Taylor had the tickets for the Century City AMC, and the seats were great. I mention this because I was curious about the type of people that would pay money to watch a film that was bound to inflict injury to the historical naive. I thought maybe fewer people would see the film here, but the seats were filled, mostly by couples and smartly dressed women between twenty and forty something. Maybe that's just the age range that most women here can afford to maintain. I don't know, it's just that poor people look so much older...I'm not sure if the film's Sunset Boulevard billboard depiction of two beautiful black women in fitted, stylish, and modern maid's uniforms whispering silliness to each other in front of two unaware, well dressed, white women created the film's homogonous stampede, but after viewing the film, I will say that the billboard illustration was a complete and accurate rendering of the entire film, except maybe the feces pie, which ironically, turned out to be the catalyst for the entire story. A catalyst is the element in a mixture that causes all the other elements caught up in the mix to destruct, fall apart, or lose it's form while the catalyst remains unscathed, unaffected, and untouched... Maybe the rich white girl, just home from journalism school was the catalyst after all..."The help," had no more depth, nor relevance than the current television prime time mindless "House Wives," franchise. However, the American public for all it's racist accusations gets point's for getting off their couches and going to the theater (at twenty million dollars at the box office for the first week-end) to support a film about it's sometimes uncomfortable past, a past from which it cannot seem to get past, but a past it wants to understand. The story is too simple; Employer dictates where feces happens. Employee can't take this feces. Employer fires employee over feces. Employee feces in pie. Employer eats feces in pie. Employee tells everyone just who ate her feces.Since this story involved a white employer, a black employee, a domestic situation, and most importantly takes place at a time none of us today can fully understand, layers and layers of racial "feces" are injected to exacerbate an already vulnerable situation in which only one perspective is fully exposed. The employees, "the maids," are glorified, as hard working, child loving, friendly, much closer to god,and morally strong, while the employers are"Weak minded," and cast as uneducated, selfish, lazy, klanish, entitled, malicious, unwilling to care for their parents, or even their own children.With a cast like this I'm surprised the feces made it into a pie shell.The film takes us through the daily life of a black maid in the sixties, and the most dreadful experiences conceivable. The tension reaches such a pitch for the maid that, like Rosa Parks where the maid sits (and does her "business") is the last straw. She's fired, and shortly thereafter the maid secretly feces in a pie and feeds it to her one time employer. At this point the movie is over for me. All creative writing credibility is lost with the very idea of anyone feeding someone else their feces, much less eating it. In creative writing class this would've earned the writer a big fat F, because it lacked any thought, or creativity. I hoped maybe she'll just let her employer think that she ate the maid's feces, and that would've been cool, but that opportunity was lost as well. Equally disturbing, is the pretty, white, "home again," college girl, journalist who has never managed a relationship in her life, including with her mother, yet some how manages to convince every black maid in town to turn their white employer's closets, inside out for the world to read....in her book....right before she leaves town... forever...to begin her writing career... with Ms. Stein...in New York City. Every maid in town gave up their profession...for what? Talk about being owned... If the filmmaker wasn't on a feces based, racial binge, she wouldn't have created this little rich white girl who single-handedly cheated many black maids out of their jobs and probably their livelihoods. She would've included examples of some of the employer's that did pay their maids well, that did give their maid rides to the bus stop, that did send food and clothing home with the maids, that did provide adequate bathrooms, that did let the maid bring her kids to work when they were too sick to attend school, and did help fund their children's education. She would've created at least one smart maid character that would've called the sketchy rich white "journalist" on her scheme. There was a copy of "To kill a mocking bird," strategically placed in one of the scenes...a more relevant book for this scene would've been..."The devil went down to Georgia." This piece of feces is just another literary masterpiece out of New York City at the expense of the "fly over," ie...the "restofUS."If your story requires that one of your characters eat a feces pie...chances are your story is weak, and SH*T ain't' gonna fix it.Does America really deserve another feces pie ?
I think Skeeter's house is great and I wanna get a picture of it when my parents and I go down to Mississippi and look at it.

reviews.review_title: Entertaining Tale About Rural Southern United States
reviews.content: I thoroughly enjoyed watching 'The Help' as films on historical data has always been of interest to me. What I find frightening is how this appears 'new' to most people, the treatment of house servants during those days when in reality people chose to ignore the issue. Bringing light to it now doesn't justify the actions by these so-called prominent families. What I find most disturbing were some references that their maids were considered like members of the family. Sadly this just isn't so. A member of the family would sit at the dining room table with the family sharing a meal. You would go visit a family members home. You would shop in public with a member of the family. A member of the family would be introduced as a 'relative' and not as 'Minny or Abileen my maid' and told to go fetch Mrs. So and So a glass of iced tea. No, these women aren't 'like a member of the family'. They are your employee.Separate but equal. A phrase that most people in the South considered to be a fair comment. There was nothing equal when it came to race relations in those days.As for the movie, I like how certain references to events were named such as the assassination of President Kennedy and Medger Evers and what transpired in the town of Jackson during those events. The clothes and styles of that era were remarkable and the acting was on point.

reviews.review_title: Excellent movie, sad and funny, well acted
reviews.content: "The Help" a human nature story of part of our history. It takes place a long time after the end of slavery.It shows us what the lives of rich white people and their black maids was like in the early 60's.It shows us the lack of respect and appreciation for the help who, loved the white children they raised. It is well acted, well presented, well written, well directed etc... I expect some Oscar nominations. I don't remember any one movie I saw that I wanted to see again the next day; this one is.It is terrific, a must see!

Went and saw the movie because I'd read the book and really liked it. I'd also heard that it roughly paralleled a similar story and one I'm all to familiar with—that of vaccine injured, and the injustices they've faced.Oh boy was it ever a slap in the faced to see the words 'Participant Productions' in the opening credits.Participant Productions bills themselves as a 'socially relevant' film company. That being said, I find the hypocrisy breathtaking, given what they've done with the movie rights to Evidence of Harm. It's a bit like that man in the soap opera who went upstairs and never came back down because the writers forgot about him. Looking on the internet, one might get the impression that the story never was in development although it was at one time. Would you like an explanation as to why it was taken out of development? You won't find one on the internet. You might try writing them, but others have—you'd be wasting your time. The socially relevant film company doesn't feel it's a socially beneficial thing to do to respond to people who've had their rights stripped from them via Bruesewitz versus Wyeth. They don't feel any need to respond to people who've been treated arguably more horrifically than most black maids of the fifties and sixties.I liked the movie a lot. That doesn't change the fact that I wouldn't have paid to see it, had I known.

The fact is this movie has a huge lesson for both: Blacks and Whites.Both "colors" of people have no idea of the ridiculous segregation abuses our recent elders went through. Still the "whites" will discover the stupidity of superiority and the "blacks" will discover the need for courage to live with dignity and honor.Equality through peaceful protest is mentioned lightly with MLK News on TV which is the long term goal we all struggle to achieve. Obviously we are not there yet.Sweat, Love, and Sacrifice are necessary ingredients for us to clean up the house of superiority.

reviews.review_title: Cus a pretty girl said so!
reviews.content: My mom reads a lot of books. So it's not shocking to me that she read The Help more than a year ago. She finished the book and couldn't stop raving about it. She told me, she told her friends, she told family, "you gotta read this book!" I didn't read it. A few months later my great aunt and then my cousin read the book, "you gotta read this book," they said. My aunt handed me the book, but I didn't read it. Some time past and the movie came out. I still hadn't read the book but I was going to. One day a cute girl mentioned to me, "hey I'm reading The Help." My response "oh me too, when I finish it, we should go see the movie." (I finished that book in 1.5 weeks.) (I did however cheat a bit I downloaded the audio book!)The cute girl finished the book and we went to the movies. I'm always afraid to read a book then go see the movie. It seems that the movie can never compare to the book! I think it's because a movie never has time to cover the details that the book does.So I thought the movie was good but not nearly as good as the book.The things I liked: It is super fun to go to a movie with somebody who has read the book. (especially when she's cute.) I loved gossiping back and forth about things the book did better. (yes we were the annoying ones talking in the theater.) I also enjoyed complaining about interesting twists and the creative license that the movie had taken.I liked the directors choice in casting Emma Stone as Skeeter. (The daughter and Reporter) She wasn't as frizzy haired as the book described her, but she was perfect for the role. Jessica Chastain was so perfect as Celia Foote. (the hopeless house wife) She made me laugh so many times! And yes Hilly Hollbrook, played by Bryce Dallas Howard was so horrible and it was fun to hate her! Finally I'm still torn about Allison Janney portrayal of Skeeter's mom. SPOILER ALERT: In the movie she was supportive of her daughter Skeeter I really liked this but it doesn't follow the book! Is that bad?The things I didn't like: Again my statement stands movies are rarely as good as the book! I think the movie touched on a lot of topics. It mentioned almost every major event in the book. However I never felt as worried for Skeeter and The Help as I did in the book. In addition I never once felt any of the weight of the repression of the 60′s and the weight of JFK's death and such. They could have done that better.Also this isn't important but I didn't like Chris Lowell as Stuart Whitworth. I always imagined Skeeter's first boyfriend being bigger, stalkier and more of a southern football star.My advice: See the movie but it's totally OK to rent it! (Unless of course a cute girl invites you to go see it in the theater in that case my advice: Definitely see this movie in a theater!)by Stef Dastard: www.reeldastards.com

to tell the truth i don't like oldies but In fact, as audiences move onto the web for movie downloads, it is likely that more indie, low budget movies will get their fame outside of the box office as distributors find it harder to market them. How did this happen and what does this mean for the future at the box office?There will always be a demand for drama, thriller, comedy genres and so forth, but the way marketing is carried out for these movies could be changing because of the web's influence. Blockbuster films have huge marketing budgets and can practically dominate online as well as traditional advertising placements. When it comes to indie movies, getting an audience buzz around a film tends to start at major film festivals. Big releases like George Clooney's 'The Descendants' and David Cronenberg's 'A Dangerous Mind' are getting plenty of attention, but perhaps audiences are turning to the web for indie movies, and the theatre for blockbusters.Because technology is bringing movies into our homes faster, simpler and cheaper, the concept of the theatre may be changing for audiences. People are more intrigued to see an 'epic', 3D movie or family release rather than an indie shot on a low budget. The web is still fairly new in the film marketing mix, but it seems that indie movies are getting more buzz online because budgets are low, and the free tools available to promote them are plentiful. Does this mean audiences discover indie movies on the web first, and would prefer to download them digitally rather than see them in theatres?

reviews.review_title: The embroidery on the wall of the Lefort's living room
reviews.content: Recently I viewed the magnificent motion picture, The Help. I loved the movie all the way through. But at the end something caught my eye. On the wall in the living room of the Lefort's, when Hilly is reprimanding Abby and accusing her of stealing a few pieces of silver, and the little girl comes to her because her throat hurts, I saw something remarkable on the far wall of the living room. I was watching the film on DVD in my living room so I could freeze the film in an appropriate frame. On the wall of that living room was a picture, a large picture of mallard ducks. The ducks were framed in a brown wooden frame. I was startled because I embroidered a picture just like that one in the late 50's early 60's. I couldn't believe my eyes because my heart told me that this picture on the wall was my embroidery! I would love to ask some questions about the piece. Is it indeed an embroidery? A cross-stitch embroidery? Is there a very obvious mistake in the lower portion of the piece, where the 2 bodies of the ducks in the foreground meet? I would love to know if this is my embroidery.

reviews.review_title: The Help is a must see.

He did a very good job creating the experience of the movie to be surprisingly light- hearted and touching. With help from leading actresses Viola Davis, Emma Stone, and Allison Janney; these women did an incredible job making the Mississippi, Southern style of life come alive. The movie explains the relationships between African American maids during the 1960s and their families they provided for. With constant care taking, daily routines and chores many of the maids went about their lives saying very few words to the white folks. When Miss Skeeter Phelan, a University grad with a passion for writing, comes back to town, she stirs up a hot pot of drama. Persuading the maids to tell-all about their unspoken stories and redemption towards white families they have worked for, may have sounded like a good idea at the time. Lets just say that some thoughts are better off not spoken. The passion and friendship Skeeter shows towards these women is truly touching and heart-warming. This movie shows how the determination of one person can change the lives of many. At some point everyone is forced to make the choice of either staying with or breaking the status quo. The light humor and strong Southern accents will definitely keep you intrigued throughout the entire movie. The Help is a must see.

reviews.review_title: Leaves all that watch a sense of urgency to stand up for what they believe in
reviews.content: The Help, based off of the 2009 novel by Kathryn Stockett, tells a story of three courageous women who join together to uncover ways they are mistreated as African American housemaids in the 1960's. Taking place in Jackson, Mississippi, these types of actions were unheard of. If caught, the members of "the help" would face arrest, never be able to find work again, and be shun from the city, however this did not stop them telling their story. Eugenia "Skeeter" Phelan, played by Emma Stone, has just graduated from college and come back to her hometown. After scoring her first job as a cleaning advice columnist which she is clueless about, she turns to Aibileen (Viola Davis) who is the African American housemaid of an old old childhood friend. to ask for advice. In doing so, she begins to notice how poorly Aibileen and other members of the help are treated, inspiring her to write a novel though the eyes of the help. Skeeter knows the dangers this can cause for Aibileen, ignores the consequences. After much convincing, Aibileen agrees to help, eventually recruiting her best friend Minny (Octivia Spencer) and other maids to join in the fight against the cities unjust treatment of the help. The writing of this book soon becomes much more than any of the women involve could have imagined, giving each of the maids a voice as well as a chance to finally tell the world what was seldom spoken of. It transforms into an important movement that was able to change the entire city of Jackson, Mississippi and the lives of all housemaids around the state. The theme of this film focuses on racism and courage. Racism is unfortunately the more serious of the two, as it brings many back to the cruel and shameful acts placed on innocent African Americans. The film steers away from much of the hate crimes happening in the 60's, yet still shows how racism had an impact in a more subtle way. Throughout the film, the town is adamant on the idea of creating separate bathrooms in the homes of those with maids. Many scenes show Aibileen and Minny sneaking around to simply use an inside bathroom or being forced to use separate outhouses. Skeeter was one of the few who saw the wrong in this and to a chance to make a change.In a more positive light, "The Help" brings attention to the moral courage of the African American women of Mississippi. Throughout the film, Aibileen is shown patience and kindness to the most racist white families, raising their children to have respect for all people, including themselves. She works hard to make them understand their worth in the world often repeating kind works of encouragement, "you is kind, you is smart, you is important". Beyond everything else, Aibileen, Milly, and other maids show courage as they tell their stories to Skeeter, risking their freedom, their jobs, and their families, all for the sake of future generations. The movie The Help shows a true testament to the courage of the women of the past, and the limits they were willing to reach in order to stand up for what they believed in. Women, just as those portrayed in the film, have paved the way to our future. This well written storyline sends a positive message to all generations, leaving all that watch a sense of urgency to stand up for what they believe in and make a difference in what's wrong in the world.

The Help is set in the strict segregated state of Mississippi. Living in the midst of the civil rights movement, being a colored maid, called the help, makes life much harder. An eccentric twenty-three year old novelist wannabe, Skeeter Phelan (Emma Stone), decided to write a book about the perspective of these ladies about the family they work with. Skeeter Phelan, just like the other 1960s white kids, grew up in the arms of their family's help. She loved her almost more than her own mother. Skeeter has dealt with numerous problems regarding segregation laws and her friend, Hilly. With the help of two unusual maids, Aibileen (Viola Davis) and Minny (Octavia Spencer), Skeeter successfully publishes her book.Tate Taylor, director of the movie, intended the viewers to leave their twenty-first century mind behind. The movie was set to give watchers the feel of living in 1960s America before the racial acceptance we have today. From what I perceive, the movie wants viewers to think about how far our country has social equality not only in race but also in gender. I notice that most of the women in the film were striving to find husbands who could provide them a good life. The movie, for me, depicted male dominance of the past. This gender inequality was also shown in the African-American side when Minny's husband hit her after losing her job as a help.Living outside the United States, my knowledge about the American history is limited and watching this kind of movie broadens my understanding. Aside from the history factor of the movie, I also thought that the little kid in Aibileen's care was fantastic. To be honest, Aibileen and the little kid's acting made me move to tears for a little bit. My family also used to have a help back when I was young and those scenes made me nostalgic about my past. There were some things I thought that did not fit for the movie though. It was the scene when Minny showed a can of Crisco, which is a food shortening, to Celia while teaching her how to cook. I just thought that the design of the Crisco can was too modern for that time period. Nonetheless, I enjoyed the watching the movie.

The plot tells the story of a white young woman called Skeeter (Emma Stone) who is a journalist. Skeeter decides to write a book about the point of view of the black maids, showing the racism that they suffered at white people's house where they worked. To write her book, Skeeter get the help of Aibileen (Viola Davis) and other black maids. Skeeter and the maids end up suffering reprisals because of the book."The Help" is an amazing film that can make you laugh and cry because of the emotional stories that are told. It shows how complicated the relationships between black and white people were in the 1960s, and shows how silly some people can be because of the racism.

reviews.review_title: The outstanding cast and engaging emotions, make The Help a must see.
reviews.content: People want to believe that they have courage, but they are unwilling to speak against social norms for fear of rejection. In The Help, Skeeter, an ambitious, white writer tries to explain what it is like for black women to serve white families during the civil rights era. Due to the social separation between the two races, she faces many obstacles in an attempt to compile stories from maids, such as Aibileen and Minny. The film does a great job of explaining the social differences at the time, while still giving the audience a deeper meaning to consider. The dialogue creates distinctions between the white and black characters through a difference in education. Although all of the characters talk with a slight southern accent, the white characters speak with sophisticated vocabulary, while the African American characters sound uneducated. The quote, "you is smart, you is kind, you is important," said by Aibileen, shows the limited education available for African Americans at the time. The way the different races talk about one another also indicates this separation. Hilly, a white housewife, insists on the necessity of separate bathrooms in houses due to the risk of catching "black diseases." The filmmakers make a point to show the different distinctions, giving the audience a better understanding of the social norms at the time. Through the use of heavy subject matter and humor, the filmmakers grab the audience's attention in an engaging way. The cruel accusations towards the maids, and brutality displayed by the white police officers, keep the film impactful, but the filmmakers incorporate humor to lift up the film's serious tone. Minny brings the humor to the film in her sassy comments. Humor is present when Minny tells Skeeter "You ain't got nothing left here but enemies in the Junior League. You done burned every bridge there is. And you ain't never gonna get another man in this town, everybody know that. So don't walk your white butt to New York, run it!" The filmmakers set the tone through serious events, but develop a more unpredictable plot by including humor. The unpredictability adds to the film's overall enjoyable story. Through the acting of Viola Davis and Octavia Spencer, the audience can better understand the characters they play. Viola Davis successfully portrays her character, Aibileen Clark, as a loving, hardworking individual. Davis delivers her lines with a tired voice, suggesting that she commits herself to her job. We also get the idea that her character is good with kids by the way she lights up around her boss' child, Mae Mobley. Davis is able to change her delivery to fit the scene. Octavia Spencer entertains the audience with her sassy interpretation of Minny Jackson. Spencer does this through mannerisms, such as pursing her lips, standing with her hands on her hip, and rolling her eyes. These mannerisms that Spencer uses add to the idea that her character is very head-strong. Octavia Spencer also delivers lines in a loud, bold manner. When Skeeter is interviewing Aibileen, Minnie storms into the scene and states, "And just what makes you think colored people need your help? Why you care?" Octavia does not hesitate before she delivers this line, adding to the confidence of her character. These actresses add believability to the film with their genuine portrayals of their roles. This film sets a precedent for future films discussing controversial topics such as the treatment of African Americans. This movie is not only entertaining, but it also sparks thought about how the audience treats others. It plays with the audience's emotions to ignite a passionate response to the subject of the movie.

reviews.review_title: In Their Own Words: A Tribute To the Maids of Mississippi
reviews.content: I sometimes feel like Academy Award nominated films do not necessarily appeal to the masses. Some require a lot of thinking. Some require a lot of emotional commitment. The Help is so powerful because rarely is anything written by the point of view from these maids who practically raised children from the 60s while their own kids were farmed out to relatives back on their side of the tracks. Davis and Spencer were perfectly cast as two women with extremely different character traits working to fulfill the same goal. They were the perfect yin and yang and it was beautiful to see their strength and courage portrayed on the screen.That said, The Help has managed to simultaneously generate Oscar buzz while appealing to demographics across the board.Twitter @zackisthe

Again, the female performances and the 'drama' underneath the personal history of each character made me enjoy the process of watching it.We need more movies that explore these subjects, but also, empower the people in it, more than just an anonymous book. reviews.review_title: The Help is more than just a "Good Movie"
reviews.content: The Help, before it was turned into a movie, was a great book. Though it painted the conditions of the South during this era in clean, easily digestible strokes, it told a great story of life in that situation.The movie, on the other hand, was more than just a great story. It payed justice to the book, and then some. The actresses and actors did a fantastic job fleshing out the characters, and giving more depth into their character development. They gave them a new life, picking up the few two-dimensional characters and turning them into characters we could sympathize and identify with.My only issue is that the movie leaned on the portrayal of a "great white savior." It plays on the fact that "only the young white girl can offer salvation", and also leans on some stereotypical caricatures that Hollywood is all to fond of using. Altogether though, it was a good story, with both comedic and tragic parts. I would recommend the book, though, before the movie.

reviews.review_title: A movie about the fight for equality and an end to African American discrimination through the eyes of a young white southern woman and two African American cleaning ladies.
reviews.content: The Help is an inspiring movie about African American discrimination and is based on the book by Kathryn Stockett. It goes through the lives of numerous people in Jackson, Mississippi. Although the transition from book to movie isn't perfect, the writers did a good job at including all the story lines and characters, showing the importance of each one no matter how little a role they had. A really emotional part was when Aibileen had to say goodbye to Mae Mobley at the end of the movie, knowing that she was the only good influence in the girl's life and that her mother wasn't able to take care of her the way she deserved. This scene was put together well and had just as much emotion in it as it did in the novel. The writers did a good job at showing the struggles Aibileen and Skeeter faced when trying to coordinate and get together to write the book about the poor conditions of "The Help" in white households. Overall, this movie is a good representation of what African Americans had to go through in the early to mid 1900s and I would recommend it to anyone.

Over all the movie I thought had a touching message and was brilliantly acted by all the actors that portrayed these characters. As a movie based of a book I say that they followed the book pretty well. The reason this movie did not get a perfect 10 from me will be very apparent if you look at the historical inaccuracy of the book. Although the movie does portray a broad range on the 1960 from Jim Crow laws to the KKK and even Kennedy's assassination it down played the way living in Mississippi in the 1960's would have been like. Instead of showing the horrificness of killing, rape, abuse, lynching and racial slurs it was substituted by mean hose wife's who crated drama. Although maid at that time were a lot closer the the children then their own mothers were it doesn't excuse the fact of the movie tiptoeing around what it was actually like down south. Another thing that they hovered around was the maids telling the story knew and told of why it was dangerous but the sense of the physical danger they could face was missing. Overall it was a well casted movie and very touching storyline but not historically portrayed well.

reviews.review_title: *Contains Spoilers!** Summary and Visual Analysis on The Help
reviews.content: This movie based on a novel originally written by Kathryn Stockett, is showcased in three southern women residing in Jackson, Mississippi in the early 1960's. The movie showcases a spectrum of individual personalities in the lives of Aibileen, Minny and Skeeter (known as Eugenia Phelan.) The movie was primarily focused on the struggles these women faced in a very racially biased south and the adversities women faced on the job market in the 1960's. Stockett created beautiful waves in how she made individuals aware of the ugliness that can happen in life, but the beauty that occurs within that ugliness when times are unforgiving. In the case I'm thinking about, Skeeter, played by Emma Stone, was an aspiring journalist living in Jackson on the forefront of race issues in the south. Skeeter, while searching for her dream job, was also searching for Constantine, her family's loyal maid that was suddenly "let go." In the search for Constantine, Skeeter realized that the maids whom supply services to her friends (essentially labeled "the help") are treated extremely differently than white employees. Later, Skeeter decides to create a column in a local newspaper to display this "mistreatment" and unfairness being done by the families of these maids in the south. Skeeter gets the "okay" to do this through having tips also written within the text in order to gain authority from her primarily white readers.In the column, Skeeter decides to use her comrades to tell their stories in order to obtain excessive attention with hopes to change the trend of blacks being extremely mistreated and unfairly rewarded for their services. Aibileen, a maid and partial nanny, agrees to share her misfortunes and tips for being a maid in the column displayed in their local newspaper. After endless efforts to get more maids and "help" on board with the project, Aibileen's friend, Minny also agrees to share her adversities. Since the column in the local paper was so scrutinized by the individuals who employ the maids and nannies, Skeeter essentially put her works and the words of the help into a book, published it, and entitled it, The Help. (Shmoop.com, 2015)The novel and movie truly opened eyes in a different light. Stockett focused on the women that suffered through the race imbalances in the south. In doing this, a white woman and two black women worked together toward a common goal: to forever cease the harsh realities of being a poorly-paid and treated maid in the deep south during the '60's and '70's. Viewers are able to witness comedy and heart-felt emotions all while receiving a not-so-common history lesson. Not only were these women facing excruciatingly harsh realities in regards to race, but on the job front as well. Skeeter, a young white female was unable to find work for a long period of time. Individuals in the south were not comfortable with allowing someone to essentially "choose the wrong side" and make that information public. Stockett really grand slammed this novel turned into a movie because of the bases she covered. One scene I remember vividly in the movie occurred when Minny, a maid of individuals who treated her below them, though really hilarious, acted in a way that only she could justify. In this scene, Minny baked a pie that she personally delivered to Hilly Holbrook, her house employer. At the end of the movie, it is apparent and learned that inside the pie that Minny baked for the villainous Holbrook, Minny placed her own feces in it. It's little (disgusting) acts displayed like that which really bring humor into a very serious issue. Additionally, Minny gets abused by her husband each night, another adversity she faces in addition to her job. (Shmoop.com, 2015) After I read the first couple chapters of this book, I knew I wanted to see the movie. It is fascinating to me how little individuals know about things that are sublets of the bigger pictures. Sure, we all learned about the endless imbalances of racial issues in the south and across America, especially in the 1950's through the 1970's. But who ever actually thought of the jobs within that conflict that showcased women specifically? It's very moving to me that Stockett focused a novel turned movie on something so miniscule in regards to the "bigger picture" of race, but so damaging to so many women's lives. I admire that she wrote about three different women of more than one race working together to achieve and tackle a goal much bigger than themselves. The Help showcases how America was very close-minded and stubborn to the fact that women of more than one race were gasping for some kind of hold of society and were never rewarded it. Through Skeeter's work and the stories of Minny and Aibileen, The Help was a success and showcased more than enough history for me to open my eyes.

reviews.review_title: You is kind. You is smart. You is important
reviews.content: This film came highly recommended by classmates of mine, and I must say it did not disappoint. After watching this film I now can't wait to read the book.The entire story is based around the theme of social problems. In the film the social problem of race issues are represented when a small minority group makes the choice to speak out and about life as they know it in their small town of Mississippi. The premise of the film starts with Skeeter (Emma Stone) graduating from college and in desperation to start her writing career takes a job writing for a cleaning column at the local newspaper. Skeeter struggles with understanding the simple mindedness of her childhood friends when it comes to how they treat their staff. Skeeter, desperate to share her observations, decides she would like to write about it all but in the perspective of the maids. At first and as expected, the maids refuse to help. After a stroke of courage, Aibileen (Viola Davis) does concede. Skeeter and Aibileen meet and the stories begin to pour. Aibileen's good friend Minny (Octavia Spencer) finds out about the secret meetings of Skeeter and Aibileen and also decides to join in with her story. Many other soon follow their lead to take Skeeter's writings to a much higher level than even she anticipated.The social problems theme in the movie is relatable to that of the film the Green Mile. Although the characters in this film are not being physically abused the maids are constantly being abused verbally and emotionally. Given the time period in which both of these films take place the social problems are almost identical. Both films deal with race as the issue as well as have at least one person of a different race that is able to see past social status and color to try everything they can, to make some sort of difference. In my opinion both the musicality and the lighting not only made this film extraordinary, but helped to re establish the theme of the film. Examples of this can be seen in many different scenes. For instance the lighting constantly reminds us how taboo it is for women like Skeeter to be seen with the help. When Skeeter travels to Aibileen's house to discuss the book, the lighting is dark helping the viewer to grasp the uneasiness as well as restate how unsafe, and illegal it was for Aibileen and Minny to be collaborating with Skeeter. The same can be said for the musicality of the film. Very often there is soft subtle music playing in the background giving the viewer the extra push to feel what the characters are feeling. Specifically in the scene where it is raining and everyone is made aware of how Hilly Holbrook (Bryce Dallas Howard) feels about the help using the restrooms in her house. The scene starts with slow, soft, subtle music by the end of the scene Minny has been fired and is walking in a storm the slow heartbreaking music gets louder forcing the viewer to be emotionally vested in what just took place for Minny, and once again re iterating the theme of what is or was socially acceptable in that time period and in the film. For a film that takes place roughly 50 years ago in the civil rights era, and primarily focuses on the social problems of that era, it was both entertaining and engaging.

Isn't it by pure racism ? In this society, the color of the skin decides which feelings an individual must have and how he needs to behave. Skeeter, the heroine, decides to write a novel and she interviews the black maids who have spent their life taking care of prominent southern families. We discover the life of these women. They are mistreated by the society, denigrated by their bosses but loved by the children they raise. These maids are extremely affected : we can see their difficulties and how they face their situations. The variety of stories of the different maids allows the audience to be affected differently. It depends on each one's sensitivity. The Help is a movie about women. The character of Skeeter represents the modern woman who tries to get her liberty through her work. She is the opposite of Hilly Holbrook and her friends who want to continue the traditions. The director of the movie never judges but he simply describes how things were during racial segregation in the United States. After seeing the movie, we understand how the American society of the 1960s was. Humor as well as emotions are waiting for you, allowing to understand this difficult social and racial subject.

reviews.review_title: The Help is the movie that can teach the world with its an amazing messages.
reviews.content: The Help is a movie that focuses on the life style of the white and colored people of Jackson, Mississippi in early 19 century. Emma Stone, who played the character of Skeeter took a risk of contacting the black maids in that city to gather the information about their life/what it looks like to be them. The major actor/actress with their character names are: Emma Stone played as Eugenia Skeeter, Viola Davis as Aibileen Clark, Octavia Spencer as Minny Jackson, Bryce Dallas as Hilly Holbrook, and Jessica Chastain as Celia Foote. Skeeter was an educated young lady who wanted to be a write. In those days majority of the women are stay home moms. Skeeter had a pressure from her mom and her society that she wasn't married even if that wasn't her first priority at that time. Skeeter had a job, and that made her different from the other women in the society in those days as well. Skeeter asked Aibleen if she could interview her what it looks like to raise other people's children while her own kinds are looked down by others. Even if she wasn't 100% happy to do that because of the risk that could come with it, she finally agreed. She continued her interview, but still she needed another maid to gather the information from since her publisher, who lived in New York pushed her to do that. While Skeeter and Aibleen were doing the interview secretly, Minny, Aibileen's friend caught them, and she went crazy. She was so sad that Aibileen agreed to take the risk of doing the interview. Minny's anger didn't stay longer. She also decided to join. Her publisher kept pushing Skeeter to get the information at least from dozen of them, which wasn't easy to find all these colored maids who would be willing to give the information. The pressure from white people on the black people had become worst. The black kids are killed on the street, black and white people couldn't share the same taxi, they didn't have pay vacation, and the black maid couldn't use their employer's bathroom. These and other unpleasant deeds encouraged others to give their testimony, and Skeeter got lucky. She was able to gather all the information she needed and also she added about the maid who raised her as well. Her book titled The Help finally published. Their voice was heard by others through this book. Skeeter finally got a job in New York and Aibileen got fired from the job. Doing what Skeeter did wasn't totally easy at that time for her and also for the maids. But courage and determination is what you can see in all of them to do what they did. The themes of this movie are: moral implication. The way white people treated their maid had a huge effect on their moral and totally on the community of black people in that area. The other theme is social problem. Also human relationships and moral riddle are two of the themes that I found critical. The relationship between Skeeter and those maids has brought the life change of that community though the risk was huge and tough. The themes of The Help reminded me the movie called 12 Years a Slave. The messages of these two movies are very similar for me. Many different techniques were used in The Help. One of these many techniques that were used was, the lighting. In the scene where Skeeter interviewed Aibileen, the light wasn't very bright and this showed to me that they were hiding from others and that the decision they took was moral riddle. The other one is the scene where Celia made speech at the charity meeting. In this scene, the angel of the camera showed that there is a boss and employee relationships between Celia and the maids. This is relevant to the moral implication. Generally, the help is a very teaching movie that can be message to the whole world. These problems are not limited to Mississippi. People around the world can learn from this movie since the themes can be important messages to the whole world as well.

If this film were total fiction bearing no relation to reality, it would still be worth seeing for the fine acting and production values--even if some of the young white women approached "Southern Gothic." But it wasn't fiction--at least, the depiction of Southern society wasn't. As I watched I kept drifting back to small-town South Carolina in the 1950s, where I grew up. It was moving and disturbing to be reminded how black people were treated then--loved and yet "kept down in their place." Our neighborhood was all middle-class and every family had a maid. There were plenty of boys my age, we visited in each other's homes, and called every maid by her first name. One even started a baseball team for the little white boys, for which her reward was a visit by the Klan.Our maid helped my mother cook and clean. One of my parents picked her up and took her home every day--and she rode in the back seat. She ate her lunch in our kitchen--without being allowed to use our utensils. I remember her eating with her fingers. I do not remember ever seeing her use our bathrooms. I thought about that during the movie and truly cannot recall what she did, an embarrassing gap in memory.I do remember when my father was out of work and our maid had to be cut back to three days a week. I actually cried; she was a member of our family. When talk about civil rights began in the late 1950s, my mother became annoyed at our maid for getting "uppity." And so it went. We moved to central Florida in 1961, where there were no maids.Travel back in time with this film. It's quite real, and I highly recommend it.
